EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe storms developed in the Nebraska Panhandle during the early evening hours of June 6th. As this activity tracked east, a broken line of strong to severe thunderstorms developed. Hail up to the size of ping pong balls, thunderstorm wind gusts to 70 MPH and a brief tornado touchdown were reported. Heavy rain also fell leading to flash flooding in western Keith county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail predominately penny size with some quarter size hail mixed in.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Most of the hail was penny to nickle sized with some ping pong ball size hail mixed in.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated thunderstorms developed in northwestern Cherry county during the early evening hours of June 8th. This activity developed along a stationary front which was anchored from northwestern Nebraska into east central Nebraska. As this activity pushed east along the front, a line of storms developed and tracked to the east southeast into portions of central Nebraska. Hail up to two inches in diameter and thunderstorm wind damage was reported. The activity persisted into the early morning hours of June 9th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Quarter to golf ball size hail reported at this location.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Four inch diameter tree limbs knocked down along with dime sized hail.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Below normal rainfall fell during the month of March 2018, with very little snowfall as well. This led to severe drought conditions spreading across most of the area, with some areas of south central Kansas now moving into extreme drought conditions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Drought conditions worsened during the month of March, 2018. By the end of the month the county had climbed into the extreme drought category.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep low pressure located over Iowa.  Northwest winds on the western and southwest side of the low, produced wind of 50 to 60 mph across portions of central and south central Kansas during the daytime hours of March 6th, 2018.  The strongest wind gust was reported near the Russell airport of 61 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Behind a cold front, high winds on the backside of a weak upper level disturbance reached the ground in a few counties. In Sherman County, the peak gust was 61 MPH at Goodland. Wallace and Gove counties also experienced high winds.||To the east ahead of the cold front, a line of strong to severe thunderstorms was moving east across Decatur, Norton, and Graham counties.  These storms produced large hail and severe wind gusts.  The largest hail size reported was golf ball at Norton, and the highest wind gust was 63 MPH at Hill City.

Through the day on February 20, 2018 numerous accidents occurred as a result of widespread accumulating ice. Patchy freezing drizzle started as early as midnight on the morning of February 20, but the heavier rain fell through the morning and early afternoon hours. Numerous powerlines and trees sustained some damage from the accumulation of 1/8 to 1/3 inch of ice across a widespread area, including the Kansas City metro area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Through the day on February 20, 2018 numerous accidents occurred as a result of widespread accumulating ice. Patchy freezing drizzle started as early as midnight on the morning of February 20, but the heavier rain fell through the morning and early afternoon hours. Numerous powerlines and trees sustained some damage from the accumulation of 1/8 to 1/3 inch of ice across a widespread area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms developed along and ahead of a quasi-stationary front that was draped across the area. One long-lived supercell produced a brief tornado northwest of Ark City before exiting into Oklahoma and becoming stationary. The supercell then moved north and produced multiple tornadoes as a large bow echo thunderstorm merged with the supercell in central Cowley County. This was quickly followed by several shorter-lived Quasi-Linear Convective System (QLCS) tornadoes north and east of Winfield.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Very brief touchdown in open country.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of storms move east across the southern sections of Kansas producing large hail, very strong winds, and heavy rains.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: With shallow cold air in place, warm advection associated with a weak wave of low pressure moving northeast from Kansas to Wisconsin produced a shield of light precipitation across northeast Nebraska. While most precipitation was in the form of light freezing rain and freezing drizzle on February 19 which resulted in a 0.05 to 0.10 inch ice accumulation, a second round of precipitation early on February 20 brought a dusting of less than an inch of snow which coated the ice and produced hazardous travel conditions. For the two day period, school delays were common for those not already out for the Washington's Birthday holiday.

With shallow cold air in place, warm advection associated with a weak wave of low pressure moving northeast from Kansas to Wisconsin produced a shield of light precipitation across northeast Nebraska. While most precipitation was in the form of light freezing rain and freezing drizzle on February 19 which resulted in a 0.05 to 0.10 inch ice accumulation, a second round of precipitation early on February 20 brought a dusting of less than an inch of snow which coated the ice and produced hazardous travel conditions. For the two day period, school delays were common for those not already out for the Washington's Birthday holiday.

Ejection of the main upper level wave (which had already steered a pair of snow producing systems across the area during the prior week) brought yet another light to moderate snowfall over northwest Iowa, southeast South Dakota, northeast Nebraska and southwest Minnesota. It generally snowed for three to five hours at most across northeast Nebraska, briefly with visibility of a mile or less. Snowfall amounts were less than 2 inches, but road conditions quickly became hazardous due to the rate of snowfall.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A band of light to briefly moderate snowfall pushed across northeast Nebraska through early afternoon. Snowfall amounts were generally light, with 0.7 inch at Concord.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A second disturbance in three days traversed the deep western trough, and the associated jet streak produced another area of snowfall across northeast Nebraska. Intensity waned for a short time in the late afternoon, allowing a brief change to light freezing drizzle. Snowfall varied from 1 to 2 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Light freezing drizzle occurred at times between 1500CST and 1800CST, but mainly snowfall occurred resulting in an accumulation of 1.0 inch at Emerson.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Ejection of the main upper level wave (which had already steered a pair of snow producing systems across the area during the prior week) brought yet another light to moderate snowfall over northwest Iowa, southeast South Dakota, northeast Nebraska and southwest Minnesota. It generally snowed for three to five hours at most across northeast Nebraska, briefly with visibility of a mile or less. Snowfall amounts were less than 2 inches, but road conditions quickly became hazardous due to the rate of snowfall.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A band of light to briefly moderate snowfall pushed across northeast Nebraska through early afternoon. Snowfall amounts were generally light, with 0.7 inch at Concord.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A second disturbance in three days traversed the deep western trough, and the associated jet streak produced another area of snowfall across northeast Nebraska. Intensity waned for a short time in the late afternoon, allowing a brief change to light freezing drizzle. Snowfall varied from 1 to 2 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Light freezing drizzle occurred at times between 1500CST and 1800CST, but mainly snowfall occurred resulting in an accumulation of 1.2 inches at Newcastle.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level system moved across a moderately unstable atmosphere and produced widespread snow across much of the area.  The heaviest amounts were north of highway 50 and along and west of highway 283.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall of around 1 inch was reported across the county with the exception of the far southwest part of the county which had amounts up to 3.5 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front swept across the region and there were a few high wind gusts reported behind the front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Reported at the Dodge City airport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level system moved across a moderately unstable atmosphere and produced widespread snow across much of the area.  The heaviest amounts were north of highway 50 and along and west of highway 283.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall of 2 to 3 inches was common across the north half of the county including the Kalvesta area.  Lighter amounts were reported south of this area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of light snow fell across southeast Nebraska early in the morning on February 4th.  Amounts were generally an inch or less.  The highest amount was 1.5 inches at Feirbury in Jefferson County.  Some wind with the light snow caused blowing snow conditions.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper-deck wave pushed a strong cold front across Kansas throughout the night and early morning of the 19th and 20th. The result was that widespread sleet and freezing rain occurred across all of the WFO Wichita County Warning Area with most of the adverse winter weather occurring on the 20th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Around 0.25 inch of glaze accumulated on trees and power lines 5 miles north of Altoona. Road surfaces were beginning to freeze.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Freezing rain produced around 0.25 inch of glaze on trees and power lines 5 miles east southeast of Humboldt and around 0.12 inch 2 miles east of Iola. In several areas, the power lines began to sag. Glazing did not occur on roads and highways.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High winds on the backside of an upper level storm system reached the ground in Hitchcock and Red Willow counties.  The peak wind gust was 66 MPH at McCook.  The high winds also fueled a wildfire which consumed a house on the north side of McCook.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The high winds caused a piece of metal roofing to touch an overhead power line, igniting the fire three miles northwest of McCook.  The high winds pushed the fire in a southerly direction, burning 212 acres.  Evacuations were ordered for the northwest part of McCook totaling 446 people.  McCook elementary school students were moved to the high school.  Sixteen people were treated for burns and smoke inhalation.  The only severe burn victim was a transient living in a canyon.  One home on the north edge of McCook was destroyed by the fire.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A bitter cold arctic air mass brought dangerous wind chills to portions of north central Nebraska during the late evening Tuesday, February 20th, and the overnight and morning hours on Wednesday, February 21st. Lowest wind chills of 30 to 39 below occurred.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind Chills as low as 30 below occurred in western Cherry County during the overnight  and into the morning hours.  Nearby Nearby Pine Ridge, South Dakota ASOS recorded a lowest wind chill of 30 below at 11 pm MST. Nearby Valentine ASOS recorded a lowest wind chill of 30 below at 5 am MST and again at 7 am MST.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A bitter cold arctic air mass brought dangerous wind chills to portions of north central Nebraska during the late evening Tuesday, February 20th, and the overnight and morning hours on Wednesday, February 21st. Lowest wind chills of 30 to 39 below occurred.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind Chills as low as 30 below occurred in eastern Cherry County during the early morning.  Valentine ASOS recorded a lowest wind chill of 30 below at 6 am CST and again at 8 am CST.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A bitter cold arctic air mass brought dangerous wind chills to portions of north central Nebraska during the late evening Tuesday, February 20th, and the overnight and morning hours on Wednesday, February 21st. Lowest wind chills of 30 to 39 below occurred.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind Chills as low as 38 below occurred in Sheridan County from late evening, through the overnight and into the morning hours.  Nearby Alliance ASOS recorded wind chills as low as 31 below to 38 below between 11 pm MST and 7 am MST.  Nearby Pine Ridge, South Dakota ASOS also recorded a lowest wind chill of 30 below at 11 pm MST.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated thunderstorms developed in northwestern Cherry county during the early evening hours of June 8th. This activity developed along a stationary front which was anchored from northwestern Nebraska into east central Nebraska. As this activity pushed east along the front, a line of storms developed and tracked to the east southeast into portions of central Nebraska. Hail up to two inches in diameter and thunderstorm wind damage was reported. The activity persisted into the early morning hours of June 9th.

Hail up to two inches in diameter and thunderstorm wind damage was reported. The activity persisted into the early morning hours of June 9th.

Severe storms developed in the Nebraska Panhandle during the early evening hours of June 6th. As this activity tracked east, a broken line of strong to severe thunderstorms developed. Hail up to the size of ping pong balls, thunderstorm wind gusts to 70 MPH and a brief tornado touchdown were reported. Heavy rain also fell leading to flash flooding in western Keith county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Cooperative observer reports water over highway 30 approximately 3 miles west of Brule.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms developed along and ahead of a quasi-stationary front that was draped across the area. One long-lived supercell produced a brief tornado northwest of Ark City before exiting into Oklahoma and becoming stationary. The supercell then moved north and produced multiple tornadoes as a large bow echo thunderstorm merged with the supercell in central Cowley County. This was quickly followed by several shorter-lived Quasi-Linear Convective System (QLCS) tornadoes north and east of Winfield.

Severe thunderstorms developed along and ahead of a quasi-stationary front that was draped across the area. One long-lived supercell produced a brief tornado northwest of Ark City before exiting into Oklahoma and becoming stationary. This was quickly followed by several shorter-lived Quasi-Linear Convective System (QLCS) tornadoes north and east of Winfield.

A deep trough again progressed through the Rockies and evolved to a compact closed mid-level circulation drifting across eastern Nebraska and Iowa on April 18. Weak instability resulted in some scattered thunder with sleet and snow from the lower Missouri River valley through northwest Iowa. Marginally warmer temperatures aloft allowed for some light mixed precipitation early on April 18, but a quick transition to snow occurred in the pre-dawn hours, leaving behind between 2 and 6 inches snowfall across areas of northeast Nebraska.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mixed precipitation started in the early morning hours, but changed rapidly to snow after 0100CST. Snowfall totaled 5.2 inches at Newcastle and 3.0 inches at Concord.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Late in the night from the 30th to early in the morning on the 31st severe thunderstorms raced across Southern Kansas. Clocked in most cases from 60 to 70 mph, the severe thunderstorms struck many areas with damaging, and at times, destructive winds, that frequently reached 60 to 80 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Power outages were reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Torrential rains caused significant rises on the Saline River. The river spilled out of its banks in and around Fairport, where water 2 to 4 feet deep inundated a small section of Fairport Road near the bridges. Sand bags were placed around one home. Floods also occurred across a section of this road about 1 mile southeast of Fairport on 176th Street.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The very heavy rains caused such significant rises on the Saline River that it overflowed around Fairport. Fairport Road was flooded at both the east and west entrances into Fairport. One section of Fairport Road was flooded 2 to 4 feet deep near the river bridges. Sand bags were placed around 1 home. Flooding also occurred about 1 mile southeast of Fairport on 176th Street.

Late in the night from the 30th to early in the morning on the 31st severe thunderstorms raced across Southern Kansas. Clocked in most cases from 60 to 70 mph, the severe thunderstorms struck many areas with damaging, and at times, destructive winds, that frequently reached 60 to 80 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: No damage was reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Late in the night from the 30th to early in the morning on the 31st severe thunderstorms raced across Southern Kansas. Clocked in most cases from 60 to 70 mph, the severe thunderstorms struck many areas with damaging, and at times, destructive winds, that frequently reached 60 to 80 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The estimated 70-mph winds caused power outages in Harper.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated severe storms moved across portions of Reno county, Kansas, on May 10th, 2018.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Quarter sized hail was reported to KWCH TV by the public.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe to extreme drought persisted over a good portions of central and south central Kansas during the month of May.  Welcome rainfall during the beginning of the month and again at the end of the month, improved the drought some over south central Kansas by the end of the month.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Extreme drought conditions persisted over the entire county for the month of May.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Extreme drought conditions persisted over the northwest portions of county.  But welcome rainfall during the beginning and end of the month actually improved the drought to severe for southeast portions of the county by the end of the month.

Severe thunderstorms developed along and ahead of a quasi-stationary front that was draped across the area. One long-lived supercell produced a brief tornado northwest of Ark City before exiting into Oklahoma and becoming stationary. The supercell then moved north and produced multiple tornadoes as a large bow echo thunderstorm merged with the supercell in central Cowley County. This was quickly followed by several shorter-lived Quasi-Linear Convective System (QLCS) tornadoes north and east of Winfield.

A deep trough again progressed through the Rockies and evolved to a compact closed mid-level circulation drifting across eastern Nebraska and Iowa on April 18. Weak instability resulted in some scattered thunder with sleet and snow from the lower Missouri River valley through northwest Iowa. Marginally warmer temperatures aloft allowed for some light mixed precipitation early on April 18, but a quick transition to snow occurred in the pre-dawn hours, leaving behind between 2 and 6 inches snowfall across areas of northeast Nebraska.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mixed precipitation started in the early morning hours, but changed rapidly to snow after 0100CST.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A winter storm produced heavy snowfall beginning in the early morning hours on January 21st continuing into the morning hours on January 22nd across western and north central Nebraska. Snowfall amounts ranged from 8 to 12 inches across much of the area. Northwest winds increased to 20 to 35 mph during the afternoon and evening on January 21st, and into the morning hours on January 22nd. This caused blizzard conditions in some areas with considerable blowing and drifting, and visibility as low as a quarter mile at times.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall amounts from 5 to 9 inches occurred across Holt County. Northwest winds of 20 to 35 mph, with gusts to 40 mph occurred during the evening hours on January 21st through the morning hours on January 22nd. Considerable blowing and drifting and visibility of a quarter mile or less occurred.  Snow drifts of 2 to 4 feet were reported. Schools were closed Monday. Some roads became closed. especially county roads.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A bitter cold arctic air mass brought dangerous wind chills to portions of north central Nebraska during the overnight and morning hours on Sunday, December 31st, 2017 and continued to produce dangerous wind chills during the overnight and morning hours on Monday, January 1st, 2018. Lowest wind chills of 30 to 39 below were common.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dangerous wind chills of 30 to 35 below zero occurred across eastern Cherry County during the overnight and morning hours on Monday, January 1st. The Valentine ASOS recorded a lowest wind chill of 35 below at 352 am CST while a mesonet station 14 miles north northeast of Brownlee recorded a lowest wind chill of 30 below at 614 am CST.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A bitter cold arctic air mass brought dangerous wind chills to portions of north central Nebraska during the early morning hours on Tuesday, January 16th, 2018. Lowest wind chills of 30 to 35 below were common.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A mesonet site located 6 miles northwest of Dunning recorded a lowest wind chill of 30 below at 356 am CST and again at 500 am CST. Lowest wind chill values of 30 to 35 below were common across Blaine County during the early morning hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A bitter cold arctic air mass brought dangerous wind chills to portions of north central Nebraska during the early morning hours on Tuesday, January 16th, 2018. Lowest wind chills of 30 to 35 below were common.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Gordon AWOS site recorded a lowest wind chill of 30 below at 215 am MST. Lowest wind chill values of 30 to 35 below were common across Sheridan County during the early morning hours.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A mesonet site located 12 miles southwest of Naper recorded a lowest wind chill of 30 below at 200 am CST and 31 below at 425 am CST. Lowest wind chill values of 30 to 35 below were common across Keya Paha County during the early morning hours.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A mesonet site located 8 miles west northwest of Rose recorded a lowest wind chill of 30 below at 1240 am CST and 32 below at 400 am CST. Lowest wind chill values of 30 to 35 below were common across Brown County during the early morning hours.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A general public with a weather station site located 8 miles west southwest of Callaway recorded a lowest wind chill of 30 below at 356 am CST and again at 415 am CST. Lowest wind chill values of 30 to 35 below were common across Custer County during the early morning hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A vigorous late season winter storm brought heavy wet snow and blowing snow from strong winds.  Near-blizzard conditions were frequently observed, with several highways closed, including Interstate 80 from the Wyoming border to east of Sidney.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Four to six inches of wet snow was observed county wide.  Strong winds to 45 mph created near-blizzard conditions from blowing snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the morning through mid afternoon freezing drizzle occurred over Northwest Kansas.  Ice accumulations ranged from a trace up to 0.38, with the highest ice accumulation reported in St. Francis.  Mid afternoon a band of moderate to heavy snow moved east into Kansas.  During the night the first band gradually ended as a second band of moderate to heavy snow developed and moved east.  Wind gusts were mostly in the 20-40 MPH range, but the strongest wind gust reported was 57 MPH at Goodland.  The combination of moderate to heavy snow along with strong winds caused zero to near zero visibility under each band of snow.  Highway 40 and 83 were closed in Logan County due to the hazardous driving conditions, stranding many motorists in Oakley.  Atleast one motorist was stranded on Highway 40.  The highest snowfall amount was 13 inches reported in northwest Sherman County.  Snowfall amounts declined to the east.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall across the county was around 11 inches.  Duration of the wind gusts during the storm were below blizzard criteria.  However blizzard like conditions were observed.  Prior to the snow occurring freezing drizzle fell, with ice accumulation totals of 0.25 to 0.38.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the morning through mid afternoon freezing drizzle occurred over Northwest Kansas.  Ice accumulations ranged from a trace up to 0.38, with the highest ice accumulation reported in St. Francis.  Mid afternoon a band of moderate to heavy snow moved east into Kansas.  During the night the first band gradually ended as a second band of moderate to heavy snow developed and moved east.  Wind gusts were mostly in the 20-40 MPH range, but the strongest wind gust reported was 57 MPH at Goodland.  The combination of moderate to heavy snow along with strong winds caused zero to near zero visibility under each band of snow. The highest snowfall amount was 13 inches reported in northwest Sherman County.  Snowfall amounts declined to the east.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The strong winds and moderate to heavy snow caused power to go out for roughly 400 people in Logan County.  Highway 83 and 40 were both closed in the county.  A semi was blocking the highway on Highway 83.  Snowfall amounts ranged from three to five inches across the county from south to north.  Wind gusts were below blizzard criteria.  However blizzard like conditions were observed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Upper level trough pushing through the region failed to phase a northern and southern stream component, resulting in limited and fairly light snowfall, but a period of strong and gusty northwest winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Just a dusting of light snowfall occurred over a 3 to 4 hour period after midnight on January 11, but with winds gusting to 40 to 50 mph, visibility fell to a mile or less briefly creating travel difficulty. Strong wind gusts continued well through the daylight hours on January 11, with peak winds of 46 mph at Wayne and 52 mph at Sioux City.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The anomalously dry period that plagued the region during the summer of 2018 continued into and through July. Most areas were about 2 inches short of normal precipitation for the month of July.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The abnormally dry summer continued into and through July for Johnson County. The Drought Monitor put the county in D3 and maintained it into August. As of yet, the breadth and magnitude of the impacts are unknown.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A quick moving clipper system deepened rapidly and carved out a closed upper level low across the western Great Lakes as it dropped southeast from the Canadian prairie provinces on the evening of January 14. The system produced an inch or less snowfall through January 15, as well as a brutal rush of arctic air into the region with winds gusting up to 35 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Northwest winds gusting to 25 to 35 mph along with temperatures falling to subzero levels produced dangerous wind chills from -25 to -35. An inch of snowfall was measured at Emerson.

This caused blizzard conditions in some areas with considerable blowing and drifting, and visibility as low as a quarter mile at times.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall amounts from 4 to 9 inches occurred across Sheridan County. The heaviest amounts occurred in northern Sheridan County. Northwest winds of 20 to 35 mph occurred during the evening hours on January 21st through the early morning hours on January 22nd. Some blowing and drifting with visibilities of a quarter mile at times occurred.  Snow drifts of 1 to 2 feet were reported. Schools were closed Monday.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level low moved out of the Four Corners region and into the Southern Rockies before ejecting northeastward across Kansas. Some of the precipitation associated with the upper level system turned to snow.  There was at least 3 inches reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observed at the Garden City airport at 1134 PM.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Wind chills from -35 to -45 continued through the morning hours across northwest Iowa as a strong arctic surface ridge continued to slide into the Northern Plains. This continued the extreme cold which initiated during late December 2017.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: West to northwest winds at times from 6 to 11 mph combined with air temperatures around 20 below to 30 below zero to produce bitterly cold wind chills around -35 to -45 through the morning hours of New Year's Day. The actual air temperature plunged to a record -32 at Concord.  As southerly return flow developed behind the retreating ridge, not as extreme wind chills of -20 to -30 occurred from the evening of January 1st into mid morning of January 2nd.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large upper level low pressure area developed across Kansas and lifted into Iowa by December 2. The leading edge of the system produced some light ice accumulations from southeast South Dakota into northwest Iowa on early Saturday morning. Heavy snow and wind developed during Saturday and Saturday evening, but a weak downslope impact reduced snow amounts closer to Interstate 29 in eastern South Dakota.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: After a brief period of freezing rain which produced a glaze of light icing during the early morning of December 1, heavy snow occurred for numerous hours. Accumulations over less than a 24-hour period totaled 8.0 inches at Emerson. Winds gusted to 30 to 40 mph and combined with snowfall to produce several hours of visibility of a half mile or less along with treacherous travel.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: After a brief period of freezing rain which produced a glaze of light icing during the early morning of December 1, heavy snow occurred for numerous hours. Accumulations over less than a 24-hour period totaled 11.1 inches at Concord and 6.0 inches at Newcastle. |Winds gusted to 30 to 40 mph and combined with snowfall to produce several hours of visibility of a half mile or less along with treacherous travel.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A long duration winter weather event ensued after Christmas as a full-latitude trough moved through the Rockies on December 26, initiating cyclogenesis as the mid-level wave closed off and lifted northeast from TX into KS by early on December 27. A leading pulse of warm advection ahead of the main system produced a swath of mixed precipitation on the 26th into early on the 27th across southeast SD and southwest MN. This area weakened before the main wave lifted across the area on the 27th and sheared into northern Minnesota by early morning December 28. A significant dry slot pushed across Iowa early on the 27th allowing for a brief change in precipitation to liquid or freezing precipitation. Heavier snowfall redeveloped within the TROWAL during the 27th and continued through the following night across southeast SD into southwest MN. ||As the area of low pressure strengthened moving across Iowa during the afternoon of December 27, winds increased with gusts of 40 to 55 mph common into the early morning of December 28.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: After a period of light wintry mix, snow developed and winds increased across far southeast South Dakota, southwest Minnesota, far northwest Iowa and northeast Nebraska. Snowfall generally totaled 3 to 5 inches, with 4 to 6 inches near southern Sioux Falls. Other snowfall totals were 5.9 inches at Worthington MN, 5.0 inches at Canton SD, 4.0 inches near Vermillion SD, 3.5 inches near Larchwood IA, 3.0 inches at Luverne, MN and 2.3 inches at Concord NE. Visibility was reduced to a mile or less while heavier snowfall occurred, and winds were gusting to 37 mph at Slayton, 38 mph at Luverne and 46 mph at Worthington.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall of 2 to 3 inches with drifting was reported across the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Precipitation picked up during August, especially in some of the hardest hit drought areas, but in a lot of cases the damage had already been done, and while the rains did pick back up the ground soil was so parched that it made hardly a dent in the drought across northeast Kansas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: While rain did pick up across the area through the month of August, drought conditions saw some improvement by the end of the month. The impacts and economic impact across far eastern Kansas as a result of the drought are as of yet unclear, but across much of the Midwest several crops and fields were deemed unfit for harvest and were either lost or baled for cattle feed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On the morning of January 11th, 2018, an area of low pressure rapidly moved northeast from the Texas Panhandle. As the low pressure area moved northeast, extremely cold temperatures to the northwest of the low plunged south across portions of central and south central Kansas.  This caused the precipitation to rapidly turn over to freezing rain, sleet, and eventually snow. This quick turnover rapidly made roadways very slick, with numerous accidents and slide offs associated with the slippery roadways.  The heaviest snowfall occurred across Northwest Saline County where 4 to 5 inch accumulations were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wintry mix of freezing rain, sleet and snow led to treacherous driving conditions across most of Saline County, Kansas.  Numerous accidents and slide offs were reported along Interstate 70 and Interstate 135 near Salina.  The heaviest snowfall occurred to the northwest of Salina where 4 to 5 inches were reported.

The heaviest snowfall occurred across Northwest Saline County where 4 to 5 inch accumulations were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A mixture of freezing rain, sleet and snow spread across McPherson County, Kansas early in the morning of January 11th, 2018. This made travel dangerous as numerous accidents and slide-offs occurred. The greatest snow accumulations, 2 to 3 inches, were reported across Western and Northern McPherson County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A winter storm produced heavy snowfall beginning in the early morning hours on January 21st continuing into the morning hours on January 22nd across western and north central Nebraska. Snowfall amounts ranged from 8 to 12 inches across much of the area. Northwest winds increased to 20 to 35 mph during the afternoon and evening on January 21st, and into the morning hours on January 22nd. This caused blizzard conditions in some areas with considerable blowing and drifting, and visibility as low as a quarter mile at times.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall amounts from 10 to 13 inches occurred across Perkins County. Northwest winds of 20 to 35 mph, with gusts to 45 mph occurred during the evening hours on January 21st through the early morning hours on January 22nd. Considerable blowing and drifting and visibility of a quarter mile or less occurred.  Snow drifts of 3 to 5 feet were reported. Schools were closed Monday and some roads became closed, especially county roads.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Periods of one-quarter mile visibility occurred along with frequent wind gusts between 40 and 50 mph on this Monday. Snowfall amounts ranged from 3 to 6 inches, with Plainville reporting the highest amount of 6 inches. Webster Dam and Logan measured 4 inches with 3 inches in Phillipsburg. This snow storm was associated with low pressure that moved east across Kansas and deepened near Kansas City during the morning hours. This low then occluded over Iowa. This system formed as an upper-level trough over the western U.S. moved east and intensified over Colorado.

A strong mid-level trough pushed across the Rockies on January 21, and developed into a closed cyclone across the central Plains. As low pressure deepened moving from Kansas to the Great Lakes on January 22, precipitation wrapped back into a tight deformation zone on the northwest flank of the storm. Initially warm enough for rain, colder air rushed in as northwest winds rapidly increased to a gusty 35 to 55 mph and brought a rapid change to snow late on January 21 and early January 22. Widespread visibility of a quarter mile or less with snow, heavy at times, continued through mid afternoon. Snow amassed to 8 to 13 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Rain changed to snow around 0000CST January 22, with northwest winds increasing during the early morning to a gusty 35 to 45 mph. Frequent wind gusts along with heavy falling snow produced near zero visibility starting before daybreak, which continued into late afternoon. The Nebraska Dept. of Transportation pulled plows off roads around 0900CST. Winds peaked late morning, with reports of drifts up to 4 feet making roads impassible. Weather conditions gradually improved toward 1700CST, but travel was not advised well into Monday night. Total snowfall was measured at 12.5 inches at Emerson.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An intense cyclone that moved northeast across Kansas enabled northwest winds from 30 to 40 mph to lash the region. Gusts reached 40 to 50 mph and were certainly strong enough to cause some tree damage in parts of South-Central Kansas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The CO-OP observer in Bluff City reported that the strong winds downed a 6-inch diameter limb in their back yard. Since the tree damage was not discovered until the following morning, the time of the event is an estimate.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the morning through mid afternoon freezing drizzle occurred over Northwest Kansas.  Ice accumulations ranged from a trace up to 0.38, with the highest ice accumulation reported in St. Francis.  Mid afternoon a band of moderate to heavy snow moved east into Kansas.  During the night the first band gradually ended as a second band of moderate to heavy snow developed and moved east.  Wind gusts were mostly in the 20-40 MPH range, but the strongest wind gust reported was 57 MPH at Goodland.  The combination of moderate to heavy snow along with strong winds caused zero to near zero visibility under each band of snow.  Highway 40 and 83 were closed in Logan County due to the hazardous driving conditions, stranding many motorists in Oakley.  Atleast one motorist was stranded on Highway 40.  The highest snowfall amount was 13 inches reported in northwest Sherman County.  Snowfall amounts declined to the east.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall across the county ranged from 6 to 13 inches from south to north.  Prior to the snow occurring 0.10 of ice accumulation was reported in Goodland.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow and blizzard conditions affected south central Nebraska on this Monday, with the worst conditions north of Interstate 80. On Sunday, a band of snow developed from northwest Kansas and extended northeast into the Nebraska Sandhills. This band formed in the deformation zone on the west side of the upper-level low and it remained stationary. The eastward fringe of this band affected areas from Cambridge to Lexington to Ord from 3 pm until 10 pm CST. Most of south central Nebraska was in the dry slot Sunday into Sunday evening. Multiple narrow bands of rain began forming over eastern Kansas, southeast Nebraska, and Iowa, east of the low Sunday evening. These bands rotated cyclonically, expanded and eventually merged with the larger snow band to the west which finally began moving east after midnight. By daybreak Monday, one large snow band extended from south central Nebraska into southern Minnesota. Over central Nebraska, the snow was heaviest and most persistent along and north of Highway 92, from 3 am to 9 am CST. At least 10 inches of snow fell over most of that area. The highest amounts were 14 inches at Belgrade and St. Paul. Greeley measured 12 inches, with 11 inches at Genoa, Osceola, and Shelby, and 10 inches at Ord. Other amounts of note include 7 inches at Grand Island and Ravenna. The southern tail of this band swept across the rest of south central Nebraska, but its narrow character resulted in much lower snow accumulations. One to 5 inches of snow fell from near Interstate 80 to the Kansas state line, with the lowest amounts near the state line. ||Strong winds developed with widespread gusts of 45 to 58 mph east of Highway 183. The highest wind gusts were 58 mph at Hastings and 57 mph at Cairo. This resulted in blizzard or near-blizzard conditions in many areas, but especially along and north of Interstate 80, with near white-out conditions reported. Conditions were so bad that the Nebraska Department of Transportation pulled their plows off the roads in Buffalo and Hall counties for about 2 hours. Numerous roads and highways were closed or reported as impassible, including portions of Highways 11, 58, and 92. Northbound Highway 281 was closed in Grand Island just north of Stolley Park Rd because two semi trucks could not make it over the overpass. Nebraska State Patrol responded to numerous vehicle accidents and vehicles that became stuck. Dozens of vehicles remained stranded as conditions were too dangerous for tow truck operators. The Polk county sheriff reported a number of cars slid into ditches on Highway 81. Portions of Interstate 80 in York county were closed for a couple hours due to multiple accidents. Power lines were reported down in Phelps county, with isolated power outages also reported in and near Lexington and from Franklin county northeast to Hamilton and Merrick counties. Numerous schools, government offices, and businesses were closed Monday, as well as the regional airports in Grand Island and Kearney. The University of Nebraska at Kearney, Hastings College, and all Central Community Colleges at Lexington, Ord, Kearney, Hastings, and Grand Island were also closed. Snow emergencies were declared in Aurora, Cozad, Gibbon, Gothenburg, Grand Island, Kearney, Hastings, Holdrege, Minden, and St. Paul. Since most people stayed off the roads, crews were able to plow roads, and life was back to normal by Tuesday.||The snow storm was associated with low pressure that moved east across Kansas and deepened near Kansas City during the morning hours. This low then occluded over Iowa. This system formed as an upper-level trough over the western U.S. moved east and intensified over Colorado.

The highest amounts were 14 inches at Belgrade and St. Paul. Greeley measured 12 inches, with 11 inches at Genoa, Osceola, and Shelby, and 10 inches at Ord. Other amounts of note include 7 inches at Grand Island and Ravenna. The southern tail of this band swept across the rest of south central Nebraska, but its narrow character resulted in much lower snow accumulations. One to 5 inches of snow fell from near Interstate 80 to the Kansas state line, with the lowest amounts near the state line. ||Strong winds developed with widespread gusts of 45 to 58 mph east of Highway 183. The highest wind gusts were 58 mph at Hastings and 57 mph at Cairo. This resulted in blizzard or near-blizzard conditions in many areas, but especially along and north of Interstate 80, with near white-out conditions reported. Conditions were so bad that the Nebraska Department of Transportation pulled their plows off the roads in Buffalo and Hall counties for about 2 hours. Numerous roads and highways were closed or reported as impassible, including portions of Highways 11, 58, and 92. Northbound Highway 281 was closed in Grand Island just north of Stolley Park Rd because two semi trucks could not make it over the overpass. Nebraska State Patrol responded to numerous vehicle accidents and vehicles that became stuck. Dozens of vehicles remained stranded as conditions were too dangerous for tow truck operators. The Polk county sheriff reported a number of cars slid into ditches on Highway 81. Portions of Interstate 80 in York county were closed for a couple hours due to multiple accidents. Power lines were reported down in Phelps county, with isolated power outages also reported in and near Lexington and from Franklin county northeast to Hamilton and Merrick counties. Numerous schools, government offices, and businesses were closed Monday, as well as the regional airports in Grand Island and Kearney. The University of Nebraska at Kearney, Hastings College, and all Central Community Colleges at Lexington, Ord, Kearney, Hastings, and Grand Island were also closed. Snow emergencies were declared in Aurora, Cozad, Gibbon, Gothenburg, Grand Island, Kearney, Hastings, Holdrege, Minden, and St. Paul. Since most people stayed off the roads, crews were able to plow roads, and life was back to normal by Tuesday.||The snow storm was associated with low pressure that moved east across Kansas and deepened near Kansas City during the morning hours. This low then occluded over Iowa. This system formed as an upper-level trough over the western U.S. moved east and intensified over Colorado.

A winter storm produced heavy snowfall beginning in the early morning hours on January 21st continuing into the morning hours on January 22nd across western and north central Nebraska. Snowfall amounts ranged from 8 to 12 inches across much of the area. Northwest winds increased to 20 to 35 mph during the afternoon and evening on January 21st, and into the morning hours on January 22nd. This caused blizzard conditions in some areas with considerable blowing and drifting, and visibility as low as a quarter mile at times.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall amounts from 9 to 13 inches occurred across Lincoln County. Northwest winds of 20 to 35 mph, with gusts to 45 mph occurred during the evening hours on January 21st through the early morning hours on January 22nd. Considerable blowing and drifting and visibility of a quarter mile or less occurred.  Snow drifts of 2 to 5 feet were reported. Schools were closed Monday. A portion of highway 83 was closed near Wellfleet, as well as numerous county roads.

Northwest winds of 20 to 35 mph, with gusts to 45 mph occurred during the evening hours on January 21st through the early morning hours on January 22nd. Considerable blowing and drifting and visibility of a quarter mile or less occurred.  Snow drifts of 2 to 5 feet were reported. Schools were closed Monday. Some roads became closed. especially county roads.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On the 26th, a strengthening surface cyclone moved northeast across the Northern Plains. As it approached, strong south to southwest winds sustained from 30 to 40 mph with 40 to 50 mph gusts lashed most of the eastern half of Kansas. The winds were strong enough to knock down a utility pole in Allen County that morning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The emergency manager received reports from multiple citizens that a utility pole was blown down on the east side of Iola.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A bitter cold arctic air mass brought dangerous wind chills to portions of north central Nebraska during the overnight and morning hours on Sunday, December 31st, 2017 and continued to produce dangerous wind chills during the overnight and morning hours on Monday, January 1st, 2018. Lowest wind chills of 30 to 39 below were common.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dangerous wind chills of 30 to 35 below zero occurred across Keya Paha County during the overnight and morning hours on Monday, January 1st. The nearby Valentine ASOS recorded a lowest wind chill of 35 below at 352 am CST while the nearby Ainsworth AWOS recorded a lowest wind chill of 32 below at 515 am CST.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A bitter cold arctic air mass brought dangerous wind chills to portions of north central Nebraska during the overnight and morning hours on Sunday, December 31st, 2017 and continued to produce dangerous wind chills during the overnight and morning hours on Monday, January 1st, 2018. Lowest wind chills of 30 to 39 below were common.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dangerous wind chills of 30 to 39 below zero occurred across Rock County during the overnight and morning hours on Monday, January 1st. The nearby Ainsworth AWOS recorded a lowest wind chill of 32 below at 515 am CST while the nearby O'Neill AWOS recorded a lowest wind chill of 39 below at 800 am CST.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A bitter cold arctic air mass brought dangerous wind chills to portions of north central Nebraska during the overnight and morning hours on Sunday, December 31st, 2017 and continued to produce dangerous wind chills during the overnight and morning hours on Monday, January 1st, 2018. Lowest wind chills of 30 to 39 below were common.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dangerous wind chills of 30 to 39 below zero occurred across Boyd County during the overnight and morning hours on Monday, January 1st. The nearby O'Neill AWOS recorded a lowest wind chill of 39 below at 800 am CST.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the morning through mid afternoon freezing drizzle occurred over Northwest Kansas.  Ice accumulations ranged from a trace up to 0.38, with the highest ice accumulation reported in St. Francis.  Mid afternoon a band of moderate to heavy snow moved east into Kansas.  During the night the first band gradually ended as a second band of moderate to heavy snow developed and moved east.  Wind gusts were mostly in the 20-40 MPH range, but the strongest wind gust reported was 57 MPH at Goodland.  The combination of moderate to heavy snow along with strong winds caused zero to near zero visibility under each band of snow.  Highway 40 and 83 were closed in Logan County due to the hazardous driving conditions, stranding many motorists in Oakley.  Atleast one motorist was stranded on Highway 40.  The highest snowfall amount was 13 inches reported in northwest Sherman County.  Snowfall amounts declined to the east.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall across the county ranged from three to five inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the morning through mid afternoon freezing drizzle occurred over Northwest Kansas.  Ice accumulations ranged from a trace up to 0.38, with the highest ice accumulation reported in St. Francis.  Mid afternoon a band of moderate to heavy snow moved east into Kansas.  During the night the first band gradually ended as a second band of moderate to heavy snow developed and moved east.  Wind gusts were mostly in the 20-40 MPH range, but the strongest wind gust reported was 57 MPH at Goodland.  The combination of moderate to heavy snow along with strong winds caused zero to near zero visibility under each band of snow.  Highway 40 and 83 were closed in Logan County due to the hazardous driving conditions, stranding many motorists in Oakley.  Atleast one motorist was stranded on Highway 40.  The highest snowfall amount was 13 inches reported in northwest Sherman County.  Snowfall amounts declined to the east.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall across the county ranged from two to almost nine inches from southeast to northwest.  Wind gusts during the storm were below blizzard criteria.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A band of moderate to heavy snow moved east from Colorado.  Under the band of snow the visibility fell to zero.  During the night the first band gradually ended as a second band formed and continued east, also causing visibility to fall to near zero under it.  Snowfall amounts ranged from 9 to 13 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall across the county was around 10 inches.  Duration of the wind gusts during the storm were below blizzard criteria.  However blizzard like conditions were observed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A band of moderate to heavy snow moved east from Colorado.  Under the band of snow the visibility fell to zero.  During the night the first band gradually ended as a second band formed and continued east, also causing visibility to fall to near zero under it.  Snowfall amounts ranged from 9 to 13 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall across the county was exceeded 6 inches during this time frame.  Duration of the wind gusts during this time frame were below blizzard criteria.  However blizzard like conditions were observed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On July 19, a large complex of storms moved through NW and west central Missouri. The western edge of this storm complex produced some wind damage in far eastern Kansas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Six inch tree limbs were broken and shingles were blown off of roof.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On July 19, a large complex of storms moved through NW and west central Missouri. The western edge of this storm complex produced some wind damage in far eastern Kansas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree fell onto a powerline, causing a localized power outage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The anomalously dry period that plagued the region during the summer of 2018 continued into and through July. Most areas were about 2 inches short of normal precipitation for the month of July.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The abnormally dry summer continued into and through July for Atchison County. The Drought Monitor put the county in D2 and maintained it into August. As of yet, the breadth and magnitude of the impacts are unknown.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The anomalously dry period that plagued the region during the summer of 2018 continued into and through July. Most areas were about 2 inches short of normal precipitation for the month of July.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The abnormally dry summer continued into and through July for Doniphan County. The Drought Monitor put the county in D2 and maintained it into August. As of yet, the breadth and magnitude of the impacts are unknown.

These bands rotated cyclonically, expanded and eventually merged with the larger snow band to the west which finally began moving east after midnight. By daybreak Monday, one large snow band extended from south central Nebraska into southern Minnesota. Over central Nebraska, the snow was heaviest and most persistent along and north of Highway 92, from 3 am to 9 am CST. At least 10 inches of snow fell over most of that area. The highest amounts were 14 inches at Belgrade and St. Paul. Greeley measured 12 inches, with 11 inches at Genoa, Osceola, and Shelby, and 10 inches at Ord. Other amounts of note include 7 inches at Grand Island and Ravenna. The southern tail of this band swept across the rest of south central Nebraska, but its narrow character resulted in much lower snow accumulations. One to 5 inches of snow fell from near Interstate 80 to the Kansas state line, with the lowest amounts near the state line. ||Strong winds developed with widespread gusts of 45 to 58 mph east of Highway 183. The highest wind gusts were 58 mph at Hastings and 57 mph at Cairo. This resulted in blizzard or near-blizzard conditions in many areas, but especially along and north of Interstate 80, with near white-out conditions reported. Conditions were so bad that the Nebraska Department of Transportation pulled their plows off the roads in Buffalo and Hall counties for about 2 hours. Numerous roads and highways were closed or reported as impassible, including portions of Highways 11, 58, and 92. Northbound Highway 281 was closed in Grand Island just north of Stolley Park Rd because two semi trucks could not make it over the overpass. Nebraska State Patrol responded to numerous vehicle accidents and vehicles that became stuck. Dozens of vehicles remained stranded as conditions were too dangerous for tow truck operators. The Polk county sheriff reported a number of cars slid into ditches on Highway 81. Portions of Interstate 80 in York county were closed for a couple hours due to multiple accidents. Power lines were reported down in Phelps county, with isolated power outages also reported in and near Lexington and from Franklin county northeast to Hamilton and Merrick counties. Numerous schools, government offices, and businesses were closed Monday, as well as the regional airports in Grand Island and Kearney. The University of Nebraska at Kearney, Hastings College, and all Central Community Colleges at Lexington, Ord, Kearney, Hastings, and Grand Island were also closed. Snow emergencies were declared in Aurora, Cozad, Gibbon, Gothenburg, Grand Island, Kearney, Hastings, Holdrege, Minden, and St. Paul. Since most people stayed off the roads, crews were able to plow roads, and life was back to normal by Tuesday.||The snow storm was associated with low pressure that moved east across Kansas and deepened near Kansas City during the morning hours. This low then occluded over Iowa. This system formed as an upper-level trough over the western U.S. moved east and intensified over Colorado.

A strong upper-deck wave pushed a strong cold front across Kansas throughout the night and early morning of the 19th and 20th. The result was that widespread sleet and freezing rain occurred across all of the WFO Wichita County Warning Area with most of the adverse winter weather occurring on the 20th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter measured 0.20 inch of sleet.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A shallow cold front pushed south into southeast Kansas during the early morning hours of February 10th, 2018.  As the front pushed south, low level moisture saturation increased enough for light freezing drizzle to develop as temperatures fell below freezing.   The light freezing drizzle led to very slick roadways across most of the Flint Hills and southeast Kansas during the morning hours and again in the evening hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Light freezing drizzle was reported in Iola, Kansas.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A shallow cold front pushed south into southeast Kansas during the early morning hours of February 10th, 2018.  As the front pushed south, low level moisture saturation increased enough for light freezing drizzle to develop as temperatures fell below freezing.   The light freezing drizzle led to very slick roadways across most of the Flint Hills and southeast Kansas during the morning hours and again in the evening hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Light freezing drizzle was reported across the entire county, causing very slick roadways.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hail and wind events were noted with storms as they moved across central and southeast Kansas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A large tree fell onto a mobile home in the center part of town.  In addition, a semi-truck was blown into the guardrail of a bridge on Interstate 135.  Report relayed via KSAL.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hail and wind events were noted with storms as they moved across central and southeast Kansas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Tree limbs were blown down in Iola.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hail and wind events were noted with storms as they moved across central and southeast Kansas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A few tree limbs were blown down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hail and wind events were noted with storms as they moved across central and southeast Kansas.
Hail and wind events were noted with storms as they moved across central and southeast Kansas.
An isolated severe thunderstorm hit Mt. Hope, located in the northwest corner of Sedgwick County, with golf ball-sized hail. The thunderstorm struck shortly after mid-night on the 21st.

A shallow cold front pushed south into southeast Kansas during the early morning hours of February 10th, 2018.  As the front pushed south, low level moisture saturation increased enough for light freezing drizzle to develop as temperatures fell below freezing.   The light freezing drizzle led to very slick roadways across most of the Flint Hills and southeast Kansas during the morning hours and again in the evening hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A mixture of freezing rain and freezing drizzle made roadways very slick in Coffeyville, Kansas and across the entire county.  The Coffeyville ASOS reported ice accumulation of 0.06 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very little rainfall fell during the winter months with very little snowfall as well.  This led to severe drought conditions creeping into portions of south central Kansas during the month of February 2018. The severe drought conditions worsened during the month, spreading north of Highway 50 and east to the Kansas Turnpike.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Severe drought conditions worsened during the month of February, 2018.  By the end of the month most of the county had climbed into the extreme drought category.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the night heavy snowfall developed over Cheyenne County in Northwest Kansas, lasting into the morning.  Snowfall rates of more than an inch an hour occurred.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Up to seven inches of snowfall was reported in the county, with the highest amount being reported in Bird City.  Six inches of snow was reported in St. Francis.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The anomalously dry period that plagued the region during the summer of 2018 continued into and through July. Most areas were about 2 inches short of normal precipitation for the month of July.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The abnormally dry summer continued into and through July for Wyandotte County. The Drought Monitor put the county in D3 and maintained it into August. As of yet, the breadth and magnitude of the impacts are unknown.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A few isolated storms occurred on the 17th with very few reports.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water was reported over highway 14 and was not causing a major issue.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A few isolated storms occurred on the 17th with very few reports.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High water was reported at 14th and Chisholm roads.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A few isolated storms occurred on the 17th with very few reports.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A few reports of power lines being blown down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A few isolated storms occurred on the 17th with very few reports.
One lone event occurred in far southeast Kansas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three telephone poles were blown down along highway 160 and Gray road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An isolated severe thunderstorm that developed in far Southeast Kansas late in the afternoon caused wind damage in and around Coffeyville. Two power poles were blown down, one in town while the 2nd just south of town.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A delayed report was received of 2 power poles that were blown down in and around Coffeyville. The 1st was in town while the 2nd was just south of town. The time of the event is estimated based on radar.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Although not a major storm by any means, this Sunday morning featured a quick-hitting burst of fluffy, wind-driven snow that roughly doubled accumulation expectations across much of South Central Nebraska, with several spots receiving 2-4 (and locally higher). The vast majority of 2+ amounts focused southwest of a line from Loup City-Grand Island-Clay Center-Hebron. According to reports from NeRAIN/CoCoRaHS and official NWS cooperative observers, some of the highest totals featured: 5 at Red Cloud, 4 at Hubbell, 3.9 at Hebron and also four miles southwest of Blue Hill, and 3.8 eight miles south of Elwood. In the Nebraska Tri Cities, totals included: 1.7 at Grand Island airport, 2.6 at Hastings NWS and 2.9 at Kearney airport. Although even the higher-end totals were relatively modest, this event packed somewhat of a punch given sustained north winds generally 20-25 MPH/gusts 30+ MPH, resulting in some drifting and at least brief visibility reductions to one-half mile or less. ||As for timing, the vast majority of accumulating snow fell between 3-10 AM, gradually ending from north-to-south as forcing departed southward into Kansas. Speaking of forcing, this event was driven by a classic case of pronounced mid-level frontogenesis, trailing well-behind a strong surface cold front that passed through during the preceding 24 hours. On the larger scale, a broad shortwave trough tracked southeast from the Northern Rockies/Dakotas into the Midwest over the course of Feb. 4th. Locally, this snow event was accompanied by a very cold airmass featuring surface temperatures only in the single digits above zero F, and wind chill values ranging from -10 to -20 F.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The cooperative observer in Miller reported 3.1 inches of total snowfall. Also, an official snowfall total of 2.9 inches was measured at the Kearney Regional Airport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Between the afternoon of Friday the 9th and the evening of Saturday the 10th, two completely separate rounds of Advisory-worthy snow affected parts of the 24-county South Central Nebraska area, making for an active couple days of winter weather despite only modest impacts. Interestingly, the two snow events overlapped minimally in area, with the first round focused mainly within northern and central counties, and the second one across the south. This event summary discusses round 1, which occurred between the afternoon of the 9th and the pre-dawn hours of the 10th:||This first round of snow primarily affected areas north of Highway 6, and especially counties along and north of Interstate 80, which reported a fairly widespread coverage of 2-4 and isolated higher amounts to around 5. According to reports from NeRAIN/CoCoRaHS and official NWS cooperative observers, some of the highest totals featured: 5 northwest of Greeley, 4.7 west of Arcadia, 4.2 at Grand Island airport and 3.6 at Ravenna. Other official Tri Cities totals included 2.3 at Kearney and only 1.7 at the Hastings NWS office. Although not overly-strong, sustained north winds averaged 10-20 MPH with some higher gusts, causing at least minor blowing and drifting of the fluffy snow. Timing-wise, while some northern counties received minor accumulation early in the afternoon of the 9th, the primary west-east oriented snow band got going in the north between 4-6 PM before gradually slipping southward across the Interstate 80 corridor through the evening. Between midnight and 2 AM on the 10th, this snow band weakened and shifted east of the local area, signaling the end of round 1. Aloft, a large-scale, broad trough was in place over much of the United States with a series of jet streaks passing directly over Nebraska. This setup yielded a concentrated swath of mid-level frontogenesis, which in turn promoted the rather narrow, west-east oriented snow band that dropped the majority of accumulation. At the surface, the fluffy nature of the flakes was supported by a very cold airmass with temperatures only in the single digits above zero F. The breezy north winds resulted from steady pressure rises emanating southward across the Central Plains from high pressure in Montana and the Dakotas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A snowfall total of 2.7 inches occurred in St. Paul.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level weather system moved across eastern Nebraska and produced a fairly narrow band of moderate snowfall on February of 1 to 5 inches of snow from Saline and Seward Counties in Nebraska to Harrison County and Pottawattamie Counties in Iowa.  The heaviest amounts included 2.7 inches at 68th and Dodge in Omaha, 3 inches west of Oakland, 4 inches at Scribner, NE , and 5 inches southwest of Dunlap, IA.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was 2.7 inches of snow reported at 62nd Street and Dodge in Omaha.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A measurement of 1.1 inches of snow occurred at Western.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A band of moderate to heavy snowfall slowly moved south across Dundy County during the day. Snowfall reports ranged from four to nine inches, with the highest amount reported north of Parks.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall amounts ranged from four to nine inches, with the higher amounts of snow occurring in the central part of the county extending from east to west.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A disturbance rotating around a large Canadian upper vortex brought a period of enhanced frontogenetic forcing through the Missouri River valley and eastward across northwest Iowa and far southern Minnesota. Snowfall averaged from 2 to 5 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Light to moderate snow over a period of several hours brought from 2 to 5 inches of snowfall across northeast Nebraska. Higher amounts were measured at Concord (3.9 inches) and Emerson (3.0 inches).

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A disturbance rotating around a large Canadian upper vortex brought a period of enhanced frontogenetic forcing through the Missouri River valley and eastward across northwest Iowa and far southern Minnesota. Snowfall averaged from 2 to 5 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Light to moderate snow over a period of several hours brought from 2 to 5 inches of snowfall across northeast Nebraska. Higher amounts were measured at Concord (3.9 inches) and Emerson (3.0 inches).

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: For the second time in three days, South Central Nebraska saw a modest-but-noticeable round of snow on this Tuesday, as most of the 24-county area received 1-3, and localized totals to 4. Unlike the event two days prior on the 4th, winds were not much of a factor, with southeasterly speeds only averaging around 10 MPH. According to reports from NeRAIN/CoCoRaHS and official NWS cooperative observers, some of the highest totals featured: 4 at Geneva and four miles east of Ohiowa, 3.9 at Ravenna, 3.7 eight miles south of Elwood and 3.6 two miles northwest of Rockville. In the Nebraska Tri Cities, official totals included 3 at both Kearney and Grand Island airports and 2 at the Hastings NWS office. ||This event was squarely centered on the daytime hours, as snow first broke out in far southwestern counties (such as Furnas) shortly before sunrise and gradually expanded northeastward, affecting the majority of South Central Nebraska by mid-late morning. As the afternoon and early evening wore on, snow slowly ended from west-to-east, with the final steady band exiting Fillmore/Thayer counties between 7-8 PM. In the mid-upper levels, the primary instigator was a shortwave trough migrating east out of Colorado across Kansas and far southern Nebraska. At the surface, this was another very cold snow with daytime highs only topping out around 10 F, and the light winds promoted by strong Arctic high pressure (roughly 1033 millibars) centered over Iowa.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A snowfall total of 3.7 inches occurred 8 miles south of Elwood.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Widespread high winds occurred on this Monday and Tuesday. Between midnight and 6 AM CST Monday, an occluded front swept across south central Nebraska. During the day Monday, several lows consolidated into a primary low along the South Dakota-Minnesota border. This low became nearly stationary as the fronts continued to progress far to the east and south. Monday night this low performed a loop and moved southeast into Iowa. During the day Tuesday, this low rapidly filled and became absorbed into a low over the Great Lakes. Two periods of strong winds occurred. The first occurred from midday through the afternoon hours Monday due to diurnal mixing. Widespread wind gusts of 50 to 61 mph occurred mainly along and west of Highway 281. There were a couple mesonet sites that measured 64 mph near Kearney and 69 mph near Norman, although these stations may not necessarily be sited properly. From the official stations, the highest winds were measured at Lexington where winds were sustained at or above 40 mph for five hours with a peak gust of 61 mph. The high winds combined with dry fuels and relative humidity levels as low as 23% to create favorable conditions for the wildfire that occurred near Wilsonville. There was a lull over much of the area during the evening, then winds increased again. The second period of high winds occurred between midnight and 9 AM CST on Tuesday. These winds were associated with a tightening of the pressure gradient as the low performed its loop. This also induced steepening lapse rates associated with an increase in cold air advection. Widespread wind gusts between 50 and 68 mph occurred. The highest wind gusts from official stations included 66 mph at the airport in Hastings and 65 mph at the Central Nebraska Regional Airport in Grand Island. The highest unofficial gust was 68 mph near Norman.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a wildfire near Wilsonville in Furnas County during the mid-late afternoon hours, located near the intersection of Highway 89 and Road 414, north of Ag Valley COOP. Emergency manager said this was started by with the wind and a rekindled burn permit from a few weeks ago, and burned approximately 350 acres. Fire departments from Wilsonville, Cambridge, Bartley, Beaver Valley (Lebanon/Danbury), HEA (Holbrook/Arapahoe/Edison), Beaver City and Norton County, KS were on the scene. Ambulances from Cambridge and Beaver City were present for rehab. Extreme Ag (Cambridge), Ag Valley COOP and Kasson Farms provided extra trucks to haul water. There were also 5-6 tractors with discs/dozer blades to provide assistance. This fire burned grassland, no structures were lost.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Widespread high winds occurred on this Monday and Tuesday. Between midnight and 6 AM CST Monday, a triple point low and associated fronts swept across north central Kansas. During the day Monday, several lows consolidated into a primary low along the South Dakota-Minnesota border. This low became nearly stationary as the fronts continued to progress far to the east and south. Monday night this low performed a loop and moved southeast into Iowa. During the day Tuesday, this low rapidly filled and became absorbed into a low over the Great Lakes. Strong winds occurred from the late morning into the afternoon hours Monday and Tuesday due to diurnal mixing. Widespread wind gusts of 50 to 60 mph occurred on both days with the highest wind gust occurring at Logan. The high winds combined with dry fuels and relative humidity levels as low as 23% to create favorable conditions for the wildfire that occurred near Kensington.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a wildfire approximately 7 miles northeast of Kensington in Smith County during the mid-late afternoon hours, located near the intersection of F Road and 100 Road. This fire burned between 2500-3000 acres, and did burn some abandoned structures. There were 5 fire departments on the scene. While the fire was under control late in the afternoon, a few firefighters lingered into the evening hours to keep an eye on the situation.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level weather system moved across eastern Nebraska and produced a fairly narrow band of moderate snowfall on February of 1 to 5 inches of snow from Saline and Seward Counties in Nebraska to Harrison County and Pottawattamie Counties in Iowa.  The heaviest amounts included 2.7 inches at 68th and Dodge in Omaha, 3 inches west of Oakland, 4 inches at Scribner, NE , and 5 inches southwest of Dunlap, IA.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a report of 2 inches of snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level system moved across a moderately unstable atmosphere and produced widespread snow across much of the area.  The heaviest amounts were north of highway 50 and along and west of highway 283.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall of 2 to 4 inches was common across the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Although not a major storm by any means, this Sunday morning featured a quick-hitting burst of fluffy, wind-driven snow that roughly doubled accumulation expectations across portions of North Central Kansas, especially within Jewell and Smith counties where 2-4 was common.  According to reports from official NWS cooperative observers, some of the highest totals in the local six-county area featured: 4.0 at Burr Oak, 3.0 at Jewell and Lebanon, and 2.6 at Smith Center. Although even these totals were relatively modest by Central Plains standards, this event packed somewhat of a punch given sustained north winds generally 20-25 MPH/gusts 30+ MPH, resulting in some drifting and at least brief visibility reductions to one-half mile or less. ||As for timing, the vast majority of accumulating snow fell between 5AM-Noon, gradually ending from north-to-south. Forcing-wise, this event was driven by a classic case of pronounced mid-level frontogenesis, trailing well-behind a strong surface cold front that passed through during the preceding 24 hours. On the larger scale, a broad shortwave trough tracked southeast from the Northern Rockies/Dakotas into the Midwest over the course of Feb. 4th. Locally, this snow event was accompanied by a very cold airmass featuring surface temperatures mainly in the single digits to around 10 degrees F, and wind chill values ranging from -5 to -15 F.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A snowfall total 4.0 inches was measured in Burr Oak, and also 3.0 inches fell in Jewell.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Although not a major storm by any means, this Sunday morning featured a quick-hitting burst of fluffy, wind-driven snow that roughly doubled accumulation expectations across much of South Central Nebraska, with several spots receiving 2-4 (and locally higher). The vast majority of 2+ amounts focused southwest of a line from Loup City-Grand Island-Clay Center-Hebron. According to reports from NeRAIN/CoCoRaHS and official NWS cooperative observers, some of the highest totals featured: 5 at Red Cloud, 4 at Hubbell, 3.9 at Hebron and also four miles southwest of Blue Hill, and 3.8 eight miles south of Elwood. In the Nebraska Tri Cities, totals included: 1.7 at Grand Island airport, 2.6 at Hastings NWS and 2.9 at Kearney airport. Although even the higher-end totals were relatively modest, this event packed somewhat of a punch given sustained north winds generally 20-25 MPH/gusts 30+ MPH, resulting in some drifting and at least brief visibility reductions to one-half mile or less. ||As for timing, the vast majority of accumulating snow fell between 3-10 AM, gradually ending from north-to-south as forcing departed southward into Kansas. Speaking of forcing, this event was driven by a classic case of pronounced mid-level frontogenesis, trailing well-behind a strong surface cold front that passed through during the preceding 24 hours. On the larger scale, a broad shortwave trough tracked southeast from the Northern Rockies/Dakotas into the Midwest over the course of Feb. 4th. Locally, this snow event was accompanied by a very cold airmass featuring surface temperatures only in the single digits above zero F, and wind chill values ranging from -10 to -20 F.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A snowfall total of 2.7 inches occurred at Cozad.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Between the afternoon of Friday the 9th and the evening of Saturday the 10th, two completely separate rounds of Advisory-worthy snow affected parts of the 24-county South Central Nebraska area, making for an active couple days of winter weather despite only modest impacts. Interestingly, the two snow events overlapped minimally in area, with the first round focused mainly within northern and central counties, and the second one across the south. This event summary discusses round 1, which occurred between the afternoon of the 9th and the pre-dawn hours of the 10th:||This first round of snow primarily affected areas north of Highway 6, and especially counties along and north of Interstate 80, which reported a fairly widespread coverage of 2-4 and isolated higher amounts to around 5. According to reports from NeRAIN/CoCoRaHS and official NWS cooperative observers, some of the highest totals featured: 5 northwest of Greeley, 4.7 west of Arcadia, 4.2 at Grand Island airport and 3.6 at Ravenna. Other official Tri Cities totals included 2.3 at Kearney and only 1.7 at the Hastings NWS office. Although not overly-strong, sustained north winds averaged 10-20 MPH with some higher gusts, causing at least minor blowing and drifting of the fluffy snow. Timing-wise, while some northern counties received minor accumulation early in the afternoon of the 9th, the primary west-east oriented snow band got going in the north between 4-6 PM before gradually slipping southward across the Interstate 80 corridor through the evening. Between midnight and 2 AM on the 10th, this snow band weakened and shifted east of the local area, signaling the end of round 1. Aloft, a large-scale, broad trough was in place over much of the United States with a series of jet streaks passing directly over Nebraska. This setup yielded a concentrated swath of mid-level frontogenesis, which in turn promoted the rather narrow, west-east oriented snow band that dropped the majority of accumulation. At the surface, the fluffy nature of the flakes was supported by a very cold airmass with temperatures only in the single digits above zero F. The breezy north winds resulted from steady pressure rises emanating southward across the Central Plains from high pressure in Montana and the Dakotas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A snowfall total of 3.5 inches occurred 2 miles southwest of Genoa, and a total of 2.0 inches fell in Belgrade.
