Speaking of forcing, this event was driven by a classic case of pronounced mid-level frontogenesis, trailing well-behind a strong surface cold front that passed through during the preceding 24 hours. On the larger scale, a broad shortwave trough tracked southeast from the Northern Rockies/Dakotas into the Midwest over the course of Feb. 4th. Locally, this snow event was accompanied by a very cold airmass featuring surface temperatures only in the single digits above zero F, and wind chill values ranging from -10 to -20 F.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A snowfall total of 3.0 inches occurred in Clay Center.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The first severe thunderstorms of the season occurred over Phillips and Smith counties on this Friday evening. A large area of showers evolved over southwest Nebraska. Around 6 PM CST, a thunderstorm formed at the southern edge of these showers along the Nebraska-Kansas state line, south of McCook. Over the next two hours, a small cyclonic-shaped arc of thunderstorms formed straddling the state line. The southernmost part of this arc moved east across Phillips and Smith counties between 7 and 9 PM CST. Severe hail occurred along most of the storms path from Logan to just south of Phillipsburg to Smith Center and Lebanon. Most of the hail reported was around 1 inch in diameter, but hail the size of ping pong balls was reported in Smith Center and golf ball size hail was reported near Glade. This storm produced lots of hail. One observer reported the ground was nearly covered in Smith Center. Severe winds also occurred over parts of Phillips county where winds were measured as high as 66 mph in Logan.||Cyclogenesis was occurring over eastern Colorado during the morning hours. As the low moved into western Kansas in the afternoon, a front that had been stationary from northwest to southeast across Kansas began moving north. By the time the storms formed, the front had moved to the Nebraska-Kansas border. These storms developed at the apex of the warm sector, near surface low, where temperatures were in the upper 70s and dewpoints were near 50. The cyclonic arc shape was to due the storms forming within a ribbon of mid-level frontogenesis. An elevated mixed layer had overspread the area, but the meager surface dewpoints resulted in weak instability with surface-based CAPE near 1000 J/kg. Deep layer shear was around 60 kt.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail ranging in size from pennies to golf balls was reported along this path.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large area of low pressure that covered the Southern Plains interacted with Canadian High Pressure to cause widespread light freezing rain and freezing drizzle that was occasionally mixed with sleet. Although most areas only received a light glazing, there were exceptions. Nearly 1/4 inch of glaze was reported in Marion (0.20 inch) while Newton received 1 inch of sleet.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Country roads and side streets were covered but main roads primarily were wet with slushy spots.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level system moved across a moderately unstable atmosphere and produced widespread snow across much of the area.  The heaviest amounts were north of highway 50 and along and west of highway 283.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall of around 1 inch was reported across the county with the exception of the far southwest part of the county which had amounts up to 3.5 inches.

As the afternoon and early evening wore on, snow slowly ended from west-to-east, with the final steady band exiting Fillmore/Thayer counties between 7-8 PM. In the mid-upper levels, the primary instigator was a shortwave trough migrating east out of Colorado across Kansas and far southern Nebraska. At the surface, this was another very cold snow with daytime highs only topping out around 10 F, and the light winds promoted by strong Arctic high pressure (roughly 1033 millibars) centered over Iowa.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A snowfall total of 3.0 inches occurred in Clay Center, and 6 miles east southeast of Clay Center.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: For the second time in three days, South Central Nebraska saw a modest-but-noticeable round of snow on this Tuesday, as most of the 24-county area received 1-3, and localized totals to 4. Unlike the event two days prior on the 4th, winds were not much of a factor, with southeasterly speeds only averaging around 10 MPH. According to reports from NeRAIN/CoCoRaHS and official NWS cooperative observers, some of the highest totals featured: 4 at Geneva and four miles east of Ohiowa, 3.9 at Ravenna, 3.7 eight miles south of Elwood and 3.6 two miles northwest of Rockville. In the Nebraska Tri Cities, official totals included 3 at both Kearney and Grand Island airports and 2 at the Hastings NWS office. ||This event was squarely centered on the daytime hours, as snow first broke out in far southwestern counties (such as Furnas) shortly before sunrise and gradually expanded northeastward, affecting the majority of South Central Nebraska by mid-late morning. EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall totals included: 4.0 inches in Geneva and also four miles east of Ohiowa, and 3.0 inches three miles south of Shickley.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall totals of 3.2 inches occurred in Osceola, and also 3 miles northeast of Shelby.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Between the afternoon of Friday the 9th and the evening of Saturday the 10th, two completely separate rounds of Advisory-worthy snow affected parts of the 24-county South Central Nebraska area, making for an active couple days of winter weather despite only modest impacts. Interestingly, the two snow events overlapped minimally in area, with the first round focused mainly within northern and central counties, and the second one across the south. This event summary discusses round 1, which occurred between the afternoon of the 9th and the pre-dawn hours of the 10th:||This first round of snow primarily affected areas north of Highway 6, and especially counties along and north of Interstate 80, which reported a fairly widespread coverage of 2-4 and isolated higher amounts to around 5. According to reports from NeRAIN/CoCoRaHS and official NWS cooperative observers, some of the highest totals featured: 5 northwest of Greeley, 4.7 west of Arcadia, 4.2 at Grand Island airport and 3.6 at Ravenna. Other official Tri Cities totals included 2.3 at Kearney and only 1.7 at the Hastings NWS office. Although not overly-strong, sustained north winds averaged 10-20 MPH with some higher gusts, causing at least minor blowing and drifting of the fluffy snow. Timing-wise, while some northern counties received minor accumulation early in the afternoon of the 9th, the primary west-east oriented snow band got going in the north between 4-6 PM before gradually slipping southward across the Interstate 80 corridor through the evening. Between midnight and 2 AM on the 10th, this snow band weakened and shifted east of the local area, signaling the end of round 1. Aloft, a large-scale, broad trough was in place over much of the United States with a series of jet streaks passing directly over Nebraska. This setup yielded a concentrated swath of mid-level frontogenesis, which in turn promoted the rather narrow, west-east oriented snow band that dropped the majority of accumulation. At the surface, the fluffy nature of the flakes was supported by a very cold airmass with temperatures only in the single digits above zero F. The breezy north winds resulted from steady pressure rises emanating southward across the Central Plains from high pressure in Montana and the Dakotas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A snowfall total of 3.5 inches was reported from CoCoRaHS 3 miles north northeast of Johnson Lake. And also, a public report of 3.0 inches in Gothenburg was reported via Facebook.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Between the afternoon of Friday the 9th and the evening of Saturday the 10th, two completely separate rounds of Advisory-worthy snow affected parts of the 24-county South Central Nebraska area, making for an active couple days of winter weather despite only modest impacts. Interestingly, the two snow events overlapped minimally in area, with the first round focused mainly within northern and central counties, and the second one across the south. This event summary discusses round 2, which occurred on the afternoon and evening of the 10th:||This second round of snow primarily affected areas south of Highway 6, but especially far southern counties along the Kansas border, where 1-3��� was common with isolated slightly higher amounts. According to reports from official NWS cooperative observers, some of the highest totals featured: 3.6��� in Hebron, 3.5��� at Wilsonville, 3��� at Hubbell and 2.5��� in Superior. Unlike the event that targeted locations farther north only 12-24 hours earlier, winds were not much of an issue, only averaging around 10 MPH from the north. As for timing, most of the affected area saw the majority of snow between 1-9 PM. However, it started accumulating as early as late-morning in the Furnas County area, while the last flakes lingered to around midnight in and near Thayer County. Aloft, a large-scale, broad trough was translating through the central United States with a series of jet streaks passing directly over Nebraska. Like ���round 1��� during the preceding 24 hours, this setup yielded another concentrated swath of mid-level frontogenesis, which in turn promoted a fairly narrow, west-east oriented snow band that dropped the majority of accumulation. At the surface, the fluffy nature of the flakes was supported by a very cold airmass with temperatures only averaging 5-10 F. The light winds were fostered by a roughly 1026 millibar high pressure center in northeast Nebraska.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A snowfall total of 3.5 inches fell in Wilsonville.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Between the afternoon of Friday the 9th and the evening of Saturday the 10th, two completely separate rounds of Advisory-worthy snow affected parts of the 24-county South Central Nebraska area, making for an active couple days of winter weather despite only modest impacts. Other official Tri Cities totals included 2.3 at Kearney and only 1.7 at the Hastings NWS office. Although not overly-strong, sustained north winds averaged 10-20 MPH with some higher gusts, causing at least minor blowing and drifting of the fluffy snow. Timing-wise, while some northern counties received minor accumulation early in the afternoon of the 9th, the primary west-east oriented snow band got going in the north between 4-6 PM before gradually slipping southward across the Interstate 80 corridor through the evening. Between midnight and 2 AM on the 10th, this snow band weakened and shifted east of the local area, signaling the end of round 1. Aloft, a large-scale, broad trough was in place over much of the United States with a series of jet streaks passing directly over Nebraska. This setup yielded a concentrated swath of mid-level frontogenesis, which in turn promoted the rather narrow, west-east oriented snow band that dropped the majority of accumulation. At the surface, the fluffy nature of the flakes was supported by a very cold airmass with temperatures only in the single digits above zero F. The breezy north winds resulted from steady pressure rises emanating southward across the Central Plains from high pressure in Montana and the Dakotas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A snowfall total of 3.6 inches fell in Ravenna and 2.3 inches fell in Kearney. Also, a public report was received of 4.0 inches falling 4 miles west northwest of Ravenna.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large area of low pressure that covered the Southern Plains interacted with Canadian High Pressure to cause widespread light freezing rain and freezing drizzle that was occasionally mixed with sleet. Although most areas only received a light glazing, there were exceptions. Nearly 1/4 inch of glaze was reported in Marion (0.20 inch) while Newton received 1 inch of sleet.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Around 1/8 inch of ice accumulated in Wellington overnight.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Around 0.20 inch of ice had accumulated from freezing rain and sleet. Country roads were ice-covered county-wide.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Although not a major storm by any means, this Sunday morning featured a quick-hitting burst of fluffy, wind-driven snow that roughly doubled accumulation expectations across much of South Central Nebraska, with several spots receiving 2-4 (and locally higher). The vast majority of 2+ amounts focused southwest of a line from Loup City-Grand Island-Clay Center-Hebron. According to reports from NeRAIN/CoCoRaHS and official NWS cooperative observers, some of the highest totals featured: 5 at Red Cloud, 4 at Hubbell, 3.9 at Hebron and also four miles southwest of Blue Hill, and 3.8 eight miles south of Elwood. In the Nebraska Tri Cities, totals included: 1.7 at Grand Island airport, 2.6 at Hastings NWS and 2.9 at Kearney airport. Although even the higher-end totals were relatively modest, this event packed somewhat of a punch given sustained north winds generally 20-25 MPH/gusts 30+ MPH, resulting in some drifting and at least brief visibility reductions to one-half mile or less. ||As for timing, the vast majority of accumulating snow fell between 3-10 AM, gradually ending from north-to-south as forcing departed southward into Kansas. Speaking of forcing, this event was driven by a classic case of pronounced mid-level frontogenesis, trailing well-behind a strong surface cold front that passed through during the preceding 24 hours. On the larger scale, a broad shortwave trough tracked southeast from the Northern Rockies/Dakotas into the Midwest over the course of Feb. 4th. Locally, this snow event was accompanied by a very cold airmass featuring surface temperatures only in the single digits above zero F, and wind chill values ranging from -10 to -20 F.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A snowfall total of 3.0 inches occurred at Harlan Lake.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper-deck wave pushed a strong cold front across Kansas throughout the night and early morning of the 19th and 20th. The result was that widespread sleet and freezing rain occurred across all of the WFO Wichita County Warning Area with most of the adverse winter weather occurring on the 20th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Freezing rain produced close to 1/4 inch of glaze across Sedgwick County. The freezing rain was occasionally mixed with sleet, which accumulated to 0.40 inch in Goddard.

This setup yielded a concentrated swath of mid-level frontogenesis, which in turn promoted the rather narrow, west-east oriented snow band that dropped the majority of accumulation. At the surface, the fluffy nature of the flakes was supported by a very cold airmass with temperatures only in the single digits above zero F. The breezy north winds resulted from steady pressure rises emanating southward across the Central Plains from high pressure in Montana and the Dakotas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A snowfall total of 2.8 inches occurred in Greeley. Also, a CoCoRaHS report of 5.0 inches occurred 6 miles west northwest of Greeley.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Between the afternoon of Friday the 9th and the evening of Saturday the 10th, two completely separate rounds of Advisory-worthy snow affected parts of the 24-county South Central Nebraska area, making for an active couple days of winter weather despite only modest impacts. Interestingly, the two snow events overlapped minimally in area, with the first round focused mainly within northern and central counties, and the second one across the south. This event summary discusses round 2, which occurred on the afternoon and evening of the 10th:||This second round of snow primarily affected areas south of Highway 6, but especially far southern counties along the Kansas border, where 1-3��� was common with isolated slightly higher amounts. According to reports from official NWS cooperative observers, some of the highest totals featured: 3.6��� in Hebron, 3.5��� at Wilsonville, 3��� at Hubbell and 2.5��� in Superior. Unlike the event that targeted locations farther north only 12-24 hours earlier, winds were not much of an issue, only averaging around 10 MPH from the north. As for timing, most of the affected area saw the majority of snow between 1-9 PM. However, it started accumulating as early as late-morning in the Furnas County area, while the last flakes lingered to around midnight in and near Thayer County. Aloft, a large-scale, broad trough was translating through the central United States with a series of jet streaks passing directly over Nebraska. Like ���round 1��� during the preceding 24 hours, this setup yielded another concentrated swath of mid-level frontogenesis, which in turn promoted a fairly narrow, west-east oriented snow band that dropped the majority of accumulation. At the surface, the fluffy nature of the flakes was supported by a very cold airmass with temperatures only averaging 5-10 F. The light winds were fostered by a roughly 1026 millibar high pressure center in northeast Nebraska.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A snowfall total of 1.2 inches occurred 4 miles southwest of Blue Hill and 1.0 inches fell in Red Cloud.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On July 19, a large complex of storms moved through NW and west central Missouri. The western edge of this storm complex produced some wind damage in far eastern Kansas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong winds from a nearby thunderstorm produced some powerline damage at 214th and Linwood Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper-deck wave pushed a strong cold front across Kansas throughout the night and early morning of the 19th and 20th. The result was that widespread sleet and freezing rain occurred across all of the WFO Wichita County Warning Area with most of the adverse winter weather occurring on the 20th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Around 0.25 inch of sleet was reported 3 miles east northeast of Cleveland.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A shallow cold front pushed south into southeast Kansas during the early morning hours of February 10th, 2018.  As the front pushed south, low level moisture saturation increased enough for light freezing drizzle to develop as temperatures fell below freezing.   The light freezing drizzle led to very slick roadways across most of the Flint Hills and southeast Kansas during the morning hours and again in the evening hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Light freezing drizzle led to slick roadways in Oswego, Kansas.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A shallow cold front pushed south into southeast Kansas during the early morning hours of February 10th, 2018.  As the front pushed south, low level moisture saturation increased enough for light freezing drizzle to develop as temperatures fell below freezing.   The light freezing drizzle led to very slick roadways across most of the Flint Hills and southeast Kansas during the morning hours and again in the evening hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Light freezing drizzle was reported in Coffeyville, Kansas.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another in a series of Alberta clipper systems moving across the plains left behind a swath of light to moderate snow accumulations across northeast Nebraska. Much of the area received from 3 to 5 inches snowfall, while wind chills dropped below zero by the end of the time of snowfall.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility dropped to less than a mile at times, producing hazardous travel conditions with snowfall totaling as much as 4.3 inches at Newcastle and 1.5 inches at Emerson.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Although not a major storm by any means, this Sunday morning featured a quick-hitting burst of fluffy, wind-driven snow that roughly doubled accumulation expectations across much of South Central Nebraska, with several spots receiving 2-4 (and locally higher). The vast majority of 2+ amounts focused southwest of a line from Loup City-Grand Island-Clay Center-Hebron. According to reports from NeRAIN/CoCoRaHS and official NWS cooperative observers, some of the highest totals featured: 5 at Red Cloud, 4 at Hubbell, 3.9 at Hebron and also four miles southwest of Blue Hill, and 3.8 eight miles south of Elwood. In the Nebraska Tri Cities, totals included: 1.7 at Grand Island airport, 2.6 at Hastings NWS and 2.9 at Kearney airport. Although even the higher-end totals were relatively modest, this event packed somewhat of a punch given sustained north winds generally 20-25 MPH/gusts 30+ MPH, resulting in some drifting and at least brief visibility reductions to one-half mile or less. ||As for timing, the vast majority of accumulating snow fell between 3-10 AM, gradually ending from north-to-south as forcing departed southward into Kansas. Speaking of forcing, this event was driven by a classic case of pronounced mid-level frontogenesis, trailing well-behind a strong surface cold front that passed through during the preceding 24 hours. On the larger scale, a broad shortwave trough tracked southeast from the Northern Rockies/Dakotas into the Midwest over the course of Feb. 4th. Locally, this snow event was accompanied by a very cold airmass featuring surface temperatures only in the single digits above zero F, and wind chill values ranging from -10 to -20 F.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A snowfall total of 3.8 inches occurred 8 miles south of Elwood.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: For the second time in three days, South Central Nebraska saw a modest-but-noticeable round of snow on this Tuesday, as most of the 24-county area received 1-3, and localized totals to 4. Unlike the event two days prior on the 4th, winds were not much of a factor, with southeasterly speeds only averaging around 10 MPH. According to reports from NeRAIN/CoCoRaHS and official NWS cooperative observers, some of the highest totals featured: 4 at Geneva and four miles east of Ohiowa, 3.9 at Ravenna, 3.7 eight miles south of Elwood and 3.6 two miles northwest of Rockville. In the Nebraska Tri Cities, official totals included 3 at both Kearney and Grand Island airports and 2 at the Hastings NWS office. ||This event was squarely centered on the daytime hours, as snow first broke out in far southwestern counties (such as Furnas) shortly before sunrise and gradually expanded northeastward, affecting the majority of South Central Nebraska by mid-late morning. As the afternoon and early evening wore on, snow slowly ended from west-to-east, with the final steady band exiting Fillmore/Thayer counties between 7-8 PM. In the mid-upper levels, the primary instigator was a shortwave trough migrating east out of Colorado across Kansas and far southern Nebraska. At the surface, this was another very cold snow with daytime highs only topping out around 10 F, and the light winds promoted by strong Arctic high pressure (roughly 1033 millibars) centered over Iowa.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A snowfall total of 3.4 inches occurred 4 miles southwest of Blue Hill.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Between the afternoon of Friday the 9th and the evening of Saturday the 10th, two completely separate rounds of Advisory-worthy snow affected parts of the 24-county South Central Nebraska area, making for an active couple days of winter weather despite only modest impacts. Interestingly, the two snow events overlapped minimally in area, with the first round focused mainly within northern and central counties, and the second one across the south. This event summary discusses round 1, which occurred between the afternoon of the 9th and the pre-dawn hours of the 10th:||This first round of snow primarily affected areas north of Highway 6, and especially counties along and north of Interstate 80, which reported a fairly widespread coverage of 2-4 and isolated higher amounts to around 5. According to reports from NeRAIN/CoCoRaHS and official NWS cooperative observers, some of the highest totals featured: 5 northwest of Greeley, 4.7 west of Arcadia, 4.2 at Grand Island airport and 3.6 at Ravenna. Other official Tri Cities totals included 2.3 at Kearney and only 1.7 at the Hastings NWS office. Although not overly-strong, sustained north winds averaged 10-20 MPH with some higher gusts, causing at least minor blowing and drifting of the fluffy snow. Timing-wise, while some northern counties received minor accumulation early in the afternoon of the 9th, the primary west-east oriented snow band got going in the north between 4-6 PM before gradually slipping southward across the Interstate 80 corridor through the evening. Between midnight and 2 AM on the 10th, this snow band weakened and shifted east of the local area, signaling the end of round 1. Aloft, a large-scale, broad trough was in place over much of the United States with a series of jet streaks passing directly over Nebraska. This setup yielded a concentrated swath of mid-level frontogenesis, which in turn promoted the rather narrow, west-east oriented snow band that dropped the majority of accumulation. At the surface, the fluffy nature of the flakes was supported by a very cold airmass with temperatures only in the single digits above zero F. The breezy north winds resulted from steady pressure rises emanating southward across the Central Plains from high pressure in Montana and the Dakotas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A snowfall total of 2.0 inches occurred in Loup City. Also, 3.1 inches was reported 2 miles northwest of Rockville through CoCoRaHS. Also, a public report of 3.0 inches in Hazard was received via Facebook.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of severe thunderstorms and a few supercells moved east across central Kansas | and along Interstate 70, during the late afternoon and evening hours of May 1st, 2018.  The strongest supercell thunderstorms produced very large hail up to 4 inches in diameter.  A couple of tornadoes were produced by one strong supercell thunderstorm, the first touched down just south of Interstate 70, seven miles north of Ellsworth, and the second touched down,  3 miles north of Glendale, or 7 miles northwest of Salina, Kansas.  Damage from the tornadoes was minimal, however, significant damage occurred due to the very large hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The report came from National Severe Storms Lab mobile mesonet team while out chasing.

A complex of storms swept east across most of the region during the afternoon and evening hours of May 2nd, 2018.  As the storms moved east, a combination of large hail and damaging winds moved across the area.  A few tornadoes were also reported along the leading edge of the quasi linear convective system with only brief touchdowns reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Utility poles were reported blown down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another fast moving upper level weather system brought several bands of snow across portions of east central and southeast Nebraska, and parts of southwest Iowa during the afternoon and evening of February 6th.  Most areas received 1-3 inches of snow.  A band of heavier snow brought 4 to 5 inches to parts of Saline County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At Odell, 3 inches of snow was measured.  At Pickrell, 3.2 inches of snow was measured.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another fast moving upper level weather system brought several bands of snow across portions of east central and southeast Nebraska, and parts of southwest Iowa during the afternoon and evening of February 6th.  Most areas received 1-3 inches of snow.  A band of heavier snow brought 4 to 5 inches to parts of Saline County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At Swanton, 4.8 inches of snow was measured. Other measurements included 2.9 inches at Crete, 3.1 inches at Friend, 3.2 inches 3 miles east Swanton, 3.7 inches at Wilber, 3.9 inches 3 miles southeast of Wilber, and 4.4 inches at Western.

A series of severe thunderstorms and a few supercells moved east across central Kansas | and along Interstate 70, during the late afternoon and evening hours of May 1st, 2018.  The strongest supercell thunderstorms produced very large hail up to 4 inches in diameter.  A couple of tornadoes were produced by one strong supercell thunderstorm, the first touched down just south of Interstate 70, seven miles north of Ellsworth, and the second touched down,  3 miles north of Glendale, or 7 miles northwest of Salina, Kansas.  Damage from the tornadoes was minimal, however, significant damage occurred due to the very large hail.

During the late morning and through the early afternoon high winds on the backside of an upper level storm system reached the ground.  This resulted in wind gusts of 60 to 70 MPH.  The peak wind gust occurred in Hoxie.  The high winds also caused damage, including blowing over three semis pulling empty trailers, breaking off a five inch diameter tree limb, and blowing over a communications tower.  ||The high winds also created a dust storm at many locations leading to zero visibility.  The pockets of blowing dust originated near a weak stationary front draped across Northwest Kansas, then slowly moved south with the weak front through the afternoon.

Severe thunderstorms developed along and ahead of a quasi-stationary front that was draped across the area. One long-lived supercell produced a brief tornado northwest of Ark City before exiting into Oklahoma and becoming stationary. The supercell then moved north and produced multiple tornadoes as a large bow echo thunderstorm merged with the supercell in central Cowley County. This was quickly followed by several shorter-lived Quasi-Linear Convective System (QLCS) tornadoes north and east of Winfield.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Fifty to fifty five mph wind gusts were also reported with the hail.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of storms move east across the southern sections of Kansas producing large hail, very strong winds, and heavy rains.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Delayed report from social media. One half inch hail fell for about 3 or 4 minutes before changing to one inch hail or slightly larger for a brief time.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The first severe thunderstorms of the season occurred over Phillips and Smith counties on this Friday evening. A large area of showers evolved over southwest Nebraska. Around 6 PM CST, a thunderstorm formed at the southern edge of these showers along the Nebraska-Kansas state line, south of McCook. Over the next two hours, a small cyclonic-shaped arc of thunderstorms formed straddling the state line. The southernmost part of this arc moved east across Phillips and Smith counties between 7 and 9 PM CST. Severe hail occurred along most of the storms path from Logan to just south of Phillipsburg to Smith Center and Lebanon. Most of the hail reported was around 1 inch in diameter, but hail the size of ping pong balls was reported in Smith Center and golf ball size hail was reported near Glade. This storm produced lots of hail. One observer reported the ground was nearly covered in Smith Center. Severe winds also occurred over parts of Phillips county where winds were measured as high as 66 mph in Logan.||Cyclogenesis was occurring over eastern Colorado during the morning hours. As the low moved into western Kansas in the afternoon, a front that had been stationary from northwest to southeast across Kansas began moving north. By the time the storms formed, the front had moved to the Nebraska-Kansas border. These storms developed at the apex of the warm sector, near surface low, where temperatures were in the upper 70s and dewpoints were near 50. The cyclonic arc shape was to due the storms forming within a ribbon of mid-level frontogenesis. An elevated mixed layer had overspread the area, but the meager surface dewpoints resulted in weak instability with surface-based CAPE near 1000 J/kg. Deep layer shear was around 60 kt.

The first severe thunderstorms of the season occurred over Furnas and Harlan counties on this Friday evening. Scattered showers and a few elevated thunderstorms crossed these counties and adjacent areas between 5 PM and 6:30 PM CST. These storms were not severe. Meanwhile, a larger area of showers developed over southwest Nebraska. Around 6 PM CST, a thunderstorm formed at the southern edge of these showers south of McCook. Over the next two hours, this storm expanded into a small cyclonic-shaped arc of thunderstorms. This middle portion of this arc moved east across Furnas and Harlan counties between 6:30 and 8 PM CST. A small number of isolated, low-end severe hail reports were received. A few hailstones the size of quarters were observed in Edison. This was the largest hail size reported.||Cyclogenesis was occurring over eastern Colorado during the morning hours. As the low moved into western Kansas in the afternoon, a front that had been stationary from northwest to southeast across Kansas began moving north. By the time the storms formed, the front had moved to the Nebraska-Kansas border. The portion of this short line of storms that affected Furnas and Harlan counties was just north of the front. Strong cold air advection was occurring which lowered temperatures to near 50 with dewpoints in the upper 40s. The cyclonic arc shape was to due the storms forming within a ribbon of mid-level frontogenesis. An elevated mixed layer had overspread the area, but instability was weak with most unstable CAPE between 700 and 900 J/kg. Deep layer shear was around 60 kt.

Although not a major storm by any means, this Sunday morning featured a quick-hitting burst of fluffy, wind-driven snow that roughly doubled accumulation expectations across much of South Central Nebraska, with several spots receiving 2-4 (and locally higher). The vast majority of 2+ amounts focused southwest of a line from Loup City-Grand Island-Clay Center-Hebron. According to reports from NeRAIN/CoCoRaHS and official NWS cooperative observers, some of the highest totals featured: 5 at Red Cloud, 4 at Hubbell, 3.9 at Hebron and also four miles southwest of Blue Hill, and 3.8 eight miles south of Elwood. In the Nebraska Tri Cities, totals included: 1.7 at Grand Island airport, 2.6 at Hastings NWS and 2.9 at Kearney airport. Although even the higher-end totals were relatively modest, this event packed somewhat of a punch given sustained north winds generally 20-25 MPH/gusts 30+ MPH, resulting in some drifting and at least brief visibility reductions to one-half mile or less. ||As for timing, the vast majority of accumulating snow fell between 3-10 AM, gradually ending from north-to-south as forcing departed southward into Kansas. Speaking of forcing, this event was driven by a classic case of pronounced mid-level frontogenesis, trailing well-behind a strong surface cold front that passed through during the preceding 24 hours. On the larger scale, a broad shortwave trough tracked southeast from the Northern Rockies/Dakotas into the Midwest over the course of Feb. 4th. Locally, this snow event was accompanied by a very cold airmass featuring surface temperatures only in the single digits above zero F, and wind chill values ranging from -10 to -20 F.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A snowfall total of 3.0 inches occurred in Wilsonville. Also, 2.4 inches occurred 6 miles north northwest of Oxford.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another fast moving upper level weather system brought several bands of snow across portions of east central and southeast Nebraska, and parts of southwest Iowa during the afternoon and evening of February 6th.  Most areas received 1-3 inches of snow.  A band of heavier snow brought 4 to 5 inches to parts of Saline County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a report of 1.5 inches of snow measured at Waverly. And 1.8 inches of snow fell  2 miles south southwest of Lincoln.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper level jet pushing across the Rockies resulted in development of low pressure across southeast Colorado late on April 2, which intensified rapidly moving across Kansas and into Illinois on April 3. A broad swath of snow and gusty winds developed north of the low track across the area, with heaviest snowfall amounts in excess of 6 inches generally corresponding to highest terrain areas in south central and southeast South Dakota, northern portions of northwest Iowa and areas of southwest Minnesota. As unseasonably cold high pressure spread in behind the system on the morning of April 4, a few low temperature records were broken by as much as 5 to 15 degrees.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A period of snowfall developed in the early morning hours of April 3, continuing at times into early afternoon. Winds shifted northwest and increased substantially with gusts of 30 to 40 mph at times through the late morning and afternoon. Snowfall totaled 3.8 inches at Concord.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A period of snowfall developed in the early morning hours of April 3, continuing at times into early afternoon. Winds shifted northwest and increased substantially with gusts of 30 to 40 mph at times through the late morning and afternoon. Snowfall totaled 1.0 inch at Emerson.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong northwest winds of 30 to 40 mph with gusts to 60 mph or higher occurred during the mid morning, through the afternoon hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Gordon AWOS recorded sustained winds of 40 mph during the mid morning into the afternoon hours. These types of sustained winds along with a few gusts up to 59 mph were common throughout Sheridan County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe to extreme drought persisted over a good portions of central and south central Kansas during the month of May.  Welcome rainfall during the beginning of the month and again at the end of the month, improved the drought some over south central Kansas by the end of the month.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Severe drought conditions were over the entire county for early portion of the month, but welcome rainfall during the beginning and end of the month improved the drought conditions considerably by the end of the month.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Numerous severe thunderstorms struck much of Central and South-Central Kansas with large hail and damaging winds. There were instances when & where the hail was very large, most notably on the south side of McPherson where it reached the size of baseballs. Gusts from 52 to 62 knots were measured in many areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Windows were broken on several cars.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High winds on the backside of an upper level storm system reached the ground in Hitchcock and Red Willow counties.  The peak wind gust was 66 MPH at McCook.  The high winds also fueled a wildfire which consumed a house on the north side of McCook.

The pockets of blowing dust originated near a weak stationary front draped across Northwest Kansas, then slowly moved south with the weak front through the afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The high winds caused a semi pulling an empty trailer to be blown over on Highway 83 at Rexford, leading to one injury.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Although not a major storm by any means, this Sunday morning featured a quick-hitting burst of fluffy, wind-driven snow that roughly doubled accumulation expectations across much of South Central Nebraska, with several spots receiving 2-4 (and locally higher). The vast majority of 2+ amounts focused southwest of a line from Loup City-Grand Island-Clay Center-Hebron. According to reports from NeRAIN/CoCoRaHS and official NWS cooperative observers, some of the highest totals featured: 5 at Red Cloud, 4 at Hubbell, 3.9 at Hebron and also four miles southwest of Blue Hill, and 3.8 eight miles south of Elwood. In the Nebraska Tri Cities, totals included: 1.7 at Grand Island airport, 2.6 at Hastings NWS and 2.9 at Kearney airport. Although even the higher-end totals were relatively modest, this event packed somewhat of a punch given sustained north winds generally 20-25 MPH/gusts 30+ MPH, resulting in some drifting and at least brief visibility reductions to one-half mile or less. ||As for timing, the vast majority of accumulating snow fell between 3-10 AM, gradually ending from north-to-south as forcing departed southward into Kansas. Speaking of forcing, this event was driven by a classic case of pronounced mid-level frontogenesis, trailing well-behind a strong surface cold front that passed through during the preceding 24 hours. On the larger scale, a broad shortwave trough tracked southeast from the Northern Rockies/Dakotas into the Midwest over the course of Feb. 4th. Locally, this snow event was accompanied by a very cold airmass featuring surface temperatures only in the single digits above zero F, and wind chill values ranging from -10 to -20 F.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A snowfall total of 4.0 inches occurred in Hubbell, and also, 3.9 inches fell in Hebron.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High winds on the backside of an upper level storm system reached the ground in Hitchcock and Red Willow counties.  The peak wind gust was 66 MPH at McCook.  The high winds also fueled a wildfire which consumed a house on the north side of McCook.
During the evening showers, moving east into Sherman and Wallace counties, brought high winds behind a warm front down to the ground. The peak gust was 76 MPH near Weskan.
During the evening showers, moving east into Sherman and Wallace counties, brought high winds behind a warm front down to the ground. The peak gust was 76 MPH near Weskan.
High winds on the backside of an upper level storm system, behind a cold front, reached ground during the afternoon.  The peak gust was 78 MPH at Leoti.

During the late morning and through the early afternoon high winds on the backside of an upper level storm system reached the ground.  This resulted in wind gusts of 60 to 70 MPH.  The peak wind gust occurred in Hoxie.  The high winds also caused damage, including blowing over three semis pulling empty trailers, breaking off a five inch diameter tree limb, and blowing over a communications tower.  ||The high winds also created a dust storm at many locations leading to zero visibility.  The pockets of blowing dust originated near a weak stationary front draped across Northwest Kansas, then slowly moved south with the weak front through the afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The high winds blew two semis over.  One blow over occurred on Highway 40 west of Winona near the county line.  Another blow over occurred two miles west of Winona on Highway 40.  A combination of deteriorating structural integrity at the base of a free standing radio tower in Oakley, and a tree branch pushing on the tower caused the tower to be blown over.  The 100 ft. tall tower landed on two cars.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of severe thunderstorms and a few supercells moved east across central Kansas | and along Interstate 70, during the late afternoon and evening hours of May 1st, 2018.  The strongest supercell thunderstorms produced very large hail up to 4 inches in diameter.  A couple of tornadoes were produced by one strong supercell thunderstorm, the first touched down just south of Interstate 70, seven miles north of Ellsworth, and the second touched down,  3 miles north of Glendale, or 7 miles northwest of Salina, Kansas.  Damage from the tornadoes was minimal, however, significant damage occurred due to the very large hail.
Strong northwest winds of 30 to 40 mph with gusts to 60 mph or higher occurred during the mid morning, through the afternoon hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nearby Imperial ASOS recorded a peak gust of 58 mph during the mid afternoon hours. Sustained winds were also frequently around 40 mph during the mid morning into the afternoon hours.  These types of sustained winds along with a few gusts near 60 mph were common throughout Hayes County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong northwest winds of 30 to 40 mph with gusts to 60 mph or higher occurred during the mid morning, through the afternoon hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nearby McCook ASOS recorded a peak gust of 61 mph during the late morning hours. Sustained winds were also frequently around 40 mph during the late morning into the mid afternoon hours.  These types of sustained winds along with a few gusts near 60 mph were common throughout Frontier County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong northwest winds of 30 to 40 mph with gusts to 60 mph or higher occurred during the mid morning, through the afternoon hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nearby North Platte ASOS recorded sustained winds of 40 mph during the mid morning into the afternoon hours.  Wind gusts also frequently reached 55 to 65 mph, with a peak gust of 72 mph recorded mid afternoon. These types of sustained winds along with frequent gusts of 55 to 65 mph, up to around 70 mph common throughout Logan County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Numerous severe thunderstorms struck much of Central and South-Central Kansas with large hail and damaging winds. There were instances when & where the hail was very large, most notably on the south side of McPherson where it reached the size of baseballs. Gusts from 52 to 62 knots were measured in many areas.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The most intense storm of the month, in fact many months, wrapped up across the central Plains on April 13, spreading a mix of wintry precipitation across the area, accompanied by numerous thunderstorms. Not included in this episode was the spotty severe hail and wind which occurred in southeast South Dakota and southwest Minnesota prior to the onset of snowfall during the morning and afternoon of April 13. |Eventually, influx of colder air would change all precipitation over to snow, and ushered in a record-breaking snowfall of 8 to 16 inches (some locations over 20 inches) and fierce winds gusting 50 to 60 mph to southeast South Dakota, southwest Minnesota, northwest Iowa and extreme northeast Nebraska. Snow drifts over 6 feet were reported in many locations. Extremely low visibility persisted for almost a day for most locations, making travel very difficult if not impossible. ||One person was killed in Rock County when the snowmobile he was riding collided with an interstate guard rail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Life threatening conditions developed during the early morning of April 14, as the earlier mix of rain, sleet and snow changed to all snow, and brutal winds (gusting as high as 46 mph at Sioux City) whipped visibility to less than a quarter mile at times through the evening of April 14.  Travel was not recommended for much of the two day period, if not impossible. A storm total snowfall of 4.5 inches was measured at Emerson.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: There were no reports of damage.

Severe to extreme drought persisted over a good portions of central and south central Kansas during the month of May.  Welcome rainfall during the beginning of the month and again at the end of the month, improved the drought some over south central Kansas by the end of the month.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Extreme drought conditions persisted over the eastern half of the county.  But welcome rainfall during the beginning and end of the month actually improved the drought to severe for western and southern portions of the county by the end of the month.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The most intense storm of the month, in fact many months, wrapped up across the central Plains on April 13, spreading a mix of wintry precipitation across the area, accompanied by numerous thunderstorms. Not included in this episode was the spotty severe hail and wind which occurred in southeast South Dakota and southwest Minnesota prior to the onset of snowfall during the morning and afternoon of April 13. |Eventually, influx of colder air would change all precipitation over to snow, and ushered in a record-breaking snowfall of 8 to 16 inches (some locations over 20 inches) and fierce winds gusting 50 to 60 mph to southeast South Dakota, southwest Minnesota, northwest Iowa and extreme northeast Nebraska. EVENT_NARRATIVE: Life threatening conditions developed during the early morning of April 14, as the earlier mix of rain, sleet and snow changed to all snow, and brutal winds (gusting as high as 56 mph near Concord) whipped visibility to less than a quarter mile at times through the evening of April 14. EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Widespread high winds occurred on this Monday and Tuesday. Between midnight and 6 AM CST Monday, an occluded front swept across south central Nebraska. During the day Monday, several lows consolidated into a primary low along the South Dakota-Minnesota border. This low became nearly stationary as the fronts continued to progress far to the east and south. Monday night this low performed a loop and moved southeast into Iowa. During the day Tuesday, this low rapidly filled and became absorbed into a low over the Great Lakes. Two periods of strong winds occurred. The first occurred from midday through the afternoon hours Monday due to diurnal mixing. Widespread wind gusts of 50 to 61 mph occurred mainly along and west of Highway 281. There were a couple mesonet sites that measured 64 mph near Kearney and 69 mph near Norman, although these stations may not necessarily be sited properly. From the official stations, the highest winds were measured at Lexington where winds were sustained at or above 40 mph for five hours with a peak gust of 61 mph. The high winds combined with dry fuels and relative humidity levels as low as 23% to create favorable conditions for the wildfire that occurred near Wilsonville. There was a lull over much of the area during the evening, then winds increased again. The second period of high winds occurred between midnight and 9 AM CST on Tuesday. These winds were associated with a tightening of the pressure gradient as the low performed its loop. This also induced steepening lapse rates associated with an increase in cold air advection. Widespread wind gusts between 50 and 68 mph occurred. The highest wind gusts from official stations included 66 mph at the airport in Hastings and 65 mph at the Central Nebraska Regional Airport in Grand Island. The highest unofficial gust was 68 mph near Norman.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind gust of 62 MPH was measured by the Ord Airport ASOS.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another fast moving upper level weather system brought several bands of snow across portions of east central and southeast Nebraska, and parts of southwest Iowa during the afternoon and evening of February 6th.  Most areas received 1-3 inches of snow.  A band of heavier snow brought 4 to 5 inches to parts of Saline County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A person 3 miles east of Millard measured 1 inch of snow. At 4 miles east southeast of Omaha, 0.8 inch of snow was measured.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong northwest winds exceeding 60 mph occurred in Custer County during the early morning hours on March 6th, and across Frontier County during the morning through the mid afternoon hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nearby Imperial ASOS recorded a 58 mph wind gust at 1104 am CST. These strong northwest winds were common throughout Hayes County during the morning into the early afternoon hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Widespread high winds occurred on this Monday and Tuesday. Between midnight and 6 AM CST Monday, an occluded front swept across south central Nebraska. During the day Monday, several lows consolidated into a primary low along the South Dakota-Minnesota border. This low became nearly stationary as the fronts continued to progress far to the east and south. Monday night this low performed a loop and moved southeast into Iowa. During the day Tuesday, this low rapidly filled and became absorbed into a low over the Great Lakes. Two periods of strong winds occurred. The first occurred from midday through the afternoon hours Monday due to diurnal mixing. Widespread wind gusts of 50 to 61 mph occurred mainly along and west of Highway 281. There were a couple mesonet sites that measured 64 mph near Kearney and 69 mph near Norman, although these stations may not necessarily be sited properly. From the official stations, the highest winds were measured at Lexington where winds were sustained at or above 40 mph for five hours with a peak gust of 61 mph. The high winds combined with dry fuels and relative humidity levels as low as 23% to create favorable conditions for the wildfire that occurred near Wilsonville. There was a lull over much of the area during the evening, then winds increased again. The second period of high winds occurred between midnight and 9 AM CST on Tuesday. These winds were associated with a tightening of the pressure gradient as the low performed its loop. This also induced steepening lapse rates associated with an increase in cold air advection. Widespread wind gusts between 50 and 68 mph occurred. The highest wind gusts from official stations included 66 mph at the airport in Hastings and 65 mph at the Central Nebraska Regional Airport in Grand Island. The highest unofficial gust was 68 mph near Norman.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind gust of 65 MPH was measured by the Central Nebraska Regional-Grand Island Airport ASOS.

This low became nearly stationary as the fronts continued to progress far to the east and south. Monday night this low performed a loop and moved southeast into Iowa. During the day Tuesday, this low rapidly filled and became absorbed into a low over the Great Lakes. Two periods of strong winds occurred. The first occurred from midday through the afternoon hours Monday due to diurnal mixing. Widespread wind gusts of 50 to 61 mph occurred mainly along and west of Highway 281. There were a couple mesonet sites that measured 64 mph near Kearney and 69 mph near Norman, although these stations may not necessarily be sited properly. From the official stations, the highest winds were measured at Lexington where winds were sustained at or above 40 mph for five hours with a peak gust of 61 mph. The high winds combined with dry fuels and relative humidity levels as low as 23% to create favorable conditions for the wildfire that occurred near Wilsonville. There was a lull over much of the area during the evening, then winds increased again. The second period of high winds occurred between midnight and 9 AM CST on Tuesday. These winds were associated with a tightening of the pressure gradient as the low performed its loop. This also induced steepening lapse rates associated with an increase in cold air advection. Widespread wind gusts between 50 and 68 mph occurred. The highest wind gusts from official stations included 66 mph at the airport in Hastings and 65 mph at the Central Nebraska Regional Airport in Grand Island. The highest unofficial gust was 68 mph near Norman.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind gust of 59 MPH was measured by a mesonet located 3 miles west of Sumner.

During the day Monday, several lows consolidated into a primary low along the South Dakota-Minnesota border. This low became nearly stationary as the fronts continued to progress far to the east and south. Monday night this low performed a loop and moved southeast into Iowa. During the day Tuesday, this low rapidly filled and became absorbed into a low over the Great Lakes. Two periods of strong winds occurred. The first occurred from midday through the afternoon hours Monday due to diurnal mixing. Widespread wind gusts of 50 to 61 mph occurred mainly along and west of Highway 281. There were a couple mesonet sites that measured 64 mph near Kearney and 69 mph near Norman, although these stations may not necessarily be sited properly. From the official stations, the highest winds were measured at Lexington where winds were sustained at or above 40 mph for five hours with a peak gust of 61 mph. The high winds combined with dry fuels and relative humidity levels as low as 23% to create favorable conditions for the wildfire that occurred near Wilsonville. There was a lull over much of the area during the evening, then winds increased again. The second period of high winds occurred between midnight and 9 AM CST on Tuesday. These winds were associated with a tightening of the pressure gradient as the low performed its loop. This also induced steepening lapse rates associated with an increase in cold air advection. Widespread wind gusts between 50 and 68 mph occurred. The highest wind gusts from official stations included 66 mph at the airport in Hastings and 65 mph at the Central Nebraska Regional Airport in Grand Island. The highest unofficial gust was 68 mph near Norman.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind gust of 58 MPH was measured by the Ord Airport ASOS.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Widespread high winds occurred on this Monday and Tuesday. Between midnight and 6 AM CST Monday, a triple point low and associated fronts swept across north central Kansas. During the day Monday, several lows consolidated into a primary low along the South Dakota-Minnesota border. This low became nearly stationary as the fronts continued to progress far to the east and south. Monday night this low performed a loop and moved southeast into Iowa. During the day Tuesday, this low rapidly filled and became absorbed into a low over the Great Lakes. Strong winds occurred from the late morning into the afternoon hours Monday and Tuesday due to diurnal mixing. Widespread wind gusts of 50 to 60 mph occurred on both days with the highest wind gust occurring at Logan. The high winds combined with dry fuels and relative humidity levels as low as 23% to create favorable conditions for the wildfire that occurred near Kensington.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind gust of 60 MPH was measured by a mesonet located 1 mile west of Logan.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Widespread high winds occurred on this Monday and Tuesday. Between midnight and 6 AM CST Monday, a triple point low and associated fronts swept across north central Kansas. During the day Monday, several lows consolidated into a primary low along the South Dakota-Minnesota border. This low became nearly stationary as the fronts continued to progress far to the east and south. Monday night this low performed a loop and moved southeast into Iowa. During the day Tuesday, this low rapidly filled and became absorbed into a low over the Great Lakes. EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind gust of 58 MPH was measured by a mesonet located 1 mile west of Logan.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A band of 3 to 6 inches of snow fell across portions of Dawson, Gosper, Phelps, and Kearney counties on this Monday. During the evening hours on the 18th, a cyclonic band of precipitation developed east and north of the developing mid-level low. This band of precipitation remained over Kansas. However, a large area of snow developed north of this band over south central Nebraska primarily south of Interstate 80. The northern fringe remained stationary for a time as it pivoted between midnight and 6 AM. The snow then ended as it dropped to the south. The highest amount was 5.5 inches at Johnson Lake. Other amounts include 5 inches at Holdrege, 4 at Minden, and 3-4 inches in and near Lexington.||Lee cyclogenesis occurred over Colorado the day before and this low moved east along the Kansas-Oklahoma border that night. A strong trough progressed east from Colorado and New Mexico with a closed mid-level low forming on the Kansas-Oklahoma state line. This snow developed in a weak area of frontogenesis.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Storm total snowfall amounts of 3 to 6 inches were reported across the area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of severe thunderstorms and a few supercells moved east across central Kansas | and along Interstate 70, during the late afternoon and evening hours of May 1st, 2018.  The strongest supercell thunderstorms produced very large hail up to 4 inches in diameter.  A couple of tornadoes were produced by one strong supercell thunderstorm, the first touched down just south of Interstate 70, seven miles north of Ellsworth, and the second touched down,  3 miles north of Glendale, or 7 miles northwest of Salina, Kansas.  Damage from the tornadoes was minimal, however, significant damage occurred due to the very large hail.

During the late morning and through the early afternoon high winds on the backside of an upper level storm system reached the ground.  This resulted in wind gusts of 60 to 70 MPH.  The peak wind gust occurred in Hoxie.  The high winds also caused damage, including blowing over three semis pulling empty trailers, breaking off a five inch diameter tree limb, and blowing over a communications tower.  ||The high winds also created a dust storm at many locations leading to zero visibility.  The pockets of blowing dust originated near a weak stationary front draped across Northwest Kansas, then slowly moved south with the weak front through the afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Zero visibility reported from Winona west to the county line and north from Winona to the county line.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A complex of storms swept east across most of the region during the afternoon and evening hours of May 2nd, 2018.  As the storms moved east, a combination of large hail and damaging winds moved across the area.  A few tornadoes were also reported along the leading edge of the quasi linear convective system with only brief touchdowns reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A weak tornado formed on the leading edge of a bow echo and moved over open country. No damage was reported from this touchdown.

A series of severe thunderstorms and a few supercells moved east across central Kansas | and along Interstate 70, during the late afternoon and evening hours of May 1st, 2018.  The strongest supercell thunderstorms produced very large hail up to 4 inches in diameter.  A couple of tornadoes were produced by one strong supercell thunderstorm, the first touched down just south of Interstate 70, seven miles north of Ellsworth, and the second touched down,  3 miles north of Glendale, or 7 miles northwest of Salina, Kansas.  Damage from the tornadoes was minimal, however, significant damage occurred due to the very large hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Winds of 50 mph were also reported.

Late in the night from the 30th to early in the morning on the 31st severe thunderstorms raced across Southern Kansas. Clocked in most cases from 60 to 70 mph, the severe thunderstorms struck many areas with damaging, and at times, destructive winds, that frequently reached 60 to 80 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The destructive winds tore off part of a roof from a home.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe to extreme drought persisted over a good portions of central and south central Kansas during the month of May.  Welcome rainfall during the beginning of the month and again at the end of the month, improved the drought some over south central Kansas by the end of the month.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Extreme drought conditions persisted over the southern half of the county.  But welcome rainfall during the beginning and end of the month actually improved the drought to severe for northern portions of the county by the end of the month.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large cluster of t-storms developed during the afternoon of May 2 across central Kansas. The cluster evolved into a line or lines of storms that moved across northeast and east central Kansas during the afternoon and evening of May 2.  Wind damage reports occurred in addition to a few tornado reports with the lines.  At least 3 documented tornadoes occurred but all were short lived and relatively weak.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Public report relayed by Sheriff of a brief tornado in open field did no damage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the latter half of the afternoon strong to severe thunderstorms moved north across Northwest Kansas.  Storm coverage increased in the late afternoon along an outflow boundary from one of storms as it moved north.  Behind the outflow boundary wind gusts around 60 MPH were reported, which caused some damage.   The largest hail reported was golf ball size near Colby.
A Quasi Linear Convective System starting on November 30th and ending on December 1st produced 60 to 70 mph winds that damaged outbuildings and downed trees and power lines.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm winds broke three power poles and overturned a 33ft RV. Time based on radar.

The pockets of blowing dust originated near a weak stationary front draped across Northwest Kansas, then slowly moved south with the weak front through the afternoon.

A winter storm brought areas of light freezing rain, followed by a period of heavy snowfall to much of Sheridan County and Cherry County during the morning into the afternoon hours. Freezing rain around a tenth of an inch with local amounts up to a quarter inch were reported. Snowfall amounts from 4 to 6 inches were also reported across the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: General public reported via social media, 4.6 inches of snowfall at 410 pm cst. The Valentine ASOS also recorded a quarter inch of ice accumulation at 1252 pm cst. Snowfall amounts from 3 to 6 inches, and ice accumulations up to a quarter of an inch were common across eastern Cherry County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system moved out of Colorado across east central Nebraska and produced snow and strong winds across northeast Nebraska. This created blowing snow conditions | and whiteout conditions across eastern Nebraska and western Iowa.  Winds gusted to 55 mph at Lincoln, NE, 53 mph at Norfolk, and 47 mph at  Eppley Airfield in Omaha. Snowfall ranged from about 1 inch in Lincoln and Columbus to as much as 6 inches in northern Cedar and Knox Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Thurston County Emergency Manager reported 2.5 inches of snow in Pender.

During the late afternoon a strong line of thunderstorm developed over Red Willow County ahead of a cold front, producing nickel size hail near Danbury.  The stronger part of the line was south of the state line in Kansas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The hail lasted 10 minutes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of severe thunderstorms and a few supercells moved east across central Kansas | and along Interstate 70, during the late afternoon and evening hours of May 1st, 2018.  The strongest supercell thunderstorms produced very large hail up to 4 inches in diameter.  A couple of tornadoes were produced by one strong supercell thunderstorm, the first touched down just south of Interstate 70, seven miles north of Ellsworth, and the second touched down,  3 miles north of Glendale, or 7 miles northwest of Salina, Kansas.  Damage from the tornadoes was minimal, however, significant damage occurred due to the very large hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A supercell thunderstorm produced a tornado, across northern portions of Saline county, Kansas, 7 miles northwest of Salina, Kansas.  When the tornado touched down, it produced damage to a metal barn. Part of the roof had been blown off and some of the side walls had been blown out. The tornado continued to track to the northwest and moved into Ottawa county, Kansas, just to the east of the town of Tescott.  The tornado was on the ground for 1.6 miles, in Saline county, and had a path width of 200 yards. A National Weather Service survey team, rated the tornado an EF1, across Saline county. Note: the tornado would go on to produce EF3 damage across Ottawa county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms developed along and ahead of a quasi-stationary front that was draped across the area. One long-lived supercell produced a brief tornado northwest of Ark City before exiting into Oklahoma and becoming stationary. The supercell then moved north and produced multiple tornadoes as a large bow echo thunderstorm merged with the supercell in central Cowley County. This was quickly followed by several shorter-lived Quasi-Linear Convective System (QLCS) tornadoes north and east of Winfield.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Tree damage was noted along the path.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Although not a major storm by any means, this Sunday morning featured a quick-hitting burst of fluffy, wind-driven snow that roughly doubled accumulation expectations across much of South Central Nebraska, with several spots receiving 2-4 (and locally higher). The vast majority of 2+ amounts focused southwest of a line from Loup City-Grand Island-Clay Center-Hebron. According to reports from NeRAIN/CoCoRaHS and official NWS cooperative observers, some of the highest totals featured: 5 at Red Cloud, 4 at Hubbell, 3.9 at Hebron and also four miles southwest of Blue Hill, and 3.8 eight miles south of Elwood. In the Nebraska Tri Cities, totals included: 1.7 at Grand Island airport, 2.6 at Hastings NWS and 2.9 at Kearney airport. Although even the higher-end totals were relatively modest, this event packed somewhat of a punch given sustained north winds generally 20-25 MPH/gusts 30+ MPH, resulting in some drifting and at least brief visibility reductions to one-half mile or less. ||As for timing, the vast majority of accumulating snow fell between 3-10 AM, gradually ending from north-to-south as forcing departed southward into Kansas. Speaking of forcing, this event was driven by a classic case of pronounced mid-level frontogenesis, trailing well-behind a strong surface cold front that passed through during the preceding 24 hours. On the larger scale, a broad shortwave trough tracked southeast from the Northern Rockies/Dakotas into the Midwest over the course of Feb. 4th. Locally, this snow event was accompanied by a very cold airmass featuring surface temperatures only in the single digits above zero F, and wind chill values ranging from -10 to -20 F.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A snowfall total of 5.0 inches occurred in Red Cloud. Also, 3.9 inches of snowfall occurred 4 miles southwest of Blue Hill.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Across southwest Nebraska, strong northwest winds of 30 to 40 mph with gusts to near 60 mph or higher occurred during the mid morning, through the mid afternoon hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Imperial ASOS recorded sustained wind gusts of 40 mph from mid morning through the early afternoon hours.  A peak wind gust of 58 mph occurred at 1004 am MST. These sustained winds and gusts were common across Chase County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Across southwest Nebraska, strong northwest winds of 30 to 40 mph with gusts to near 60 mph or higher occurred during the mid morning, through the mid afternoon hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The nearby Imperial ASOS recorded sustained wind gusts of 40 mph from mid morning through the early afternoon hours.  A peak wind gust of 58 mph occurred at 1004 am MST. These sustained winds and gusts were common across Hayes County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Across southwest Nebraska, strong northwest winds of 30 to 40 mph with gusts to near 60 mph or higher occurred during the mid morning, through the mid afternoon hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The nearby McCook ASOS recorded sustained wind gusts of 40 mph from mid morning through the mid afternoon hours.  A peak wind gust of 66 mph occurred at 1126 am CST. These sustained winds and gusts over 60 mph were common across Frontier County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An isolated severe thunderstorm that struck Southwest Kingman County just after mid-night from the 30th to the 31st packed a nasty punch when a location 2 miles southeast of Zenda was hit by an estimated 70 mph gust. The powerful winds knocked down several large branches of unknown diameters.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The estimated 70 mph winds knocked down several large branches of unknown diameters.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Across southwest Nebraska, strong northwest winds of 30 to 40 mph with gusts to near 60 mph or higher occurred during the mid morning, through the mid afternoon hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The nearby Ogallala AWOS recorded sustained wind gusts of 40 mph from mid morning through the early afternoon hours. These sustained winds were common across Deuel County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Across southwest Nebraska, strong northwest winds of 30 to 40 mph with gusts to near 60 mph or higher occurred during the mid morning, through the mid afternoon hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The nearby Ogallala AWOS recorded sustained wind gusts of 40 mph from mid morning through the early afternoon hours. These sustained winds were common across Perkins County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Across southwest Nebraska, strong northwest winds of 30 to 40 mph with gusts to near 60 mph or higher occurred during the mid morning, through the mid afternoon hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The North Platte ASOS recorded sustained wind gusts of 40 mph from the mid to late morning hours.  A peak wind gust of 58 mph occurred at a mesonet site near North Platte at 855 am CST. These sustained winds and gusts near 60 mph were common across Lincoln County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Across southwest Nebraska, strong northwest winds of 30 to 40 mph with gusts to near 60 mph or higher occurred during the mid morning, through the mid afternoon hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Ogallala AWOS recorded sustained wind gusts of 40 mph from mid morning through the early afternoon hours. These sustained winds were common across Keith County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the late morning and through the early afternoon high winds on the backside of an upper level storm system reached the ground.  This resulted in wind gusts of 60 to 70 MPH.  The peak wind gust occurred in Hoxie.  The high winds also caused damage, including blowing over three semis pulling empty trailers, breaking off a five inch diameter tree limb, and blowing over a communications tower.  ||The high winds also created a dust storm at many locations leading to zero visibility.  The pockets of blowing dust originated near a weak stationary front draped across Northwest Kansas, then slowly moved south with the weak front through the afternoon.

A series of severe thunderstorms and a few supercells moved east across central Kansas | and along Interstate 70, during the late afternoon and evening hours of May 1st, 2018.  The strongest supercell thunderstorms produced very large hail up to 4 inches in diameter.  A couple of tornadoes were produced by one strong supercell thunderstorm, the first touched down just south of Interstate 70, seven miles north of Ellsworth, and the second touched down,  3 miles north of Glendale, or 7 miles northwest of Salina, Kansas.  Damage from the tornadoes was minimal, however, significant damage occurred due to the very large hail.

Damage from the tornadoes was minimal, however, significant damage occurred due to the very large hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Sent via Twitter. The hail lasted for 10 minutes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms developed along and ahead of a quasi-stationary front that was draped across the area. One long-lived supercell produced a brief tornado northwest of Ark City before exiting into Oklahoma and becoming stationary. The supercell then moved north and produced multiple tornadoes as a large bow echo thunderstorm merged with the supercell in central Cowley County. This was quickly followed by several shorter-lived Quasi-Linear Convective System (QLCS) tornadoes north and east of Winfield.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Large electrical transmission lines were downed and a tree was completely uprooted.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms developed during the early morning hours of March 26th across southern Kansas. These storms moved northeast and produced up to baseball size hail across portions of Lyon and Coffey counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: KVOE radio relayed the report.

Numerous severe thunderstorms struck much of Central and South-Central Kansas with large hail and damaging winds. There were instances when & where the hail was very large, most notably on the south side of McPherson where it reached the size of baseballs. Gusts from 52 to 62 knots were measured in many areas.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper-level storm system tracked from the northern Rockies into northern High Plains with an associated surface low developing east across the Dakotas. Thunderstorms developed during the late afternoon and evening hours from north-central into eastern Nebraska along a trailing cold front with storms organizing into a bow-echo complex which produced numerous severe wind gusts and wind damage over northeast Nebraska, as well as a brief tornado near Madison, NE.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter estimated 60 mph winds from a thunderstorm 1/2 mile east of Stanton.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong northwest winds exceeding 60 mph occurred in Custer County during the early morning hours on March 6th, and across Frontier County during the morning through the mid afternoon hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Broken Bow ASOS recorded a peak wind gust of 61 mph at 1247 am CST with a sustained winds  exceeding 40 mph between 1 am and 2 am CST.  These strong winds were common throughout Custer County during the early morning hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A winter storm brought areas of light freezing rain, followed by a period of heavy snowfall to much of Sheridan County and Cherry County during the morning into the afternoon hours. Freezing rain around a tenth of an inch with local amounts up to a quarter inch were reported. Snowfall amounts from 4 to 6 inches were also reported across the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A Cooperative observer located 6 miles north of Gordon reported ice accumulations of a tenth of an inch, followed by snowfall amounts of 6 inches by mid afternoon. Snowfall amounts from 3 to 7 inches, and ice accumulations up to a tenth of an inch were common across Sheridan County.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A nearby Cooperative observer located 6 miles north of Gordon reported ice accumulations of a tenth of an inch, followed by snowfall amounts of 6 inches by mid afternoon. Snowfall amounts from 3 to 6 inches, and ice accumulations up to a tenth of an inch were common across western Cherry County.
