EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Behind a cold front, high winds on the backside of a weak upper level disturbance reached the ground in a few counties. In Sherman County, the peak gust was 61 MPH at Goodland. Wallace and Gove counties also experienced high winds.||To the east ahead of the cold front, a line of strong to severe thunderstorms was moving east across Decatur, Norton, and Graham counties.  These storms produced large hail and severe wind gusts.  The largest hail size reported was golf ball at Norton, and the highest wind gust was 63 MPH at Hill City.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous ping-pong to golf ball size hail fell.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system moved eastward across southeast Nebraska with a warm front extending east into southern Iowa.  Isolated thunderstorms develop along and north of the warm front producing isolated damaging winds and large hail across southeast Nebraska and southwest Iowa.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Penny size hail reported south of Auburn.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system moved eastward across southeast Nebraska with a warm front extending east into southern Iowa.  Isolated thunderstorms develop along and north of the warm front producing isolated damaging winds and large hail across southeast Nebraska and southwest Iowa.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A roof was blown off a building.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system moved eastward across southeast Nebraska with a warm front extending east into southern Iowa.  Isolated thunderstorms develop along and north of the warm front producing isolated damaging winds and large hail across southeast Nebraska and southwest Iowa.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Nebraska City AWOS reported a 62 mph wind gust from a thunderstorm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Sunday the 29th and Monday the 30th were two of the windiest consecutive days of spring 2018 within South Central Nebraska, especially in terms of SOUTH winds. On both days, primarily the afternoon featured several hours of sustained speeds commonly 25-35 MPH (isolated 40 MPH) and frequent gusts to around 50 MPH, along with isolated severe-criteria gusts of 58+ MPH. Also on both days, the combination of recent dry conditions and recently-tilled fields promoted a number of localized dust storms, causing drastic visibility reductions over short distances. Specifically on the late afternoon of the 29th, dust blowing across Interstate 80 near the Aurora exit led to a major pileup of 29 vehicles, closing I-80 for over two hours. Sadly, this incident resulted in one fatality and over a dozen injuries. ||As for measured winds from a variety of official and unofficial sources, a few peak gusts on the 29th featured: 62 MPH near Kearney (mesonet), 59 MPH near Oxford (mesonet), and 58 MPH at Grand Island and Ord airports. At Kearney Regional Airport, sustained winds averaged 40 MPH for an hour, mainly between 12-1 PM CDT. Although it remained quite breezy even after dark, gusts by late evening largely eased below 40 MPH. Turning to the meteorological background, this was a classic recipe for prolonged, strong south winds across the Central Plains. In the mid-upper levels, an expansive, large-scale trough gradually deepened over the western CONUS, only edging slowly eastward. This in turn promoted strengthening surface low pressure across the Central High Plains, averaging around 998 millibars in eastern Colorado. This low pressure, in concert with sprawling high pressure centered over the eastern CONUS, set up a healthy pressure gradient. During the height of the strongest winds on the 29th, the state of Nebraska featured roughly a 16-millibar gradient, ranging from around 1000 millibars in the western Panhandle, to around 1016 millibars in far southeast counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a peak gust of 60 MPH on the east side of Kearney.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Sunday the 29th and Monday the 30th were two of the windiest consecutive days of spring 2018 within South Central Nebraska, especially in terms of SOUTH winds. On both days, primarily the afternoon featured several hours of sustained speeds commonly 25-35 MPH (isolated 40 MPH) and frequent gusts to around 50 MPH, along with isolated severe-criteria gusts of 58+ MPH. Also on both days, the combination of recent dry conditions and recently-tilled fields promoted a number of localized dust storms, causing drastic visibility reductions over short distances. Specifically on the afternoon of the 30th, dust blowing across Interstate 80 led to another multi-vehicle pileup, but this one occurred just east of the local South Central Nebraska area in Seward County, and was not quite as severe as the one the previous day in Hamilton County. Although strong south winds and blowing dust were clearly the main stories on the 30th, the far northern fringe of the local area (northwestern Valley County) was brushed by a line of strong to severe thunderstorms mainly between 9-11 PM CDT, yielding a report of quarter size hail west-southwest of Elyria, along with nearly 3 inches of rain. ||As for measured winds from a variety of official and unofficial sources, some peak gusts on the 30th featured: 60 MPH near Bradshaw (mesonet), 58 MPH near Nelson and Davenport (mesonets), and 57 MPH at Grand Island airport. Like the preceding day, gusts largely eased below 40 MPH after dark. Turning to the meteorological background, this was a classic recipe for prolonged, strong south winds across the Central Plains. In the mid-upper levels, an expansive, large-scale trough gradually deepened over the western CONUS, only edging slowly eastward. This in turn promoted strengthening surface low pressure across the Central High Plains, averaging around 998 millibars in eastern Colorado. This low pressure, in concert with sprawling high pressure centered over the eastern CONUS, set up a healthy pressure gradient. Looking a bit closer at the severe storm that affected Valley County during the evening, this activity evolved eastward from convection that initially formed just west of the local area along a slow-moving cold front. Mesoscale parameters in the area featured mixed-layer CAPE at least 1000 J/kg and deep-layer wind shear around 40 knots.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A mesonet near Bradshaw gusted to 60 MPH.

Specifically on the afternoon of the 30th, dust blowing across Interstate 80 led to another multi-vehicle pileup, but this one occurred just east of the local South Central Nebraska area in Seward County, and was not quite as severe as the one the previous day in Hamilton County. Although strong south winds and blowing dust were clearly the main stories on the 30th, the far northern fringe of the local area (northwestern Valley County) was brushed by a line of strong to severe thunderstorms mainly between 9-11 PM CDT, yielding a report of quarter size hail west-southwest of Elyria, along with nearly 3 inches of rain. ||As for measured winds from a variety of official and unofficial sources, some peak gusts on the 30th featured: 60 MPH near Bradshaw (mesonet), 58 MPH near Nelson and Davenport (mesonets), and 57 MPH at Grand Island airport. Like the preceding day, gusts largely eased below 40 MPH after dark. Turning to the meteorological background, this was a classic recipe for prolonged, strong south winds across the Central Plains. In the mid-upper levels, an expansive, large-scale trough gradually deepened over the western CONUS, only edging slowly eastward. This in turn promoted strengthening surface low pressure across the Central High Plains, averaging around 998 millibars in eastern Colorado. This low pressure, in concert with sprawling high pressure centered over the eastern CONUS, set up a healthy pressure gradient. Looking a bit closer at the severe storm that affected Valley County during the evening, this activity evolved eastward from convection that initially formed just west of the local area along a slow-moving cold front. Mesoscale parameters in the area featured mixed-layer CAPE at least 1000 J/kg and deep-layer wind shear around 40 knots.

A surface low pressure center pushed well into Kansas overnight, and a surge of north winds developed in its wake. The pressure gradient tightened as a result of high pressure over the High Plains of western Nebraska and Kansas with 3-hr pressure rises on the order of 10-12 millibars. Behind the associated cold front, intense cold advection occurred from the surface through about 825mb, and this layer became well-mixed.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The wind was observed at the Sublette airport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A winter storm produced blizzard conditions across western and north central Nebraska. Snow developed and winds intensified Friday morning, in the panhandle and western Sandhills, then spread east through the evening and overnight hours, where the snow was mixed with sleet at times. On Friday, thunderstorms developed with dime sized hail being reported in Holt county.  The blizzard conditions continued Saturday morning, with conditions improving Saturday afternoon, as the snow and winds diminished. The heaviest snow occurred from the eastern panhandle into west central and north central Nebraska. These areas received 6 to 10 inches, with locally higher amounts of 12 to 14 inches. Strong northwest winds increased to 30 to 40 mph with gusts from 50 to 60 mph at times, beginning Friday afternoon and continuing Friday night into Saturday morning. This created blizzard conditions and resulted in snow drifts several feet high and multiple highway closures, including Interstate 80.

High winds continued through much of the day once again as the surface to 500mb low moved across northern Kansas into northwest Missouri. Boundary layer mean winds across western Kansas ranged from 40 to 45 knots and 850mb winds were greater than 50 knots through much of Saturday. Wind gusts as high as 68 mph occurred through the mid-afternoon as sustained northwest winds howled at 30 to 40 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The high wind gust was observed at a location 1 ENE of Garden City at 825 AM.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed along a surface front over southern South Dakota during the late afternoon and evening hours of June 8th. The storms merged into a bow-echo complex which tracked southeast through eastern Nebraska during the early-morning hours of June 9th. The thunderstorms produced wind damage and a measured wind gust of 74 mph at the Lincoln Municipal Airport.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An eight inch diameter tree was snapped in half near Sapp Brothers on Cornhusker Highway in northeast Lincoln.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching upper level trough of low pressure, forced a cold front through western and north central Nebraska during the late afternoon and evening hours of April 30th. Thunderstorms initiated along a line from western Frontier county, north northeast into Blaine County. Further development occurred east of this line into the late evening hours. Hail up to the size of golf balls along with thunderstorm wind gusts to 65 MPH were reported.

A strong upper-level storm system tracked from the northern Rockies into northern High Plains with an associated surface low developing east across the Dakotas. Thunderstorms developed during the late afternoon and evening hours from north-central into eastern Nebraska along a trailing cold front with storms organizing into a bow-echo complex which produced numerous severe wind gusts and wind damage over northeast Nebraska, as well as a brief tornado near Madison, NE.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A storm chaser estimated 80 mph winds 3 miles southwest of Columbus.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper-level low tracked from the northern Rockies into the mid Missouri Valley in tandem with a surface low that developed slowly east across Nebraska. Multiple waves of thunderstorms moved through eastern Nebraska during the 24th and 25th with isolated occurrences of damaging winds and severe hail, along with heavy rain that resulted in areas of flooding. Hardest hit were Cuming and Platte Counties where rainfall totals of 6.0 to 6.5 were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Large tree branches broken by damaging winds near 35th and Vine Streets in Lincoln.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong gusty northwest winds developed behind a cold front crossing western |Kansas through the morning as a deepening upper level low began to lift northeast out of the Central Rockies and into the West Central High Plains. Strong cold air advection behind this front developed during the afternoon as 50+ knot 850mb winds mixed down to the surface. Wind speeds of 30 to 40 mph with gusts to 55 to 60 became common.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The wind was observed at the Syracuse airport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A late season hard freeze damaged orchard's produce. Overnight temperatures dropped into the middle and upper 20s for several nights. While no dollar amount is available at this time, it is estimated between 10 to 25 percent of the potential produce may be lost.

The blizzard conditions continued Saturday morning, with conditions improving Saturday afternoon, as the snow and winds diminished. EVENT_NARRATIVE: General public reported 6 to 9 inches of total snowfall by Saturday morning. Moderate to heavy snow developed early Friday afternoon as northwest winds increased to 30 to 40 mph with gusts from 50 to 60 mph, resulting in blizzard conditions. These strong winds and blizzard conditions continued Friday night into early Saturday afternoon, then diminished Saturday afternoon. Highway 92 and 97 became closed. Snow drifts of 3 to 6 feet were common with drifts up to 12 feet reported throughout McPherson County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A winter storm produced blizzard conditions across western and north central Nebraska. Snow developed and winds intensified Friday morning, in the panhandle and western Sandhills, then spread east through the evening and overnight hours, where the snow was mixed with sleet at times. On Friday, thunderstorms developed with dime sized hail being reported in Holt county.  The blizzard conditions continued Saturday morning, with conditions improving Saturday afternoon, as the snow and winds diminished. The heaviest snow occurred from the eastern panhandle into west central and north central Nebraska. These areas received 6 to 10 inches, with locally higher amounts of 12 to 14 inches. Strong northwest winds increased to 30 to 40 mph with gusts from 50 to 60 mph at times, beginning Friday afternoon and continuing Friday night into Saturday morning. This created blizzard conditions and resulted in snow drifts several feet high and multiple highway closures, including Interstate 80.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The 911 Call Center reported blizzard conditions soon after 4 pm CST in Lincoln County. Several vehicles became stranded on Interstate 80, including a semi accident near Maxwell which blocked the Interstate. Total snowfall amounts of 3 to 8 inches were reported by Saturday morning. Moderate to heavy snow developed early Friday afternoon as northwest winds increased to 30 to 40 mph with gusts from 50 to 60 mph, resulting in blizzard conditions. These strong winds and blizzard conditions continued Friday night into early Saturday afternoon, then diminished Saturday afternoon. Interstate 80 and other area roads became closed or very difficult to travel by late Friday afternoon and Friday night. Snow drifts of 2 to 4 feet were reported throughout Lincoln County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching upper level trough of low pressure, forced a cold front through western and north central Nebraska during the late afternoon and evening hours of April 30th. Thunderstorms initiated along a line from western Frontier county, north northeast into Blaine County. Further development occurred east of this line into the late evening hours. Hail up to the size of golf balls along with thunderstorm wind gusts to 65 MPH were reported.

A strong upper-level storm system tracked from the northern Rockies into northern High Plains with an associated surface low developing east across the Dakotas. Thunderstorms developed during the late afternoon and evening hours from north-central into eastern Nebraska along a trailing cold front with storms organizing into a bow-echo complex which produced numerous severe wind gusts and wind damage over northeast Nebraska, as well as a brief tornado near Madison, NE.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Large tree limbs and power lines blown down in and around West Point.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper-level storm system tracked from the northern Rockies into northern High Plains with an associated surface low developing east across the Dakotas. Thunderstorms developed during the late afternoon and evening hours from north-central into eastern Nebraska along a trailing cold front with storms organizing into a bow-echo complex which produced numerous severe wind gusts and wind damage over northeast Nebraska, as well as a brief tornado near Madison, NE.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Large tree limbs down.  One tree limb fell on a power line in Fremont.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed along a surface front over southern South Dakota during the late afternoon and evening hours of June 8th. The storms merged into a bow-echo complex which tracked southeast through eastern Nebraska during the early-morning hours of June 9th. The thunderstorms produced wind damage and a measured wind gust of 74 mph at the Lincoln Municipal Airport.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 60 mph wind at Wahoo Airport.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 58 mph wind gust was measured at Fremont Airport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed along a surface front over southern South Dakota during the late afternoon and evening hours of June 8th. EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 62 mph wind gust was measured at Omaha, Eppley Airfield.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High winds continued through much of the day once again as the surface to 500mb low moved across northern Kansas into northwest Missouri. Boundary layer mean winds across western Kansas ranged from 40 to 45 knots and 850mb winds were greater than 50 knots through much of Saturday. Wind gusts as high as 68 mph occurred through the mid-afternoon as sustained northwest winds howled at 30 to 40 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The high wind gust was observed at a location 11 N of Jetmore at 140 PM.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The high wind gust was observed at a location 1 WSW Hugoton at 137 PM.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper level shortwave moved from the northern Rockies into the Northern Plains. This helped push a cold front through the area with very strong northerly winds. Wind gusts as high as 75 mph occurred throughout the day, causing significant blowing dust and wind damage across much of southwestern Kansas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The wind gust was observed at the Syracuse airport at 655 PM.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On the evening of April 13 a large upper level system ejected into the plains and brought scattered thunderstorms to eastern Kansas and western Missouri. A few of these storms became supercells and produced quarter to golf ball sized hail. The largest stone reported this afternoon was 2 inches in the city of Olathe.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This report was received via social media.

Below normal rainfall fell during the month of April. This led to severe drought conditions continuing across most of the area, with extreme drought conditions spreading across most of south central Kansas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Drought conditions worsened during the month of April, 2018. Most of the county climbed into the severe drought category by the end of the month.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper level shortwave moved from the northern Rockies into the Northern Plains. This helped push a cold front through the area with very strong northerly winds. Wind gusts as high as 75 mph occurred throughout the day, causing significant blowing dust and wind damage across much of southwestern Kansas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The wind gust was observed at a location 1 ENE of Scott State Lake at 655 PM.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper-level low tracked from the northern Rockies into the mid Missouri Valley in tandem with a surface low that developed slowly east across Nebraska. Multiple waves of thunderstorms moved through eastern Nebraska during the 24th and 25th with isolated occurrences of damaging winds and severe hail, along with heavy rain that resulted in areas of flooding. Hardest hit were Cuming and Platte Counties where rainfall totals of 6.0 to 6.5 were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees were blown down on 58th and R streets in Lincoln.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On the evening of April 13 a large upper level system ejected into the plains and brought scattered thunderstorms to eastern Kansas and western Missouri. A few of these storms became supercells and produced quarter to golf ball sized hail. The largest stone reported this afternoon was 2 inches in the city of Olathe.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This report was received via social media.

An approaching upper level trough of low pressure, forced a cold front through western and north central Nebraska during the late afternoon and evening hours of April 30th. Thunderstorms initiated along a line from western Frontier county, north northeast into Blaine County. Further development occurred east of this line into the late evening hours. Hail up to the size of golf balls along with thunderstorm wind gusts to 65 MPH were reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper-level storm system tracked from the northern Rockies into northern High Plains with an associated surface low developing east across the Dakotas. Thunderstorms developed during the late afternoon and evening hours from north-central into eastern Nebraska along a trailing cold front with storms organizing into a bow-echo complex which produced numerous severe wind gusts and wind damage over northeast Nebraska, as well as a brief tornado near Madison, NE.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Winds were estimated between 60-65 mph near 38th and Ames Streets in Omaha.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A brief touchdown was reported.

An upper-level low tracked from the northern Rockies into the mid Missouri Valley in tandem with a surface low that developed slowly east across Nebraska. EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rainfall of 4 to 6 1/2 inches caused flash flooding in parts of Platte County. EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed along a surface front over southern South Dakota during the late afternoon and evening hours of June 8th. The storms merged into a bow-echo complex which tracked southeast through eastern Nebraska during the early-morning hours of June 9th. The thunderstorms produced wind damage and a measured wind gust of 74 mph at the Lincoln Municipal Airport.

Thunderstorms developed along a surface front over southern South Dakota during the late afternoon and evening hours of June 8th. The storms merged into a bow-echo complex which tracked southeast through eastern Nebraska during the early-morning hours of June 9th. The thunderstorms produced wind damage and a measured wind gust of 74 mph at the Lincoln Municipal Airport.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An 80 mph wind was measured at a home weather station.  A small tree was snapped in their yard.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak upper-level disturbance tracking through the central Plains triggered an early-day cluster of thunderstorms that intensified rapidly while moving through northeast Nebraska and west-central Iowa. Wind gusts well into the 70-mph range were recorded in Antelope, Madison, and Burt counties with the passage of the storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A two foot diameter ash tree  was blown down and a lot of small and large tree limbs blown down in Petersburg.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak upper-level disturbance tracking through the central Plains triggered an early-day cluster of thunderstorms that intensified rapidly while moving through northeast Nebraska and west-central Iowa. Wind gusts well into the 70-mph range were recorded in Antelope, Madison, and Burt counties with the passage of the storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Large tree limbs were blown off in Newman Grove.  The winds also caused power outages in the town.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A winter storm produced blizzard conditions across western and north central Nebraska. Snow developed and winds intensified Friday morning, in the panhandle and western Sandhills, then spread east through the evening and overnight hours, where the snow was mixed with sleet at times. On Friday, thunderstorms developed with dime sized hail being reported in Holt county.  The blizzard conditions continued Saturday morning, with conditions improving Saturday afternoon, as the snow and winds diminished. The heaviest snow occurred from the eastern panhandle into west central and north central Nebraska. These areas received 6 to 10 inches, with locally higher amounts of 12 to 14 inches. Strong northwest winds increased to 30 to 40 mph with gusts from 50 to 60 mph at times, beginning Friday afternoon and continuing Friday night into Saturday morning. This created blizzard conditions and resulted in snow drifts several feet high and multiple highway closures, including Interstate 80.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A CoCoRaHS observer located in Burwell reported 7 inches of snowfall. Whiteout conditions with zero visibility at times developed by early Friday evening.  Total snowfall amounts of 4 to 7 inches were reported across Garfield County. Moderate to heavy snow developed late Friday afternoon as northwest winds increased to 30 to 40 mph with gusts as high as 50 to 60 mph at times, resulting in blizzard conditions by early evening. These strong winds and blizzard conditions continued Friday night into Saturday afternoon, then diminished Saturday evening. Highway 91 and other area roads became closed or very difficult to travel by Friday  night into Saturday. Snow drifts of 2 to 5 feet were reported throughout Garfield County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A winter storm produced blizzard conditions across western and north central Nebraska. Snow developed and winds intensified Friday morning, in the panhandle and western Sandhills, then spread east through the evening and overnight hours, where the snow was mixed with sleet at times. On Friday, thunderstorms developed with dime sized hail being reported in Holt county.  The blizzard conditions continued Saturday morning, with conditions improving Saturday afternoon, as the snow and winds diminished. The heaviest snow occurred from the eastern panhandle into west central and north central Nebraska. These areas received 6 to 10 inches, with locally higher amounts of 12 to 14 inches. Strong northwest winds increased to 30 to 40 mph with gusts from 50 to 60 mph at times, beginning Friday afternoon and continuing Friday night into Saturday morning. This created blizzard conditions and resulted in snow drifts several feet high and multiple highway closures, including Interstate 80.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: General public reported 3 to 5 inches of snowfall across Wheeler County. Whiteout conditions with zero visibility at times developed by early Friday evening. Moderate to heavy snow developed late Friday afternoon as northwest winds increased to 30 to 40 mph with gusts as high as 50 to 60 mph at times, resulting in blizzard conditions by early evening. These strong winds and blizzard conditions continued Friday night into Saturday afternoon, then diminished Saturday evening. Highway 91 and 281, and other area roads became closed or very difficult to travel by Friday  night into Saturday. Snow drifts of 2 to 5 feet were reported throughout Wheeler County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper-level storm system tracked from the northern Rockies into northern High Plains with an associated surface low developing east across the Dakotas. Thunderstorms developed during the late afternoon and evening hours from north-central into eastern Nebraska along a trailing cold front with storms organizing into a bow-echo complex which produced numerous severe wind gusts and wind damage over northeast Nebraska, as well as a brief tornado near Madison, NE.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees and power lines were blown down in and around Columbus.  Trampolines were blown over, with some of them wrapped around power poles.

Thunderstorms developed during the late afternoon and evening hours from north-central into eastern Nebraska along a trailing cold front with storms organizing into a bow-echo complex which produced numerous severe wind gusts and wind damage over northeast Nebraska, as well as a brief tornado near Madison, NE.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Semi-truck was overturned on US 30 1 1/2 miles east of Duncan.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A late season hard freeze damaged orchard's produce. Overnight temperatures dropped into the middle and upper 20s for several nights. While no dollar amount is available at this time, it is estimated between 10 to 25 percent of the potential produce may be lost.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: One large wildfire moved in from Colorado and went through southwest Stanton county before turning south into Morton county.  Around 4000 acres were reported to be burned with several structures in both counties being lost to the fire.  Another fire burned south of Lakin in Kearny county but no structures were reported to be affected.  About 1500 acres were burned.

Ridging aloft transitioned eastward across the Central Plains giving way to an increasingly diffluent southwest flow aloft across the Western High Plains. Meanwhile, a prevailing southerly flow at the surface increased low level moisture across central and much of western Kansas. This increased instability with SBCAPE values pushing upward of 1000 J/kg ahead of a strengthening lee side trough in extreme eastern Colorado contributed to an unstable atmosphere. As steep low/mid level lapse rates developed by mid to late afternoon, a few isolated thunderstorms developed off a sharpening dryline near the Colorado border as H5 vort maxima lifted out of the Southern Rockies into the high plains. Weak flow aloft and marginal shear hindered severe potential.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The ground was covered by the hail.

An intense weather system moved very slowly through the mid Missouri Valley, contributing to the development of  widespread thunderstorms that produced heavy rainfall during the early-morning hours. The heaviest rainfall occurred over Jefferson County where 6 to 8 amounts resulted in considerable flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Gravel roads in  and around Reynolds impassable as they were covered by water. Some bridges were covered with water.  4 to 8 1/2 inches of rain fell across the area west of Fairbury and around Reynolds that caused flash flooding.

The heaviest rainfall occurred over Jefferson County where 6 to 8 amounts resulted in considerable flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms dropped 1 1/2 to 2 1/4 inches of rain over western Douglas County on the night of the 19th that caused water to go over Nebraska Highway 64 near Waterloo. |This caused the highway to be closed.

The heaviest rainfall occurred over Jefferson County where 6 to 8 amounts resulted in considerable flooding.

An upper-level low tracked from the northern Rockies into the mid Missouri Valley in tandem with a surface low that developed slowly east across Nebraska. Multiple waves of thunderstorms moved through eastern Nebraska during the 24th and 25th with isolated occurrences of damaging winds and severe hail, along with heavy rain that resulted in areas of flooding. Hardest hit were Cuming and Platte Counties where rainfall totals of 6.0 to 6.5 were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms producing 4 to 5 inch rainfall across Thurston County caused flash flooding near Pender.  Nebraska highways 94, 9, and 16 were all under water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A peak wind gust of 60 MPH was measured at the McCook airport during the afternoon.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Large tree limbs down north of Wayne.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed along a surface front over southern South Dakota during the late afternoon and evening hours of June 8th. The storms merged into a bow-echo complex which tracked southeast through eastern Nebraska during the early-morning hours of June 9th. The thunderstorms produced wind damage and a measured wind gust of 74 mph at the Lincoln Municipal Airport.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A large tree was blown down 3 miles south of Rising City.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Below normal rainfall fell during the month of April. This led to severe drought conditions continuing across most of the area, with extreme drought conditions spreading across most of south central Kansas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Drought conditions worsened during the month of April, 2018. By the end of the month the county had climbed into the extreme drought category.

A strong upper level shortwave moved from the northern Rockies into the Northern Plains. This helped push a cold front through the area with very strong northerly winds. Wind gusts as high as 75 mph occurred throughout the day, causing significant blowing dust and wind damage across much of southwestern Kansas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The wind gust was observed at the Medicine Lodge airport at 12:02 AM CDT.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Similar to the day before, an upper level shortwave trough lifted northeast across the Central Rockies resulting in an increasingly diffluent southwest flow aloft across the Western High Plains. Meanwhile, a prevailing southerly flow continued to draw  moisture into central and much of western Kansas ahead of an approaching dryline pushing surface dew points well up into the 50s(F). Increased instability with SBCAPE values upward of 1500 to 2000 J/kg and a modest +60kt upper level jet set the stage for a few isolated thunderstorms ahead of the dryline.

A weak upper-level disturbance tracking through the central Plains triggered an early-day cluster of thunderstorms that intensified rapidly while moving through northeast Nebraska and west-central Iowa. Wind gusts well into the 70-mph range were recorded in Antelope, Madison, and Burt counties with the passage of the storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Empty grain bins were blown over by damaging winds 7 miles north of Madison.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak upper-level disturbance tracking through the central Plains triggered an early-day cluster of thunderstorms that intensified rapidly while moving through northeast Nebraska and west-central Iowa. Wind gusts well into the 70-mph range were recorded in Antelope, Madison, and Burt counties with the passage of the storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees were snapped and one tree was uprooted 6 miles north of Clarkson.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High winds during the morning and into the afternoon caused pockets of blowing dust to occur along a stationary front.  The GOES satellite detected the blowing dust.  However due to the sparce population, only one of the blowing dust pockets was confirmed.  The highest wind gust was 72 MPH measured near Weskan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The peak wind gust was measured near Weskan.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Snow developed over southeast Nebraska early on April 1st.  Moderate to heavy snow occurred in an east west band from a line south of Lincoln to Nebraska City.  Snowfall totals ranged from 5 to 9 inches across southeast Nebraska.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A total  of 5.5 inches of snow of snow fell at Friend.  Other reports in Saline County included 6 inches at Wilber, 7.1 inches at Western, 7.5 inches at Swanton, and 9.1 inches  at Tobias.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Behind a cold front, high winds on the backside of a weak upper level disturbance reached the ground in a few counties. In Sherman County, the peak gust was 61 MPH at Goodland. Wallace and Gove counties also experienced high winds.||To the east ahead of the cold front, a line of strong to severe thunderstorms was moving east across Decatur, Norton, and Graham counties.  These storms produced large hail and severe wind gusts.  The largest hail size reported was golf ball at Norton, and the highest wind gust was 63 MPH at Hill City.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The hail ranged from pea to quarter in size.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front brought high winds and blowing dust to Southwest Nebraska. The high winds led to some wind damage across the area. In addition, the winds caused zero visibility in the widespread blowing dust.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency manager reported River Road east of Parks was closed due to downed trees. Wind gust to 74 mph was reported at 4:42 pm MST in Benkelman.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A winter storm system produced 1 to 4.5 inches of snow across northeast Nebraska starting early in the morning of April 3rd.  South of the light snow was freezing drizzle.  The snowfall eventually spread southeast into east central Nebraska during the day.  Snowfall totals were between 1 inch in Pender, NE  and Little Sioux, IA to over 4 inches in Knox County, NE  at Verdel and Bloomfield.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy snowfall occurred in Knox County .  Cooperative observers reported 4.1 inches at Bloomfield and 4.5 inches  6 miles south southeast of Verdel.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Snow overspread the state as a short wave trough lifted out of the southern Rockies. There was a moderate amount of blowing and drifting of the snow.  In general amounts were less than three inches.  However, there was a heavier band that stretch from near Ulysses to near Scott City where 4 to 5.5 inches were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow amounts ranged from 1 to 3 inches across the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The first significant snowfall of the 2018/2019 winter season arrived on Thursday, November 8th, when a fast moving upper disturbance combined with unseasonably cold temperatures. Locations generally north of Highway 400 saw most of the snow with some locations picking up around 5 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: One to three inches of wet snow fell across Harvey county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front brought high winds and blowing dust to Southwest Nebraska. The high winds led to some wind damage across the area. In addition, the winds caused zero visibility in the widespread blowing dust.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Peak winds 3 WNW Trenton.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front brought high winds, blowing dust, and a wildfire to Northwest Kansas. The high winds led to some wind damage across the area. In addition, the winds caused widespread blowing dust with zero visibility, which resulted in at least 2 accidents on area roadways. Finally, as the winds brought down power lines in Weskan, a wildfire began and rapidly spread.  The fire was so large that fire departments from neighboring counties were asked to respond.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several reports of dust storm with less than quarter mile visibility reported across Cheyenne County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front brought high winds, blowing dust, and a wildfire to Northwest Kansas. The high winds led to some wind damage across the area. In addition, the winds caused widespread blowing dust with zero visibility, which resulted in at least 2 accidents on area roadways. Finally, as the winds brought down power lines in Weskan, a wildfire began and rapidly spread.  The fire was so large that fire departments from neighboring counties were asked to respond.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wildfire started just north of the town of Weskan. Cause was power lines snapped due to high winds with the cold front. Fire ran 7 miles to the southeast and reached approximately three quarters of a mile wide at times. Fire was detected by GOES-16 imagery as well as radar. At least two structures were lost along with numerous power poles. Damage to railroad and railroad bridge also noticed by NWS Employee passing through a few days later.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Report of widespread blowing dust in Winona and Russell Springs, zero miles visibility in blowing dust, sand, and gravel.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A couple severe thunderstorms developed and moved across Northwest Kansas during the afternoon and evening.  The largest hailstone reported was hen egg size in Goodland.  The highest wind gust occurred at both Horace and Hill City of 58 MPH.  One was produced by a thunderstorm and the other from high winds above ground being directed to the ground.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The hail ranged from quarter to ping-pong ball size.

Below normal rainfall fell during the month of April. This led to severe drought conditions continuing across most of the area, with extreme drought conditions spreading across most of south central Kansas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Drought conditions continued during the month of April, 2018. Most of the county remained in the severe drought category.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A winter storm system produced 1 to 4.5 inches of snow across northeast Nebraska starting early in the morning of April 3rd.  South of the light snow was freezing drizzle.  The snowfall eventually spread southeast into east central Nebraska during the day.  Snowfall totals were between 1 inch in Pender, NE  and Little Sioux, IA to over 4 inches in Knox County, NE  at Verdel and Bloomfield.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An observer in Wayne, NE reported 2 inches of snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system moved from Wyoming across Nebraska to northwest Missouri and produced snow across northeast Nebraska and Southwest Iowa.  Snowfall ranged from  1.5 inches near Wakefield, NE, in Wayne County  to 7.8 inches near Verdel, NE in Knox County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Between 2 to 5 inches of snow fell across Antelope County.  Totals included 2.5 inches at Elgin, 3.5 inches at Oakdale, and 5 inches at Neligh.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Between 2 and 6 inches of snow fell across Pierce County.  Snowfall totals included 6.5 inches 6 miles south southeast of Plainview and 3.8 inches at Pierce.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: An observer at Wayne reported 2 inches of snow.  Wayne County received 2 to 3 inches of snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Snow overspread the state as a short wave trough lifted out of the southern Rockies. There was a moderate amount of blowing and drifting of the snow.  In general amounts were less than three inches.  However, there was a heavier band that stretch from near Ulysses to near Scott City where 4 to 5.5 inches were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow amounts ranged from 1.5 to 2.5 inches across the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong winter storm system created blizzard conditions across part of Northwest Kansas.  The blizzard conditions caused some area highways to be closed.  Up to five inches of snow was reported with the winter storm system.  South of the snow, high winds were reported in some of the counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Zero visibility reported along Highway 36 across the county.  Snowfall amounts ranged from three to five inches across the county.  Highway 27 was closed from Wheeler to the Nebraska border, and Highway 36 was closed from St. Francis west into Yuma County.

Up to five inches of snow was reported with the winter storm system.  South of the snow, high winds were reported in some of the counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Near zero visibility was reported at the weather office.  A peak gust of 63 MPH was measured at the Goodland airport at 5:53 MDT and 11:53 MDT.  Around three inches of snow was reported across the county.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Near zero visibility reported in the southern part of the county.  Around 4 inches of snow was reported across the county.   Power flickers were reported in Atwood during the blizzard.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The first significant snowfall of the 2018/2019 winter season arrived on Thursday, November 8th, when a fast moving upper disturbance combined with unseasonably cold temperatures. Locations generally north of Highway 400 saw most of the snow with some locations picking up around 5 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three to five inches of snow fell across portions of McPherson county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered snow showers began moving east across Southwest Nebraska in the morning. There were several different waves of snow showers from the morning until after midnight. The repeated rounds of snow from these showers yielded snowfall amounts close to a foot across the east half of Dundy County into the west half of Hitchcock County. The highest snowfall amount of 12 was reported in Stratton. The band of higher snowfall amounts extended northeast into northwestern Red Willow County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The highest snowfall amount of 11 was reported at two different locations, a few miles north of Parks and a few miles north of Benkelman.  Snowfall amounts declined to the west.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered snow showers began moving east across Southwest Nebraska in the morning. There were several different waves of snow showers from the morning until after midnight. The repeated rounds of snow from these showers yielded snowfall amounts close to a foot across the east half of Dundy County into the west half of Hitchcock County. The highest snowfall amount of 12 was reported in Stratton. The band of higher snowfall amounts extended northeast into northwestern Red Willow County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The highest snowfall amount was 12 in Stratton.  Eight inches of snow was reported in Culbertson.  The snowfall amounts declined to the southeast to around three inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered snow showers began moving east across Southwest Nebraska in the morning. There were several different waves of snow showers from the morning until after midnight. The repeated rounds of snow from these showers yielded snowfall amounts close to a foot across the east half of Dundy County into the west half of Hitchcock County. The highest snowfall amount of 12 was reported in Stratton. The band of higher snowfall amounts extended northeast into northwestern Red Willow County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The highest snowfall amount of 7.5 was reported in Bartley, although similar snowfall amounts may have fallen in the northwest corner of the county too.  Four and a half inches was reported in McCook.  Snowfall amounts declined to the south, with just over an inch reported in northern Decatur County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered snow showers began moving east across far Northwest Kansas in the morning. There were several different waves of snow showers from the morning until after midnight. The repeated rounds of snow from these showers yielded snowfall amounts of atleast five inches. The highest snowfall amount of 5.3 was reported north of St. Francis. The highest snowfall amounts occurred over the northwest part of the county, with amounts declining to the southeast.  The icy roadway north of St. Francis impeded traffic for a brief time in the afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At approximately 13:15 local time seven semis were unable to climb a hill on Highway 27 near CR R.  This caused a total of twelve semis to be stopped on the highway at that location.  Local farmers had to tow the semis up the hill with tractors in order for traffic to flow again.  Five inches of snow had fallen when this occurred.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong winter storm system created blizzard conditions across part of Northwest Kansas.  The blizzard conditions caused some area highways to be closed.  Up to five inches of snow was reported with the winter storm system.  South of the snow, high winds were reported in some of the counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Salina Journal reported a teenage driver became stranded in the winter storm due to zero visibility.  The sheriff was able to rescue the teenager during the storm.  Based on radar and surface observations, blizzard conditions were intermittent across the county which did not allow for a consecutive three hours of blizzard conditions to occur.  Around three inches of snow fell across the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A mini squall line move across portions of the Flint Hills on the 13th producing a couple of severe weather events.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Fifty percent of the ground was covered at Highway 160.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front and weak upper level shortwave moved across parts of the area during the early morning.  While there was only 1 to 3 inches of snow, winds were in excess of 60 MPH with gusts to 70 MPH which caused blizzard conditions during the morning hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The visibility dropped to less than 1/4 of a mile and occasionally to zero for about 4 hours as snow and high winds swept through the area.  Snowfall was 1 to 3 inches.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The visibility dropped to less than 1/4 of a mile and occasionally to zero for about 4 hours as snow and high winds swept through the area.  Snowfall was 1 to 3 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong winter storm system created blizzard conditions across part of Northwest Kansas.  The blizzard conditions caused some area highways to be closed.  Up to five inches of snow was reported with the winter storm system.  South of the snow, high winds were reported in some of the counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two narrow bands of heavy snow moved over the county, one of the east and one over the west.  Each had blizzard conditions reported under them prior to the bands entering the county.  The near blizzard conditions lasted an hour and a half to two hours.  Around an inch of snow was reported across the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong winter storm system created blizzard conditions across part of Northwest Kansas.  The blizzard conditions caused some area highways to be closed.  Up to five inches of snow was reported with the winter storm system.  South of the snow, high winds were reported in some of the counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two high wind gusts were measured during this time frame near Horace, one at the beginning and one at the end.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The peak wind gust was measured near Colby, but several locations in the county were gusting close to the same speed.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The peak gust was measured at the Oakley airport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front brought high winds, blowing dust, and a wildfire to Northwest Kansas. The high winds led to some wind damage across the area. In addition, the winds caused widespread blowing dust with zero visibility, which resulted in at least 2 accidents on area roadways. Finally, as the winds brought down power lines in Weskan, a wildfire began and rapidly spread.  The fire was so large that fire departments from neighboring counties were asked to respond.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts to 77 mph across Sherman County, peak reported at KGLD at 3:28 pm MST. Observations at ASOS in Goodland, mesonet in Ruleton, 8 miles northeast of Goodland. A few downed trees and powerlines reported by dispatch in Goodland.

Finally, as the winds brought down power lines in Weskan, a wildfire began and rapidly spread.  The fire was so large that fire departments from neighboring counties were asked to respond.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Second instance of high winds recorded at Goodland Municipal Airport. Peak reported at 8:29 pm MST.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front brought high winds, blowing dust, and a wildfire to Northwest Kansas. The high winds led to some wind damage across the area. EVENT_NARRATIVE: Fifty yard visibility reported at Monument Rocks relayed via social media. Visibility less than one quarter mile due to blowing dust in Grinnell. Dust storm visible on KDOT cameras on I-70 just east of Grainfield and 2 miles east of Grainfield. Social media report of quarter mile visibility in Quinter. At least one accident involving two vehicles occurred on I-70 near Grainfield due to the blowing dust.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts up to 65 mph in Gove County. Peak was 10 miles south of Gove at 6:44 pm CST. Shingles blown off and 1 inch tree limbs broken in Grainfield. Report of a building collapse in Grainfield.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dust storm moved across Thomas county with several reports of near zero visibility. One accident occurred on HWY 24 five miles east of Colby. 3 vehicles involved with at least 5 injuries.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: While the vast majority of April was quiet in the severe weather department, April 13th wasn't short on severe weather reports. Scattered thunderstorms produced numerous reports of large hail across northeast Kansas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mostly dime size hail with a few quarter size.

Snow overspread the state as a short wave trough lifted out of the southern Rockies. There was a moderate amount of blowing and drifting of the snow.  In general amounts were less than three inches.  However, there was a heavier band that stretch from near Ulysses to near Scott City where 4 to 5.5 inches were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow amounts ranged from 1.5 to 3 inches across the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong winter storm system produced blizzard conditions across Southwest Nebraska.  The blizzard conditions caused highways to be closed.  The highest wind gust reported was 60 MPH at McCook.  The highest snowfall amount reported was 5 inches in Red Willow County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: All highways across the county are closed due to whiteout conditions.  A peak wind gust of 60 MPH was reported at the McCook airport 10:37 PM CDT.  Snow amounts ranged from two to five inches across the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Snow is not usually associated with Easter, but this Sunday looked and felt a lot more like winter than early spring across South Central Nebraska...albeit more so in some places than others. While most of the 24-county area received at least a dusting up to a few inches, a fairly narrow, roughly 15-25 mile wide corridor accumulated markedly higher amounts ranging generally 4-11. The heart of this band was oriented west-northwest to east-southeast, centered roughly along a line from Elwood-Minden-Blue Hill-Bruning. According to reports from a variety of official and unofficial sources, some of the highest totals concentrated near the Fillmore-Thayer County line, featuring: 11.0 at Carleton, 10.8 near Belvidere and 9.5 near Shickley. Totals from a few larger towns in and near this main band included: 8 in Minden and 6 in Holdrege, Blue Hill and Clay Center. Lower amounts within the northern and southern fringes of the band included: 5.1 at NWS Hastings, 3.8 at Kearney and 3.4 in Hebron. Despite fairly hefty snow amounts in some spots, this event was relatively low impact, with little-to-no blowing and drifting thanks to winds averaging 10 MPH-or-less. However, slick roads did contribute to a single-fatality traffic accident on the northeast side of Grand Island. ||As for timing, the majority of snow accumulated during the pre-dawn hours, starting in western counties around midnight and steadily spreading east within a few hours. After daybreak, mainly light snow hung on several more hours, ending in the west generally between 10 AM-noon CDT, and vacating far southeast areas around Hebron by 2 PM CDT. Turning to the meteorology behind this Easter event, this was a fairly textbook case of pronounced mid-level frontogenesis migrating across the Central Plains in broad west-northwest flow, especially evident around 700 millibars. At the surface, a sharp cold front had passed through on March 31st, ushering in an unseasonably-cold airmass. By the time snow broke out, a strong high pressure system (nearly 1030 millibars) settled into the region, keeping winds light. Although not record-breaking, high temperatures on the 1st averaged around 30 degrees below normal, with most of South Central Nebraska only topping out a few degrees either side of 30 F.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A public report of 4.0 inches of snow was reported from Gothenburg. A cooperative observer measured a snowfall total of 3.3 inches in Cozad.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A snowfall total of 9.5 inches occurred 4 miles south of Shickley. Also, 5.0 inches fell in Geneva, both reported by cooperative observers. A public report of 8.0 inches occurred in Shickley.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A surface low pressure center pushed well into Kansas overnight, and a surge of north winds developed in its wake. The pressure gradient tightened as a result of high pressure over the High Plains of western Nebraska and Kansas with 3-hr pressure rises on the order of 10-12 millibars. Behind the associated cold front, intense cold advection occurred from the surface through about 825mb, and this layer became well-mixed.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The wind was observed at a location 1 ENE Garden City.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High winds continued through much of the day once again as the surface to 500mb low moved across northern Kansas into northwest Missouri. Boundary layer mean winds across western Kansas ranged from 40 to 45 knots and 850mb winds were greater than 50 knots through much of Saturday. Wind gusts as high as 68 mph occurred through the mid-afternoon as sustained northwest winds howled at 30 to 40 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The high wind gust was observed at a location 4 SSW Kismet at 935 AM.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wildfire developed between Hugoton and Moscow as the result of a cotton gin fire that got out of control.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The fire did not consume any structures.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: While the vast majority of April was quiet in the severe weather department, April 13th wasn't short on severe weather reports. Scattered thunderstorms produced numerous reports of large hail across northeast Kansas.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front and weak upper level shortwave moved across parts of the area during the early morning.  While there was only 1 to 3 inches of snow, winds were in excess of 60 MPH with gusts to 70 MPH which caused blizzard conditions during the morning hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Sunday the 29th and Monday the 30th were two of the windiest consecutive days of spring 2018 within South Central Nebraska, especially in terms of SOUTH winds. On both days, primarily the afternoon featured several hours of sustained speeds commonly 25-35 MPH (isolated 40 MPH) and frequent gusts to around 50 MPH, along with isolated severe-criteria gusts of 58+ MPH. Also on both days, the combination of recent dry conditions and recently-tilled fields promoted a number of localized dust storms, causing drastic visibility reductions over short distances. Specifically on the late afternoon of the 29th, dust blowing across Interstate 80 near the Aurora exit led to a major pileup of 29 vehicles, closing I-80 for over two hours. Sadly, this incident resulted in one fatality and over a dozen injuries. ||As for measured winds from a variety of official and unofficial sources, a few peak gusts on the 29th featured: 62 MPH near Kearney (mesonet), 59 MPH near Oxford (mesonet), and 58 MPH at Grand Island and Ord airports. At Kearney Regional Airport, sustained winds averaged 40 MPH for an hour, mainly between 12-1 PM CDT. Although it remained quite breezy even after dark, gusts by late evening largely eased below 40 MPH. Turning to the meteorological background, this was a classic recipe for prolonged, strong south winds across the Central Plains. In the mid-upper levels, an expansive, large-scale trough gradually deepened over the western CONUS, only edging slowly eastward. This in turn promoted strengthening surface low pressure across the Central High Plains, averaging around 998 millibars in eastern Colorado. This low pressure, in concert with sprawling high pressure centered over the eastern CONUS, set up a healthy pressure gradient. During the height of the strongest winds on the 29th, the state of Nebraska featured roughly a 16-millibar gradient, ranging from around 1000 millibars in the western Panhandle, to around 1016 millibars in far southeast counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A mesonet station just east-southeast of Kearney measured a 62 MPH gust.

Also on both days, the combination of recent dry conditions and recently-tilled fields promoted a number of localized dust storms, causing drastic visibility reductions over short distances. Specifically on the late afternoon of the 29th, dust blowing across Interstate 80 near the Aurora exit led to a major pileup of 29 vehicles, closing I-80 for over two hours. Sadly, this incident resulted in one fatality and over a dozen injuries. ||As for measured winds from a variety of official and unofficial sources, a few peak gusts on the 29th featured: 62 MPH near Kearney (mesonet), 59 MPH near Oxford (mesonet), and 58 MPH at Grand Island and Ord airports. At Kearney Regional Airport, sustained winds averaged 40 MPH for an hour, mainly between 12-1 PM CDT. Although it remained quite breezy even after dark, gusts by late evening largely eased below 40 MPH. Turning to the meteorological background, this was a classic recipe for prolonged, strong south winds across the Central Plains. In the mid-upper levels, an expansive, large-scale trough gradually deepened over the western CONUS, only edging slowly eastward. This in turn promoted strengthening surface low pressure across the Central High Plains, averaging around 998 millibars in eastern Colorado. This low pressure, in concert with sprawling high pressure centered over the eastern CONUS, set up a healthy pressure gradient. During the height of the strongest winds on the 29th, the state of Nebraska featured roughly a 16-millibar gradient, ranging from around 1000 millibars in the western Panhandle, to around 1016 millibars in far southeast counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This was the third and final peak gust of 58 MPH at Central Nebraska Regional Airport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper level shortwave moved from the northern Rockies into the Northern Plains. This helped push a cold front through the area with very strong northerly winds. Wind gusts as high as 75 mph occurred throughout the day, causing significant blowing dust and wind damage across much of southwestern Kansas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A pivot irrigation sprinkler was turned over by the high wind at a location 5 S Ingalls.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper level shortwave moved from the northern Rockies into the Northern Plains. This helped push a cold front through the area with very strong northerly winds. EVENT_NARRATIVE: A semi truck was overturned by the high wind on highway 50 3 ENE of Offerle at 1024 PM.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The wind gust was observed at the Elkhart airport at 500 PM.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed along a surface front over southern South Dakota during the late afternoon and evening hours of June 8th. The storms merged into a bow-echo complex which tracked southeast through eastern Nebraska during the early-morning hours of June 9th. The thunderstorms produced wind damage and a measured wind gust of 74 mph at the Lincoln Municipal Airport.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A person estimated 70 mph winds 5 miles south southeast of Creston.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed along a surface front over southern South Dakota during the late afternoon and evening hours of June 8th. The storms merged into a bow-echo complex which tracked southeast through eastern Nebraska during the early-morning hours of June 9th. EVENT_NARRATIVE: A person estimated 60 mph winds with pea size hail in Falls City.

A weak upper-level disturbance tracking through the central Plains triggered an early-day cluster of thunderstorms that intensified rapidly while moving through northeast Nebraska and west-central Iowa. Wind gusts well into the 70-mph range were recorded in Antelope, Madison, and Burt counties with the passage of the storms.

A weak upper-level disturbance tracking through the central Plains triggered an early-day cluster of thunderstorms that intensified rapidly while moving through northeast Nebraska and west-central Iowa. Wind gusts well into the 70-mph range were recorded in Antelope, Madison, and Burt counties with the passage of the storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several large branches snapped off trees and corn flattened by damaging winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the evening the group of thunderstorms from East Central Colorado moved into Northwest Kansas behind a cold front.  As the thunderstorms moved into Kansas they become an organized thunderstorm complex, turning into more of a wind threat than a hail threat.  Peak wind gusts from this event were estimated at 100 MPH from damage in Hoxie and in far southern Cheyenne County.  As this complex moved east, another area of prolonged thunderstorm activity behind the cold front was occurring over Graham County where several hours of heavy rainfall had occurred.  The many hours of prolonged rainfall added up to between four and six inches of rain for the northern half of Graham County, which lead to flash flooding in Hill City.  The largest hail size reported was golf ball at two different locations.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The flood waters moved into Hill City from the north, overwhelming the drainage tunnels under the town.  Water was deep enough in town to move into businesses. |Residents in the trailer park on the south side of town had to evacuate.  Two different families had to be water rescued due to their resistance to leave despite flood waters surrounding their home in both instances.  One trailer house was carried away by the flood waters.  A house in town, located near where the drainage tunnels empty, was engulfed with flood waters.  The city park and playground equipment, where the drainage for town empties, was almost completely submerged in water.  Over six inches of rainfall was measured in town.

As this complex moved east, another area of prolonged thunderstorm activity behind the cold front was occurring over Graham County where several hours of heavy rainfall had occurred. The largest hail size reported was golf ball at two different locations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The bridge west of Nicodemus was flooded.  No damage was reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Early in the afternoon scattered thunderstorms developed north of a warm front.  Penny size hail was reported from one of these storms.  During the latter half of the afternoon a thunderstorm complex moved east out of Colorado into Northwest Kansas.  The complex continued to increase in coverage as it moved eastward, transitioning into more of a wind threat than a hail threat.  Winds from the thunderstorm complex blew trees down, some of them being large trees, blew power lines down, and damaged a grain bin.  There were very few hail reports with this thunderstorm complex, with the largest being only penny size from several locations.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the afternoon storm activity from East Central Colorado spread into Northwest Kansas.  The storm intensity increased as the storms moved into Kansas, but turned into more of a wind threat than a hail threat.  The peak wind gust reported was 77 MPH measured at the Bird City airport.  The thunderstorms winds blew down power lines north of Blakeman in Rawlins County, and were responsible for blowing dust at a couple locations.  The largest hail size reported was nickel near Weskan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Brownout conditions reported due to the blowing dust.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the afternoon storm activity from East Central Colorado spread into Northwest Kansas.  The storm intensity increased as the storms moved into Kansas, but turned into more of a wind threat than a hail threat.  The peak wind gust reported was 77 MPH measured at the Bird City airport.  The thunderstorms winds blew down power lines north of Blakeman in Rawlins County, and were responsible for blowing dust at a couple locations.  The largest hail size reported was nickel near Weskan.

During the afternoon and through the evening two groups of thunderstorms progressed across Northwest Kansas.  One group crossed into Kansas from Colorado behind a cold front, while the second group moved north across the forecast area east of the front, expanding in coverage.  The storm activity moving in from Colorado was responsible for most of the thunderstorm wind gust reports. One storm that moved across Cheyenne County Kansas produced significant straight-line wind and wind-driven hail damage. A swath of crops between 5 and 10 miles wide was completely destroyed.  Straight-line winds blew down large cotton wood trees in Sherman County.  In addition there were multiple reports of thunderstorm wind gusts above 70 MPH, with a peak gust (estimated) of 90 MPH west of St. Francis.  The largest hail reported was apple size in Oakley.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Also had 0.80 of rainfall.

One storm that moved across Cheyenne County Kansas produced significant straight-line wind and wind-driven hail damage. A swath of crops between 5 and 10 miles wide was completely destroyed.  Straight-line winds blew down large cotton wood trees in Sherman County.  In addition there were multiple reports of thunderstorm wind gusts above 70 MPH, with a peak gust (estimated) of 90 MPH west of St. Francis.  The largest hail reported was apple size in Oakley.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The severe weather from Colorado spread north into Nebraska as the storms themselves moved eastward.  A peak gust of 71 MPH was reported at the McCook airport.  A large tree in Indianola was blown down from this same line of thunderstorm winds.
During the evening winds ahead of an approaching thunderstorm produced blowing dust, reducing the visibility to three or four miles west of Goodland.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Winds ahead of the thunderstorm caused blowing dust to reduce the visibility to three or four miles.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A well-built barn was blown over by significant straight-line winds. Other structures nearby were damaged as well...including barn doors blown away, shingles blown off, and metal roofing blown up to a quarter mile away.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of storms move east across the southern sections of Kansas producing large hail, very strong winds, and heavy rains.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: No damage was reported at this location.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High winds during the morning and into the afternoon caused pockets of blowing dust to occur along a stationary front.  The GOES satellite detected the blowing dust.  However due to the sparce population, only one of the blowing dust pockets was confirmed.  The highest wind gust was 72 MPH measured near Weskan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The peak wind gust was measured near Colby.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High winds during the morning and into the afternoon caused pockets of blowing dust to occur along a stationary front.  The GOES satellite detected the blowing dust.  However due to the sparce population, only one of the blowing dust pockets was confirmed.  The highest wind gust was 72 MPH measured near Weskan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Peak wind speed was measured at the Goodland airport.  The high winds also created blowing dust, but visibility was above a quarter mile in the blowing dust. Law enforcement reported a trailer pulled by a truck was blown over at exit 12 on I-70 near Caruso.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong winter storm system created blizzard conditions across part of Northwest Kansas.  The blizzard conditions caused some area highways to be closed.  Up to five inches of snow was reported with the winter storm system.  South of the snow, high winds were reported in some of the counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The wind gust was measured near Weskan.  Two high wind gusts were measured, one at the beginning and one at the end of time frame.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong winter storm system created blizzard conditions across part of Northwest Kansas.  The blizzard conditions caused some area highways to be closed.  Up to five inches of snow was reported with the winter storm system.  South of the snow, high winds were reported in some of the counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Blizzard conditions were reported at Ludell in Rawlins County with the same band that was over Decatur County.  Blizzard conditions were later reported in Red Willow County in another band over Decatur County.  There was a reprieve in blizzard conditions after midnight before blizzard conditions were reported near Traer mid morning on the 14th as the winter storm was winding down.  Around an three inches of snow was reported across the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong winter storm system produced blizzard conditions across Southwest Nebraska.  The blizzard conditions caused highways to be closed.  The highest wind gust reported was 60 MPH at McCook.  The highest snowfall amount reported was 5 inches in Red Willow County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Webcam at Haigler showed blizzard conditions.  One to four inches of snow was reported across the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed in two different waves on a southwest to northeast orientated cold front across eastern Nebraska.  In the early morning of the 30th, a wave of thunderstorms moved northeast across northeastern Nebraska.  One of the storms intensified and became severe with large hail over Knox County.  Later in the afternoon,  thunderstorms redeveloped over southeast Nebraska and produced damaging wind and large hail, and between 2 to 3 inches of rain.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Seven miles north of Tobias, doors were ripped off of a shed, and another shed was destroyed with the tin thrown 1/4 mile away from the shed.  A tree was also split from damaging winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the afternoon and through the evening two groups of thunderstorms progressed across Northwest Kansas.  One group crossed into Kansas from Colorado behind a cold front, while the second group moved north across the forecast area east of the front, expanding in coverage.  The storm activity moving in from Colorado was responsible for most of the thunderstorm wind gust reports. One storm that moved across Cheyenne County Kansas produced significant straight-line wind and wind-driven hail damage. A swath of crops between 5 and 10 miles wide was completely destroyed.  Straight-line winds blew down large cotton wood trees in Sherman County.  In addition there were multiple reports of thunderstorm wind gusts above 70 MPH, with a peak gust (estimated) of 90 MPH west of St. Francis.  The largest hail reported was apple size in Oakley.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A large tree was uprooted and was blocking the road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the evening the group of thunderstorms from East Central Colorado moved into Northwest Kansas behind a cold front.  As the thunderstorms moved into Kansas they become an organized thunderstorm complex, turning into more of a wind threat than a hail threat.  Peak wind gusts from this event were estimated at 100 MPH from damage in Hoxie and in far southern Cheyenne County.  As this complex moved east, another area of prolonged thunderstorm activity behind the cold front was occurring over Graham County where several hours of heavy rainfall had occurred.  The many hours of prolonged rainfall added up to between four and six inches of rain for the northern half of Graham County, which lead to flash flooding in Hill City.  The largest hail size reported was golf ball at two different locations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An unknown number of tree were blown down and a shed blew over the house.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Numerous severe thunderstorms struck much of Central and South-Central Kansas with large hail and damaging winds. There were instances when & where the hail was very large, most notably on the south side of McPherson where it reached the size of baseballs. Gusts from 52 to 62 knots were measured in many areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: No damage was reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A complex of storms swept east across most of the region during the afternoon and evening hours of May 2nd, 2018.  As the storms moved east, a combination of large hail and damaging winds moved across the area.  A few tornadoes were also reported along the leading edge of the quasi linear convective system with only brief touchdowns reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement reported the gust.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stationary front was the focus for late afternoon thunderstorms.

A strong winter storm system produced blizzard conditions across Southwest Nebraska.  The blizzard conditions caused highways to be closed.  The highest wind gust reported was 60 MPH at McCook.  The highest snowfall amount reported was 5 inches in Red Willow County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Based on blizzard reports from surrounding counties with the same bands that were over Hitchcock county, blizzard conditions should have occurred over the county.  Between one and four inches of snow likely fell across the county, based on snowfall reports in Dundy and Red Willow counties.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system that produced severe weather across southeast Nebraska on April 13th, strengthened and produced snow across the area on the 13th and 15th.  Snowfall across Antelope, Pierce, Wayne, Cedar and Knox counties ranged from 4 to 8 inches.  In addition high winds caused blizzard conditions across parts of northeast Nebraska.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Winds gusting up to 48 mph created visibilities of 1/4 mile  or less with blowing snow.  Total snowfall in Madison County ranged from 2 to 5 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system that produced severe weather across southeast Nebraska on April 13th, strengthened and produced snow across the area on the 13th and 15th.  Snowfall across Antelope, Pierce, Wayne, Cedar and Knox counties ranged from 4 to 8 inches.  In addition high winds caused blizzard conditions across parts of northeast Nebraska.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous accidents and whiteout conditions were reported on Highway 275 between Pilger and Norfolk.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system that produced severe weather across southeast Nebraska on April 13th, strengthened and produced snow across the area on the 13th and 15th.  Snowfall across Antelope, Pierce, Wayne, Cedar and Knox counties ranged from 4 to 8 inches.  In addition high winds caused blizzard conditions across parts of northeast Nebraska.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong winds up to 50 mph combined with 8 inches of snow reported at Neligh created blizzard conditions midday on the 14th.  Visibility in Antelope County was reported to be down to a few feet.  Drifts of snow  up to 3 to 4 feet were reported in rural areas of Antelope County. Power poles were snapped in some areas due to stress from icing of the lines.  Two accidents were reported in the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving thunderstorm developed over Wallace County and produced a wind gust of 70 MPH near Weskan.  The thunderstorm remained over Wallace County into the evening.  The prolonged heavy rainfall led to flash flooding occurring.  Many roads around Weskan had water flow over them, including Highway 40.  Over five inches of rain fell in the Weskan area.||To the north quarter size hail was reported from a thunderstorm near the Cheyenne/Sherman county line.

During the early evening a slow moving thunderstorm over eastern Gove County produced wind gusts strong enough to move a spare tire.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spare tire was moved 20-30 feet by the thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Early morning hours of August 31 brought some large hail to portions of extreme northeast Kansas. 1-1.75 hail fell in Atchison and Doniphan Counties.
