EVENT_NARRATIVE: This brief EF-1 tornado occurred in northwest York County, causing damage approximately 7 miles north of Bradshaw. A home was damaged, mainly to soffits and garage doors, and there was also some roof damage. Grain bins were damaged along with several trees. Some larger cedar trees were snapped 2-3 feet above ground. Two irrigation pivots were damaged along the path. Peak winds were estimated to be 90 MPH.||This tornado was associated with a supercell and a much larger scale wind and hail event in the region. There were numerous irrigation pivots overturned or damaged, and crop damage was widespread, especially around and just to the east of the tornado path. Some soybean fields were stripped and beat to the ground, and corn fields were cut down by the wind and hail to only three feet tall in spots.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Although this Wednesday morning technically featured no severe-criteria hail/wind reports, a southward-drifting cluster of strong storms still managed to create a bit of commotion. Most notably, around 7:45 a.m. CDT, a suspected lightning strike ignited a fire at a small oil storage tank facility near the Franklin-Harlan County line north of Naponee. Four of the five tanks were destroyed in the fire, which produced a plume of dark black smoke that could be seen for miles. Prior to sparking the fire, this storm cluster yielded a slightly sub-severe wind gust of 55 MPH at the Holdrege airport and a report of penny size hail in Wilcox. ||Timing-wise, this convective cluster first entered South Central Nebraska between 4:30-5:30 a.m. CDT, dropping southward into eastern Dawson/western Buffalo counties. Over the next few hours, storms continued nearly due-south before exiting into north central Kansas between 8-9 a.m. CDT. In the mid-upper levels, this activity was sparked by a series of weak disturbances passing southward through the region in northwesterly flow, directed between a large-scale trough centered over eastern Canada/the Great Lakes, and a trough over the southwestern United States. Mesoscale convective parameters over the local area featured around 1500 J/kg of most-unstable CAPE, but no more than 30 knots of deep-layer wind shear.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a lightning strike to an area of oil storage tanks, resulting in a fire. This fire destroyed 4 of the 5 storage tanks located at the facility. The time was estimated from radar data.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Drought conditions improved dramatically across the region during the month of August 2018.  A few bouts of heavy rainfall occurred during the month, which led to vast improvements in drought conditions across the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Extreme drought conditions persisted over the entire county for the early portions of August 2018. But welcome rainfall during the middle and end of the month improved drought conditions considerably to severe by the end of the month.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the late afternoon on August 5th, 2018, a severe thunderstorm hit Quinter, KS leading to thunderstorm wind damage. Thunderstorm wind gust speeds were estimated at 90 MPH. An hour later, a line of severe thunderstorms moved east across northwest Kansas. Thunderstorm wind gusts were measured as high as 80 MPH.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Tree uprooted and roof blown off a house. Animal pen and other structural material blown against a chain link fence enclosure.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very heavy rains occurred across portions of southeast Kansas producing prolific flash flooding.  Unfortunately, two people lost their lives while trying to drive across a water covered road.  Rainfall amounts up 8.5 inches were noted.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Torrential rains within a bowl shaped landscape produced catastrophic flooding of Racket Creek. Rainfall amounts up to 8.5 inches fell in an isolated area in which the creek ran between a pair of elevated regions causing significant and rapid rises of the creek.  Water was estimated to be approximately 4 feet above road level and rushing rapidly.  It was reported that the gentlemen were driving a pickup and may have encountered an obstacle in the rushing waters causing them to stop.  The rushing waters overcame the vehicle and swept it off of the road and into the creek channel. It was estimated that the depth of the creek base to the roadway was about 15 to 20 feet.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms developed along a surface boundary near the Colorado/Kansas border during the latter half of the afternoon.  One of the thunderstorms produced a brief tornado in northern Greeley County, blew a tree over in Tribune with estimated wind speeds of 100 MPH, and produced golf ball size hail south of Tribune.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The hail ranged from nickel to quarter in size.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Estimated 60 mph wind gusts blew a tree down and an anchored trampoline a quarter mile away, and corn was sheared at the ground.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A group of supercells moved through the Sandhills late the night of Aug. 7 and into the early morning hours of Aug. 8, creating winds up to 60 mph and golf ball size hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Tree branches up to 5 inches in diameter were downed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cluster of supercells moved southeast across the western Sandhills and southwest Nebraska during the late afternoon and evening, producing winds near 70 mph and hail up to tennis ball size.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail accumulated at the property.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A supercell over Lincoln County merged with other storms to form a cluster or mini-QLCS, producing up to quarter size hail and winds estimated at 80 mph.
A supercell over Lincoln County merged with other storms to form a cluster or mini-QLCS, producing up to quarter size hail and winds estimated at 80 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Winds estimated at 80 mph overturned irrigation pivots, damaged and/or destroyed outbuildings and grain bins.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A supercell over Lincoln County merged with other storms to form a cluster or mini-QLCS, producing up to quarter size hail and winds estimated at 80 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An off duty NWS employee reported 2 campers and 1 semi trailer blown over between mile markers 169 and 171 on Interstate 80.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Mid evening a thunderstorm moved northeast over Western Kansas.  Outflow winds ahead of the thunderstorm caused brownout conditions south of Oakley.  In Gove County thunderstorm winds, estimated at 95 MPH, caused significant damage to structures and trees west of Gove.  Golf ball size hail was reported as this storm moved through Gove County.

Mid evening a thunderstorm moved northeast over Western Kansas.  Outflow winds ahead of the thunderstorm caused brownout conditions south of Oakley.  In Gove County thunderstorm winds, estimated at 95 MPH, caused significant damage to structures and trees west of Gove.  Golf ball size hail was reported as this storm moved through Gove County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The hail ranged from quarter to golf ball in size.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed along and north of a stationary front draped east/west across the southern portion of the area.   An upper level short wave trough moved out of the Rockies and helped initiate high terrain thunderstorms that eventually formed into a MCS as it tracked across the region.

Isolated thunderstorms developed over far northeastern Colorado mid afternoon on June 17th and tracked into Deuel where they became severe. Storms moved east northeast into the Sandhills and remained severe through the mid evening hours. Large hail, damaging winds and tornadoes were reported from Deuel county, east northeast into Blaine county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Measured wind gust of 64 MPH at this location.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated thunderstorms developed over far northeastern Colorado mid afternoon on June 17th and tracked into Deuel where they became severe. Storms moved east northeast into the Sandhills and remained severe through the mid evening hours. Large hail, damaging winds and tornadoes were reported from Deuel county, east northeast into Blaine county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado touched down and damaged two farmsteads along its path. The first farmstead had a livestock shed which lost its roof.  Wooden beams were tossed 30 yards, piercing the side of a garage. Shingles were ripped off of nearby outbuildings. The tornado then passed onto another farmstead where two full irrigation pivots were flipped, the first by the tornado, and a second by straight line winds. Large branches were also broken off of trees at this location.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated thunderstorms developed over far northeastern Colorado mid afternoon on June 17th and tracked into Deuel where they became severe. Storms moved east northeast into the Sandhills and remained severe through the mid evening hours. Large hail, damaging winds and tornadoes were reported from Deuel county, east northeast into Blaine county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Tornado briefly touched down in an open field with no damage reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms developed in Deuel County midday on June 24th. As they tracked east across Lake McConaughy, wind gusts in excess of 80 MPH toppled several mature trees surrounding the lake. One of the trees fell on a camper crushing the occupant inside. In addition, several campers were rolled over at a campsite.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm wind gusts estimated at 88 MPH uprooted several trees, snapped tree trunks and brought down several large branches. One branch struck a camper, killing the occupant inside. Several RV trailers were rolled over and one was rolled 5 times, landing in Lake McConaughy.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated thunderstorms developed over far northeastern Colorado mid afternoon on June 17th and tracked into Deuel where they became severe. Storms moved east northeast into the Sandhills and remained severe through the mid evening hours. Large hail, damaging winds and tornadoes were reported from Deuel county, east northeast into Blaine county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A rental house and a tree line were damaged by the tornado.  The tornado continued to the northeast where it hit another homestead where windows were shattered and a door was blown in on a residence. A full irrigation pivot was also flipped at this location.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated thunderstorms developed along a stalled out frontal boundary in southwestern Nebraska during the late afternoon of June 19th. Storms became severe over southern Frontier county with wind gusts up to 60 MPH.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm wind gust estimated at 60 MPH at this location. No damage reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated thunderstorms developed in southwest South Dakota during the afternoon hours of June 23rd and tracked into northern Nebraska were they produced some non-severe wind gusts. Other thunderstorm activity developed in the western Nebraska Panhandle later that evening. This activity tracked southeast into southwestern Nebraska where it produced wind gusts up to 60 MPH.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gust estimated at 60 MPH at this location.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Starting at the very end of May and going into June the US Drought Monitor at the University of Nebraska declared portions of eastern Kansas in a D2 or worse drought. While impacts from this drought would be felt through the summer, it's unclear if any drought impacts were felt through the month of June.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed over southeastern Cherry county during the early morning hours of June 28th. As this activity pushed east southeast, it became severe over Garfield county producing wind gusts estimated at 60 MPH.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed along an approaching cold front during the evening hours of June 29th. This activity produced Nickle sized hail in Sheridan County mid evening on June 29th. This activity drifted across north central Nebraska overnight where it intensified over Holt county producing golf ball sized hail during the early morning hours of June 30th.

Thunderstorms developed along an approaching cold front during the evening hours of June 29th. This activity produced Nickle sized hail in Sheridan County mid evening on June 29th. This activity drifted across north central Nebraska overnight where it intensified over Holt county producing golf ball sized hail during the early morning hours of June 30th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail damaged siding on a house.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of thunderstorms developed and intensified across the eastern Nebraska during the early evening hours of June 30th. As this line of activity tracked east into the western Sandhills, it became severe with damaging wind gusts of 60 MPH. As the line moved into the central Sandhills, wind gusts up to 85 MPH were reported near Stapleton.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several utility poles snapped in half and cottonwood tree branches blow 80 yards along highway 83 at mile marker 118.

While impacts from this drought would be felt through the summer, it's unclear if any drought impacts were felt through the month of June.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of thunderstorms developed and intensified across the eastern Nebraska during the early evening hours of June 30th. As this line of activity tracked east into the western Sandhills, it became severe with damaging wind gusts of 60 MPH. As the line moved into the central Sandhills, wind gusts up to 85 MPH were reported near Stapleton.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm wind gusts, estimated at around 60 MPH, brought down tree limbs at this location.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed along an approaching cold front during the evening hours of June 29th. This activity produced Nickle sized hail in Sheridan County mid evening on June 29th. EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A brief weak tornado occurred on the evening of Saturday June 30th over Jefferson county. It damaged one farmstead including minor damage to outbuildings. The tornado was virtually invisible on radar and quite honestly may have been invisible on the ground too with no damage to corn to the south or northeast of the farm noted.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This was a narrow swath of 70-80 mph winds that caused damage to a farmstead and scattered debris up to 2/3rds of a mile to the northeast.  Several outbuildings in various stages of decay were damaged.  A 2x4 wood piece was driven into the siding of the home. The corn to the south and northeast of the home were untouched at least to visible inspection.  A mystery.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of thunderstorms tracked into far southwestern Nebraska from northeastern Colorado producing thunderstorm wind gusts around 60 MPH at Imperial. A second area of strong thunderstorm winds impacted the eastern Nebraska Panhandle.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm wind gust of 67 MPH reported at the Imperial Airport.

An upper level trough of low pressure forced a cold front through western and north central Nebraska on June 1st. Along and ahead of the front, thunderstorms initiated over northeastern Cherry county. As storms tracked east, they became better organized and extended from Boyd county, south to Custer county during the evening hours. Activity exited western and north central Nebraska by 11 PM CDT. Hail up to 2.5 inches in diameter and damaging thunderstorm wind gusts were reported.

The severe weather from Colorado spread north into Nebraska as the storms themselves moved eastward.  A peak gust of 71 MPH was reported at the McCook airport.  A large tree in Indianola was blown down from this same line of thunderstorm winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A large tree was destroyed and a camper trailer was moved at a residence in Indianola.

During the latter part of the evening a line of elevated storms developed near a cold front.  The largest hail reported from these storms was golf ball size near Weskan.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tin roof was blown off a barn or shed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak upper level short wave trough moved out of the Rockies and interacted with a weak surface front to produce thunderstorms, some severe.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A propane tank and grill were smashed against the wall.  Also, a heavy glass patio table was flipped and shattered.  Chairs were blown some distance to the east.  Also, numerous pivot irrigation sprinklers across the southwest part of the county were flipped over.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level trough of low pressure forced a cold front through western and north central Nebraska on June 1st. Along and ahead of the front, thunderstorms initiated over northeastern Cherry county. As storms tracked east, they became better organized and extended from Boyd county, south to Custer county during the evening hours. Activity exited western and north central Nebraska by 11 PM CDT. Hail up to 2.5 inches in diameter and damaging thunderstorm wind gusts were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Report received by the Garfield County Sheriff.

A decaying complex of thunderstorms produced several damaging wind reports during the early morning hours of June 2nd. Several of these reports occurred well behind the initial outflow boundary.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Delayed report of broken power poles received via a twitter post from Westar Energy.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of strong storms pushed through the area during the early morning hours on June 2. Most of the damage across the KC Metro occurred on the Missouri side, but numerous locations in far eastern Kansas got hit with strong damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At least one large tree was down in the city of Tonganoxie.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated thunderstorms developed over far northeastern Colorado mid afternoon on June 17th and tracked into Deuel where they became severe. Storms moved east northeast into the Sandhills and remained severe through the mid evening hours. Large hail, damaging winds and tornadoes were reported from Deuel county, east northeast into Blaine county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail ranged in size from nickles to golf balls.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On the morning of June 26 a line of storms approached far eastern Kansas, and by early to mid afternoon had caused one inch hail to fall in Johnson County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: One inch hail fell at 87th St and Quivira.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On the morning of June 26 a line of storms approached far eastern Kansas, and by early to mid afternoon had caused one inch hail to fall in Johnson County.

Severe to extreme drought conditions across portions of central and south central Kansas during the month of June, 2018.  But welcome rainfall during the middle and towards the end of the month, actually helped with drought conditions across portions of central Kansas.  Some areas of central Kansas actually received enough rainfall to drop out of a severe drought.  The areas still in extreme drought were located along the Little Arkansas River basin from McPherson to Newton to Wichita.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Severe drought conditions were over the entire county for the early portion of the month, but welcome rainfall during the middle and end of the month improved the drought conditions considerably by the end of the month.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong storms producing large hail and high winds moved across much of southern Kansas on the 11th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The report was relayed via KWCH TV.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another in a series of Alberta clipper systems moving across the plains left behind a swath of light to moderate snow accumulations across northeast Nebraska. Much of the area received from 3 to 5 inches snowfall, while wind chills dropped below zero by the end of the time of snowfall.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility dropped to less than a mile at times, producing hazardous travel conditions with snowfall totaling as much as 4.3 inches at Newcastle and 1.5 inches at Emerson.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A few thunderstorms developed in Central Kansas in the morning, primarily over Barton County where golf ball-sized hail was reported 5 miles south/southwest of Great Bend. That afternoon and evening, the severe thunderstorms increased considerably as a weak cold front moved across South-Central and Southeast Kansas into a moisture-rich environment. Both large hail, which at times was very large, was the primary severe weather mode early in the event while damaging winds were the dominant mode as the event progressed. One rapidly developing thunderstorm did produce a strong tornado over Greenwood County that touched down on the southwest side of Eureka.  The tornado tore a path through town from southwest to northeast, producing EF3 damage on the northeast side of town.  Eight injuries occurred with the tornado but fortunately none were life-threatening.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Butler County Emergency Management relayed a report of a destroyed barn. The time of the event was estimated from radar.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moderate to extreme drought continued across a good portion of central, south central and southeast Kansas during the month of the July, 2018.  Rainfall amounts continued to be below normal, but some bouts of rainfall kept the drought from becoming worse. The areas still in extreme drought were located along the Little Arkansas River basin from McPherson to Newton to Wichita.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Extreme drought conditions persisted over entire county during the month of July 2018. Welcome rainfall did occur by the end of the month which actually improved the drought some by the end of the month.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moderate to extreme drought continued across a good portion of central, south central and southeast Kansas during the month of the July, 2018.  Rainfall amounts continued to be below normal, but some bouts of rainfall kept the drought from becoming worse. The areas still in extreme drought were located along the Little Arkansas River basin from McPherson to Newton to Wichita.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Severe to extreme drought conditions persisted over the eastern half of the county  during the early part of July 2018. Welcome rainfall did occur by the end of the month which actually improved the drought conditions to severe by the end of the month.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Severe to extreme drought conditions persisted over the entire county for the early portions of July 2018. But welcome rainfall during the middle and end of the month improved drought conditions considerably by the end of the month.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms produced widespread high winds between Interstate 80 and Highway 6 on this Thursday night and Friday morning. During the mid to late-afternoon hours Thursday, scattered thunderstorms developed from the Nebraska Panhandle down into northeast Colorado. Storm mergers, and an increasing number of storms, resulted in the formation of a squall line by 700 PM CST. This line of storms crossed most of south central Nebraska between 10 PM CST on the 10th and 1 AM CST on the 11th. These storms produced widespread measured gusts between 58 and 70 mph along the entire way across south central Nebraska from the Interstate 80 corridor south to Highway 6. A couple unofficial weather stations measured higher wind speeds including 80 mph near Axtell and 78 near Norman, both in Kearney County. Despite the coverage and magnitude of the winds, damage was only reported in a few spots. Tree branches were snapped off in Minden, an irrigation pivot was overturned near Glenvil, a few trees were blown down in Central City, and six utility poles were blown down or snapped off near Harvard. There were reports in southern Adams County and western Clay County of zero visibility in blowing dust as the high winds from the outflow moved in before the rain fell. Farmers had been preparing the fields for planting. So, top soil was loose and available for easy lofting and transport. Behind the squall line, other scattered thunderstorms developed. The strongest storms moved east along the entire length of Interstate 80 from Lexington to York between 1230 AM and 330 AM CST. These storms were mostly sub-severe, but there was a single report of one inch hail in Kearney at 2 AM CST.||During the morning hours of Thursday, a strong southward-moving cold front crossed Nebraska and became stationary along the northern Kansas border. A low pressure center formed over Wyoming and, by early evening, began moving east along the front. Meanwhile, chilly high pressure moved from the Canadian Prairies into the Great Lakes region. A broad upper-level ridge was over the Plains with a trough along the East Coast and another trough advancing through the western states. MUCAPE was around 1500 J/kg immediately preceding the storms. These storms formed on the northeast fringe of an elevated mixed layer that was advecting into the region, ahead of the western trough. Deep layer shear was 50 kts and greater. This environment was more than sufficient for severe thunderstorms. The cold pool associated with the squall line was strong. The temperature at Lexington dropped 16 deg F in 20 minutes (76 to 60 deg F) as the gust front moved through, and 23 deg in 40 min (76 to 53 deg F).

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms produced widespread high winds between Interstate 80 and Highway 6 on this Thursday night and Friday morning. During the mid to late-afternoon hours Thursday, scattered thunderstorms developed from the Nebraska Panhandle down into northeast Colorado. Storm mergers, and an increasing number of storms, resulted in the formation of a squall line by 700 PM CST. This line of storms crossed most of south central Nebraska between 10 PM CST on the 10th and 1 AM CST on the 11th. These storms produced widespread measured gusts between 58 and 70 mph along the entire way across south central Nebraska from the Interstate 80 corridor south to Highway 6. A couple unofficial weather stations measured higher wind speeds including 80 mph near Axtell and 78 near Norman, both in Kearney County. Despite the coverage and magnitude of the winds, damage was only reported in a few spots. Tree branches were snapped off in Minden, an irrigation pivot was overturned near Glenvil, a few trees were blown down in Central City, and six utility poles were blown down or snapped off near Harvard. There were reports in southern Adams County and western Clay County of zero visibility in blowing dust as the high winds from the outflow moved in before the rain fell. Farmers had been preparing the fields for planting. So, top soil was loose and available for easy lofting and transport. Behind the squall line, other scattered thunderstorms developed. The strongest storms moved east along the entire length of Interstate 80 from Lexington to York between 1230 AM and 330 AM CST. These storms were mostly sub-severe, but there was a single report of one inch hail in Kearney at 2 AM CST.||During the morning hours of Thursday, a strong southward-moving cold front crossed Nebraska and became stationary along the northern Kansas border. A low pressure center formed over Wyoming and, by early evening, began moving east along the front. Meanwhile, chilly high pressure moved from the Canadian Prairies into the Great Lakes region. A broad upper-level ridge was over the Plains with a trough along the East Coast and another trough advancing through the western states. MUCAPE was around 1500 J/kg immediately preceding the storms. These storms formed on the northeast fringe of an elevated mixed layer that was advecting into the region, ahead of the western trough. Deep layer shear was 50 kts and greater. This environment was more than sufficient for severe thunderstorms. The cold pool associated with the squall line was strong. The temperature at Lexington dropped 16 deg F in 20 minutes (76 to 60 deg F) as the gust front moved through, and 23 deg in 40 min (76 to 53 deg F).

These storms were mostly sub-severe, but there was a single report of one inch hail in Kearney at 2 AM CST.||During the morning hours of Thursday, a strong southward-moving cold front crossed Nebraska and became stationary along the northern Kansas border. A low pressure center formed over Wyoming and, by early evening, began moving east along the front. Meanwhile, chilly high pressure moved from the Canadian Prairies into the Great Lakes region. A broad upper-level ridge was over the Plains with a trough along the East Coast and another trough advancing through the western states. MUCAPE was around 1500 J/kg immediately preceding the storms. These storms formed on the northeast fringe of an elevated mixed layer that was advecting into the region, ahead of the western trough. Deep layer shear was 50 kts and greater. This environment was more than sufficient for severe thunderstorms. The cold pool associated with the squall line was strong. The temperature at Lexington dropped 16 deg F in 20 minutes (76 to 60 deg F) as the gust front moved through, and 23 deg in 40 min (76 to 53 deg F).

Severe thunderstorms produced widespread high winds between Interstate 80 and Highway 6 on this Thursday night and Friday morning. During the mid to late-afternoon hours Thursday, scattered thunderstorms developed from the Nebraska Panhandle down into northeast Colorado. Storm mergers, and an increasing number of storms, resulted in the formation of a squall line by 700 PM CST. This line of storms crossed most of south central Nebraska between 10 PM CST on the 10th and 1 AM CST on the 11th. These storms produced widespread measured gusts between 58 and 70 mph along the entire way across south central Nebraska from the Interstate 80 corridor south to Highway 6. A couple unofficial weather stations measured higher wind speeds including 80 mph near Axtell and 78 near Norman, both in Kearney County. Despite the coverage and magnitude of the winds, damage was only reported in a few spots. Tree branches were snapped off in Minden, an irrigation pivot was overturned near Glenvil, a few trees were blown down in Central City, and six utility poles were blown down or snapped off near Harvard. There were reports in southern Adams County and western Clay County of zero visibility in blowing dust as the high winds from the outflow moved in before the rain fell. Farmers had been preparing the fields for planting. So, top soil was loose and available for easy lofting and transport. Behind the squall line, other scattered thunderstorms developed. The strongest storms moved east along the entire length of Interstate 80 from Lexington to York between 1230 AM and 330 AM CST. These storms were mostly sub-severe, but there was a single report of one inch hail in Kearney at 2 AM CST.||During the morning hours of Thursday, a strong southward-moving cold front crossed Nebraska and became stationary along the northern Kansas border. A low pressure center formed over Wyoming and, by early evening, began moving east along the front. Meanwhile, chilly high pressure moved from the Canadian Prairies into the Great Lakes region. A broad upper-level ridge was over the Plains with a trough along the East Coast and another trough advancing through the western states. MUCAPE was around 1500 J/kg immediately preceding the storms. These storms formed on the northeast fringe of an elevated mixed layer that was advecting into the region, ahead of the western trough. Deep layer shear was 50 kts and greater. This environment was more than sufficient for severe thunderstorms. The cold pool associated with the squall line was strong. The temperature at Lexington dropped 16 deg F in 20 minutes (76 to 60 deg F) as the gust front moved through, and 23 deg in 40 min (76 to 53 deg F).

A major winter storm moved into the Central Plains on the 22nd.  A band of snow dumped over 10 inches of snow over a large area of northeast Nebraska.  Amounts of snow ranged from 1.8 inches in Lincoln to 17.6 inches in Bloomfield.  The largest amounts included 10 inches in Albion, 12.5 inches near Wakefield, 14 inches at Neligh, 14.6 inches at Norfolk, 15 inches at Stanton, and 16 inches at Pierce.  The heavy snow combined with strong winds created blizzard conditions across a large area of Northeastern Nebraska.  Roads were closed, and traffic came to a standstill on many highways.  Numerous power outages were reported as far south as Omaha.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Intense winds along with heavy snow created blizzard conditions across Pierce County.  There was a total of 16 of snow reported at Pierce.

The heavy snow combined with strong winds created blizzard conditions across a large area of Northeastern Nebraska.  Roads were closed, and traffic came to a standstill on many highways.  Numerous power outages were reported as far south as Omaha.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Intense winds and heavy snowfall created blizzard conditions across Knox County.  Nebraska Highway 59 was closed as well as U.S. 20.  Bloomfield reported 17.6 of snow.  Numerous vehicles were stuck on highways.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms, several that were severe, broke out across Kansas late in the afternoon and continued well into the night. The severe thunderstorms were prolific wind producers as 60-70 mph speeds were reported in many areas throughout the event.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The gust was measured at Strother Field.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A few thunderstorms developed in Central Kansas in the morning, primarily over Barton County where golf ball-sized hail was reported 5 miles south/southwest of Great Bend. That afternoon and evening, the severe thunderstorms increased considerably as a weak cold front moved across South-Central and Southeast Kansas into a moisture-rich environment. Both large hail, which at times was very large, was the primary severe weather mode early in the event while damaging winds were the dominant mode as the event progressed. One rapidly developing thunderstorm did produce a strong tornado over Greenwood County that touched down on the southwest side of Eureka.  The tornado tore a path through town from southwest to northeast, producing EF3 damage on the northeast side of town.  Eight injuries occurred with the tornado but fortunately none were life-threatening.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The 56-knot/65-mph winds were reported by campers at Lake Afton. Ping pong ball sized hail also occurred.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moderate to extreme drought continued across a good portion of central, south central and southeast Kansas during the month of the July, 2018.  Rainfall amounts continued to be below normal, but some bouts of rainfall kept the drought from becoming worse. The areas still in extreme drought were located along the Little Arkansas River basin from McPherson to Newton to Wichita.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Extreme drought conditions persisted over entire county during the month of July 2018. Welcome rainfall did occur by the end of the month, which actually improved the drought some by the end of the month.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong storms producing large hail and high winds moved across much of southern Kansas on the 11th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Measured by official observing equipment.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms, several that were severe, broke out across Kansas late in the afternoon and continued well into the night. The severe thunderstorms were prolific wind producers as 60-70 mph speeds were reported in many areas throughout the event.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The gust occurred 3 miles south of the Butler/Cowley County line on U.S. Highway 77.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms, several that were severe, broke out across Kansas late in the afternoon and continued well into the night. The severe thunderstorms were prolific wind producers as 60-70 mph speeds were reported in many areas throughout the event.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter reported gusts of at least 70 mph. The wind damaged a B-47 bomber that had been on display at the east entrance to McConnell AFB. A B-52 displayed at the west entrance to the base was slightly damaged. This was a delayed report.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of severe thunderstorms surged southeast from Russell County, through Barton and Ellsworth Counties, to as far southeast as Sedgwick County very early in the morning on the 29th. Damage was limited to trees, but considering how strong the winds were, one would have to believe there was considerable property damage and downed power poles as well.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The gust was measured by the Lyons AWOS. There were no reports of damage, but one would believe that there was.

A low pressure center formed over Wyoming and, by early evening, began moving east along the front. Meanwhile, chilly high pressure moved from the Canadian Prairies into the Great Lakes region. A broad upper-level ridge was over the Plains with a trough along the East Coast and another trough advancing through the western states. MUCAPE was around 1500 J/kg immediately preceding the storms. These storms formed on the northeast fringe of an elevated mixed layer that was advecting into the region, ahead of the western trough. Deep layer shear was 50 kts and greater. This environment was more than sufficient for severe thunderstorms. The cold pool associated with the squall line was strong. A weakening thunderstorm briefly produced severe hail on this Sunday evening. Shortly after 6 PM CST, a short line segment of storms formed southwest of Hayes. The storm on the easternmost portion of the line broke off from the line and rapidly moved northeast across Ellis County. This small storm cross southeast Rooks County between 745 PM and 810 PM CST and produced one inch hail at Natoma before weakening.||The initial storms developed near a quasi-stationary front that extended from southwest to northeast across Kansas, then east along I-70 into the Mid-Atlantic states. The upper-level flow was from the southwest as a low was over Nevada and a subtropical high was over the Mid-Mississippi Valley. Mid-level lapse rates were steep (8 deg C/km) with MUCAPE around 2000 J/kg. Deep layer shear was around 30 kts.

Spotty wind damage occurred in Cozad after midnight on this Friday morning, followed by severe winds associated with a wake low later in the morning. At 1200 AM CST, a large mesoscale convective system was in progress from the Sandhills southwest into the southern Nebraska Panhandle. The forward-propagating squall line extended from the Sandhills southwest into Custer County and was weakening. Where the outflow boundary became oriented more west-east, a few strong storms remained. These storms formed into a new squall line over Lincoln and Custer counties. As this line moved into Dawson County, some minor roof damage occurred in Cozad and a large pine tree was blown over and onto a house. This line weakened as it moved further east into south central Nebraska. After sunrise, the persistent mesoscale convective complex that had affected the area, throughout the nighttime and early morning hours, weakened and decreased in size. As this occurred, a wake low developed on its westward side and resulted in measured winds of 60 mph at the airport in Ord, along with significant fluctuations in pressure.||Two fronts separated three air masses over the U.S., one across the southern states and the other across the northern states. A chilly continental polar air mass was across the north, a warm and humid maritime tropical air mass was over the south, and these storms occurred in the modified continental polar air in between, far from any fronts. An upper-level trough was over the western U.S., while a ridge was over the Great Lakes. Fairly weak southwest flow was over the Central Plains. This MCS developed from scattered storms that initially formed within the lee trough near the Nebraska-Wyoming border the previous afternoon. Warm air advection and convergence associated with the low-level jet maintained the MCS through the night. Just prior to the squall line affecting Cozad, MUCAPE was around 1500 J/kg with mid-level lapse rates around 7.5 deg C/km. Deep layer shear was around 45 kts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A few local businesses sustained minor roof damage, and some tin was blown off a few outbuildings.  A large pine tree was uprooted, landing on a house.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Spotty wind damage occurred in Cozad after midnight on this Friday morning, followed by severe winds associated with a wake low later in the morning. At 1200 AM CST, a large mesoscale convective system was in progress from the Sandhills southwest into the southern Nebraska Panhandle. The forward-propagating squall line extended from the Sandhills southwest into Custer County and was weakening. Where the outflow boundary became oriented more west-east, a few strong storms remained. These storms formed into a new squall line over Lincoln and Custer counties. As this line moved into Dawson County, some minor roof damage occurred in Cozad and a large pine tree was blown over and onto a house. This line weakened as it moved further east into south central Nebraska. After sunrise, the persistent mesoscale convective complex that had affected the area, throughout the nighttime and early morning hours, weakened and decreased in size. As this occurred, a wake low developed on its westward side and resulted in measured winds of 60 mph at the airport in Ord, along with significant fluctuations in pressure.||Two fronts separated three air masses over the U.S., one across the southern states and the other across the northern states. A chilly continental polar air mass was across the north, a warm and humid maritime tropical air mass was over the south, and these storms occurred in the modified continental polar air in between, far from any fronts. An upper-level trough was over the western U.S., while a ridge was over the Great Lakes. Fairly weak southwest flow was over the Central Plains. This MCS developed from scattered storms that initially formed within the lee trough near the Nebraska-Wyoming border the previous afternoon. Warm air advection and convergence associated with the low-level jet maintained the MCS through the night. Just prior to the squall line affecting Cozad, MUCAPE was around 1500 J/kg with mid-level lapse rates around 7.5 deg C/km. Deep layer shear was around 45 kts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This wind gust was associated with a wake low. The pressure plunged 9 mb between 9-10 a.m. CDT. There was a 3 mb pressure drop from 9:55-10 a.m. CDT and then a 3 mb rise from 10-10:05 a.m. CDT. This gust coincided with the lowest pressure.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe hail occurred across portions of Phillips and Smith counties on this Wednesday afternoon. Around 2 PM CST, a thunderstorm developed over southwestern Phillips County. This storm slowly moved northeast across the county and it finally exited into northwest Smith County around 4 PM CST. This storm produced severe hail from west-central Phillips County all the way into northwest Smith County. Multiple reports of hail occurred. Hail averaged one inch in diameter, but there was one report of half dollar size hail north of Kensington.||This storm occurred in return flow between a warm front retreating north and east into South Dakota and Iowa and a lee-side trough that extended from weak low pressure over South Dakota southwestward into Colorado. Weak southwest flow was over the Central Plains with a mean trough in the West and a ridge over the Upper Midwest. A weak shortwave trough was lifting northeast across Wyoming, Colorado, and New Mexico. As the storm developed, temperatures were in the lower 80s with dewpoints in the lower 60s. Despite a poor mid-level lapse rate, MLCAPE was between 1500 and 2000 J/kg. Deep layer shear was weak, just under 20 kts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A few thunderstorms developed in Central Kansas in the morning, primarily over Barton County where golf ball-sized hail was reported 5 miles south/southwest of Great Bend. That afternoon and evening, the severe thunderstorms increased considerably as a weak cold front moved across South-Central and Southeast Kansas into a moisture-rich environment. Both large hail, which at times was very large, was the primary severe weather mode early in the event while damaging winds were the dominant mode as the event progressed. One rapidly developing thunderstorm did produce a strong tornado over Greenwood County that touched down on the southwest side of Eureka.  The tornado tore a path through town from southwest to northeast, producing EF3 damage on the northeast side of town.  Eight injuries occurred with the tornado but fortunately none were life-threatening.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: No damage was reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms, several that were severe, broke out across Kansas late in the afternoon and continued well into the night. The severe thunderstorms were prolific wind producers as 60-70 mph speeds were reported in many areas throughout the event.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 4-inch diameter limb was blown down at the WFO.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms, several that were severe, broke out across Kansas late in the afternoon and continued well into the night. The severe thunderstorms were prolific wind producers as 60-70 mph speeds were reported in many areas throughout the event.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The ping pong ball-sized hail combined with winds around 60 mph to down power lines. Heavy rains were also reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms, several that were severe, broke out across Kansas late in the afternoon and continued well into the night. The severe thunderstorms were prolific wind producers as 60-70 mph speeds were reported in many areas throughout the event.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The cloud-to-ground strike knocked down a tree onto power lines.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms, several that were severe, broke out across Kansas late in the afternoon and continued well into the night. The severe thunderstorms were prolific wind producers as 60-70 mph speeds were reported in many areas throughout the event.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Power lines & power poles were knocked down onto Franklin Street and Hayes Street in town. Both roads were blocked.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A few thunderstorms developed in Central Kansas in the morning, primarily over Barton County where golf ball-sized hail was reported 5 miles south/southwest of Great Bend. That afternoon and evening, the severe thunderstorms increased considerably as a weak cold front moved across South-Central and Southeast Kansas into a moisture-rich environment. Both large hail, which at times was very large, was the primary severe weather mode early in the event while damaging winds were the dominant mode as the event progressed. One rapidly developing thunderstorm did produce a strong tornado over Greenwood County that touched down on the southwest side of Eureka.  The tornado tore a path through town from southwest to northeast, producing EF3 damage on the northeast side of town.  Eight injuries occurred with the tornado but fortunately none were life-threatening.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A large circulation around tree top level moved into the southwest side of town causing minimal damage initially to trees and one business, before descending fully to the ground, as it moved northeast across town.  The tornado fully came down to the ground, on the northeast side of town, intensifying, and causing significant damage to homes and businesses.  The worst damage, rated EF-3, occurred just south of the high school, with one home having only interior walls remaining standing.   Eight injuries were reported due to the tornado, with three of the injuries occurring in one house.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of severe thunderstorms surged southeast from Russell County, through Barton and Ellsworth Counties, to as far southeast as Sedgwick County very early in the morning on the 29th. Damage was limited to trees, but considering how strong the winds were, one would have to believe there was considerable property damage and downed power poles as well.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Tree limbs and branches were downed across town.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of severe thunderstorms surged southeast from Russell County, through Barton and Ellsworth Counties, to as far southeast as Sedgwick County very early in the morning on the 29th. Damage was limited to trees, but considering how strong the winds were, one would have to believe there was considerable property damage and downed power poles as well.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The emergency manager didn't report any damage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe hail occurred across portions of Phillips and Smith counties on this Wednesday afternoon. Around 2 PM CST, a thunderstorm developed over southwestern Phillips County. This storm slowly moved northeast across the county and it finally exited into northwest Smith County around 4 PM CST. This storm produced severe hail from west-central Phillips County all the way into northwest Smith County. Multiple reports of hail occurred. Hail averaged one inch in diameter, but there was one report of half dollar size hail north of Kensington.||This storm occurred in return flow between a warm front retreating north and east into South Dakota and Iowa and a lee-side trough that extended from weak low pressure over South Dakota southwestward into Colorado. Weak southwest flow was over the Central Plains with a mean trough in the West and a ridge over the Upper Midwest. A weak shortwave trough was lifting northeast across Wyoming, Colorado, and New Mexico. As the storm developed, temperatures were in the lower 80s with dewpoints in the lower 60s. Despite a poor mid-level lapse rate, MLCAPE was between 1500 and 2000 J/kg. Deep layer shear was weak, just under 20 kts.

Severe to extreme drought conditions across portions of central and south central Kansas during the month of June, 2018.  But welcome rainfall during the middle and towards the end of the month, actually helped with drought conditions across portions of central Kansas.  Some areas of central Kansas actually received enough rainfall to drop out of a severe drought.  The areas still in extreme drought were located along the Little Arkansas River basin from McPherson to Newton to Wichita.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Severe drought conditions persisted over the entire county for the month of June 2018.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A storm system dropped south across central sections of the state.  It started out as just below severe criteria before they exploded into a significant situation.  One tornado occurred with a long swath of winds between 75 and 90 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread wind damage was noted along the path to many trees and structures in which the trees fell.  One Cedar tree with an 18 inch trunk was snapped off about 20 feet above ground level and another maple tree was uprooted.  One other location south of Ark City had all the limbs blown out with other damage to trees noted.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A storm system dropped south across central sections of the state.  It started out as just below severe criteria before they exploded into a significant situation.  One tornado occurred with a long swath of winds between 75 and 90 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This tornado moved in from Sumner county and dissipated quickly with no damage.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A delayed report was received via Twitter. The video that was submitted showed a tree being uprooted by severe thunderstorm winds. The time of the event was estimated by radar.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A few storms moved across central Kansas producing a few severe events on the 18th and 19th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Power lines were blown down around the 4300 block of Plum St.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A few storms moved across central Kansas producing a few severe events on the 18th and 19th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Four power poles were blown down near the 43rd and Monroe area.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Power outages were also reported in the area.

Severe storms produced numerous reports of hail and 3 brief, weak tornadoes on this Tuesday afternoon and evening. Between 230 and 330 PM CST, scattered fairly small supercell thunderstorms developed along a line from Red Cloud to Grand Island to Columbus. They were not mini-supercells, though, as cloud tops were near 40,000 ft. The storms generally remained along that line except for one storm that moved east into Clay County and another small multicell cluster that moved east along the Nebraska-Kansas border. Nearly 30 occurrences of severe hail were reported with most of between the sizes of quarters and golf balls. The largest hail reported was 2 inches in diameter in the town of Roseland. Three brief EF-0 tornadoes also occurred. The storms from Grand Island to Columbus formed along a slow-moving cold front. One tornado was associated with a supercell located on or very close to the front just west of Aurora. Another tornado formed near Doniphan as a north-northeastward-moving storm crossed the front. The third tornado occurred with the storm that moved east along the Nebraska-Kansas border. This storm evolved from a small bow echo and exhibited a spiral shape as it produced a brief tornado near Chester. The storms dissipated or moved out of south central Nebraska by 6 PM CST.||A low pressure system was near Lake Superior with a slow-moving cold front extending southwest across Nebraska to the Oklahoma Panhandle. In the upper-levels, southwest flow covered most of the U.S., with a trough over the West and a ridge over the Northeast. Just prior to thunderstorm development, temperatures were in the lower 80s with dewpoints in the upper 50s to near 60. With mid-level lapse rates near 8 C/km, MLCAPE was 2000-2500 J/kg. Deep layer shear was 40-50 kts, which was more than sufficient for supercell convective mode.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This EF-0 rated tornado moved in from Republic County, Kansas. The tornado was captured on video by a local farmer. The video and radar was used to determine the time. This tornado did not cause any significant damage as it moved through an open field, and the maximum wind speed was estimated to be 70 MPH.

One tornado was associated with a supercell located on or very close to the front just west of Aurora. Another tornado formed near Doniphan as a north-northeastward-moving storm crossed the front. The third tornado occurred with the storm that moved east along the Nebraska-Kansas border. This storm evolved from a small bow echo and exhibited a spiral shape as it produced a brief tornado near Chester. The storms dissipated or moved out of south central Nebraska by 6 PM CST.||A low pressure system was near Lake Superior with a slow-moving cold front extending southwest across Nebraska to the Oklahoma Panhandle. In the upper-levels, southwest flow covered most of the U.S., with a trough over the West and a ridge over the Northeast. Just prior to thunderstorm development, temperatures were in the lower 80s with dewpoints in the upper 50s to near 60. With mid-level lapse rates near 8 C/km, MLCAPE was 2000-2500 J/kg. Deep layer shear was 40-50 kts, which was more than sufficient for supercell convective mode.

Storms produced very heavy rain, localized hail and wind damage, and even a brief tornado over north central Kansas on this Tuesday afternoon and evening. Around 2 PM CST, several thunderstorms rapidly developed southwest-to-northeast across Rooks and Smith counties. These storms merged into a line as they moved east and gradually evolved into two multicell clusters. Each cluster tracked across portions of Jewell, and Osborne and Mitchell counties. The Jewell County storm become a very small bow echo, but with no wind damage reported. However, some wind damage did occur over southeastern Osborne County where wood framing and metal sheeting were blown off an outbuilding on one farm. A hay rake and two empty grain trailers were also blown over. Hail occurred in many places, with the largest 2 inches in diameter over south central Mitchell County. This same storm produced a brief tornado that resembled an elephant trunk. As these storms moved into northeast Kansas, other storms continued to initiate near Interstate 70 and began lifting into southern Osborne and Mitchell counties after 6 PM CST. The axis of storms stopped lifting north and repeated storm development occurred over southern Osborne and Mitchell counties, between 7 and 11 PM CST, resulting in total rainfall amounts between 2.50 and 5.18 inches. The highest amount of 5.18 inches fell just southeast of Tipton. Flash flooding occurred in low-lying spots from southeast Osborne across central Mitchell counties, with water over multiple county roads. Flooding resulted in a washout where bridge work was being performed in Mitchell county on Victor road, between P and Q roads.||A low pressure system was near Lake Superior with a slow-moving cold front extending southwest across Kansas to the Oklahoma Panhandle. In the upper-levels, southwest flow covered most of the U.S., with a trough over the West and a ridge over the Northeast. Just prior to thunderstorm development, temperatures were in the lower to middle 80s with dewpoints in the lower 60s. With mid-level lapse rates near 8 C/km, MLCAPE was 2000-2500 J/kg. Deep layer shear was 40-50 kts, which was more than sufficient for severe thunderstorms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This tornado was captured by video and photograph by a storm chaser. The tornado was rated an EF-0, moving over an open field with an estimated wind speed of 75 MPH.

Severe hail occurred across portions of Phillips and Smith counties on this Wednesday afternoon. Around 2 PM CST, a thunderstorm developed over southwestern Phillips County. This storm slowly moved northeast across the county and it finally exited into northwest Smith County around 4 PM CST. This storm produced severe hail from west-central Phillips County all the way into northwest Smith County. Multiple reports of hail occurred. Hail averaged one inch in diameter, but there was one report of half dollar size hail north of Kensington.||This storm occurred in return flow between a warm front retreating north and east into South Dakota and Iowa and a lee-side trough that extended from weak low pressure over South Dakota southwestward into Colorado. Weak southwest flow was over the Central Plains with a mean trough in the West and a ridge over the Upper Midwest. A weak shortwave trough was lifting northeast across Wyoming, Colorado, and New Mexico. As the storm developed, temperatures were in the lower 80s with dewpoints in the lower 60s. Despite a poor mid-level lapse rate, MLCAPE was between 1500 and 2000 J/kg. Deep layer shear was weak, just under 20 kts.

A single report of severe hail occurred on this Thursday evening. Just after 730 PM CST, an arc-shaped line of thunderstorms developed across Graham and Trego counties. This line of storms crossed the entirety of Rooks County between 830 PM and 940 PM CST. There was a single report of nickel to quarter size hail at Webster State Park. Measured wind gusts associated with this line remained just below 50 MPH.||This line of storms occurred away from any synoptic-scale boundaries. The pressure gradient was weak as high pressure was over eastern Kansas to the Gulf Coast states. A lee-side low was over southeastern Colorado, and outflow boundaries from previous convection were over portions of Kansas. In the upper-levels, ridges were over the Rockies and the Great Lakes with the eastern ridge anchored by a subtropical high over the Tennessee Valley. Through the day, a shortwave trough had been moving out of the Northern Rockies and into the Northern Plains, with its tail end extending into western Nebraska. Just prior to the thunderstorms moving in, temperatures were in the lower 80s with dewpoints in the middle 60s. Mid-level lapse rates were steep (7.5 C/km) contributing to MLCAPE between 2000 and 2500 J/kg. Deep layer shear was around 25 kts.

Isolated severe winds occurred in Buffalo County on this Monday, along with locally heavy rain. Thunderstorms were widespread over southwest Nebraska and the western fringe of south central Nebraska (west of Hwy 283) at sunrise. This area of storms decreased and became more scattered as it advanced further east into south central Nebraska late in the morning. New thunderstorms formed over southwestern Buffalo County around 1030 AM CST. As they moved northeast across the county, one observer north of Kearney estimated winds may have been as high as 60 mph. There was no nearby measurements or reports of damage to substantiate the observation, though. Multiple storms occurred over southwest Hall County between 1200 and 100 PM CST, and lighter anvil-generated rain continued thereafter. An observer measured just over 3 inches of rain.||Scattered thunderstorms originally formed far to the west along and ahead of a cold front the previous afternoon. The front remained quasi-stationary across northern and western Nebraska during the day Monday. An outflow boundary from the overnight MCS did move southeast across the state, aiding in the initiation of additional thunderstorms. A persistent trough was over the Western U.S. with an embedded cut-off low, with a downstream ridge over the Upper Midwest. Fairly weak southwest flow was over the Central Plains. In advance of the storms, temperatures had risen into the 80s with dewpoints in the 60s. Combined with mid-level lapse rates near 7 C/km, this resulted in MLCAPE between 1500 and 2000 J/kg. Deep layer shear was around 25-30 kts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts were estimated to be near 60 MPH.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A couple locations in Phillips County experienced severe winds and hail on this Monday, and significant rain also fell. At noon CST, an area of scattered thunderstorms moved into north central Kansas. The area of storms was leftover from previous afternoon and nighttime convection and was associated with an advancing outflow boundary. By this time, new thunderstorms were beginning to form over north central Kansas as well. A quasi-stationary line of thunderstorms formed from southwest to northeast across Phillips and Rooks counties between noon and 4 PM CST. This line fell apart, but one last storm moved into Rooks County by 5 PM CST and weakened as it moved into southeastern Phillips County by 6 PM CST. Severe hail occurred in a couple spots around 1 PM CST. Hail the size of pennies fell just north of the town of Speed, and hail the size of quarters fell near the Phillips-Smith County line north of Agra. The final storm that weakened over Phillips County produced winds up to 70 mph near the town of Glade. The echo-training resulted in heavy rainfall amounts between 3 and 4 inches from western Rooks into central Phillips counties. Meanwhile, an area of 4-8 inches of rain fell over Gove, Graham, and Trego counties, with the highest observation of 9.88 inches measured in southwestern Graham County. As all this water drained into the South Fork of the Solomon River and Bow Creek, along with their tributaries, water levels shot up rapidly during the evening, with flooding occurring in crop and pasture land adjacent to these features. The South Fork of the Solomon River west of the Webster Reservoir rose into moderate flood stage and crested at 13.56 ft around 6 AM CST Tuesday (flood stage is 8.5 ft). Bow Creek near Stockton rose into minor flood stage and crested at 10.55 ft late Tuesday morning (flood stage is 9.0 ft). Just downstream from the river gauge, water from Bow Creek was flowing over the bridge near east 500 Rd and Day Dream Rd. ||Scattered thunderstorms developed well to the west during the previous afternoon and night, along and ahead of a cold front. The resulting MCS sent an outflow boundary across north central Kansas, which aided in initiating new storms. A persistent trough was over the Western U.S. with an embedded cut-off low, with a downstream ridge over the Upper Midwest. Fairly weak southwest flow was over the Central Plains. In advance of the storms, temperatures had risen into the 80s with dewpoints in the 60s. Combined with mid-level lapse rates near 7.5 C/km, this resulted in MLCAPE between 2500 and 3000 J/kg. Deep layer shear was around 30 kts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A residual outflow boundary and a warm front interacted with an unstable atmosphere to produce severe thunderstorms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Ten power poles were broken by high wind.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A couple of thunderstorms barely reached severe status.
A couple of thunderstorms barely reached severe status.

A cold front moving southward across eastern Nebraska and western Iowa caused some flash freezing conditions on wet roadway surfaces.  In addition an area of snow developed behind the front.  Amounts between 3 to 5 inches fell over southeast Nebraska and southwest Iowa.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A storm total of 3.7 inches of snow was reported 5 miles east of Auburn.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe to extreme drought conditions across portions of central and south central Kansas during the month of June, 2018.  But welcome rainfall during the middle and towards the end of the month, actually helped with drought conditions across portions of central Kansas.  Some areas of central Kansas actually received enough rainfall to drop out of a severe drought.  The areas still in extreme drought were located along the Little Arkansas River basin from McPherson to Newton to Wichita.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Severe drought conditions persisted over the northwest portions of the county during the month of June 2018.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong storms producing large hail and high winds moved across much of southern Kansas on the 11th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: This report was in the Highlands at 82nd and Monroe. Via social media.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong storms producing large hail and high winds moved across much of southern Kansas on the 11th.
Strong storms producing large hail and high winds moved across much of southern Kansas on the 11th.

A storm system dropped south across central sections of the state.  It started out as just below severe criteria before they exploded into a significant situation.  One tornado occurred with a long swath of winds between 75 and 90 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotters reported funnels, debris, and power flashes as the rain wrapped tornado moved southeast.  Minimal damage was noted as it moved over open countryside. This tornado moved into Cowley County and dissipated.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A storm system dropped south across central sections of the state.  It started out as just below severe criteria before they exploded into a significant situation.  One tornado occurred with a long swath of winds between 75 and 90 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 62 mph measured gust was reported on the north side of town.  As the wind moved across town and to the southeast, a significant amount of tree damage was reported across the community.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A few thunderstorms developed in Central Kansas in the morning, primarily over Barton County where golf ball-sized hail was reported 5 miles south/southwest of Great Bend. That afternoon and evening, the severe thunderstorms increased considerably as a weak cold front moved across South-Central and Southeast Kansas into a moisture-rich environment. Both large hail, which at times was very large, was the primary severe weather mode early in the event while damaging winds were the dominant mode as the event progressed. One rapidly developing thunderstorm did produce a strong tornado over Greenwood County that touched down on the southwest side of Eureka.  The tornado tore a path through town from southwest to northeast, producing EF3 damage on the northeast side of town.  Eight injuries occurred with the tornado but fortunately none were life-threatening.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A few thunderstorms developed in Central Kansas in the morning, primarily over Barton County where golf ball-sized hail was reported 5 miles south/southwest of Great Bend. That afternoon and evening, the severe thunderstorms increased considerably as a weak cold front moved across South-Central and Southeast Kansas into a moisture-rich environment. Both large hail, which at times was very large, was the primary severe weather mode early in the event while damaging winds were the dominant mode as the event progressed. One rapidly developing thunderstorm did produce a strong tornado over Greenwood County that touched down on the southwest side of Eureka.  The tornado tore a path through town from southwest to northeast, producing EF3 damage on the northeast side of town.  Eight injuries occurred with the tornado but fortunately none were life-threatening.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Brief small funnel touched down over open country.  No damage reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moderate to extreme drought continued across a good portion of central, south central and southeast Kansas during the month of the July, 2018.  Rainfall amounts continued to be below normal, but some bouts of rainfall kept the drought from becoming worse. The areas still in extreme drought were located along the Little Arkansas River basin from McPherson to Newton to Wichita.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Severe drought conditions persisted over the entire county for the month of July 2018.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of severe thunderstorms surged southeast from Russell County, through Barton and Ellsworth Counties, to as far southeast as Sedgwick County very early in the morning on the 29th. Damage was limited to trees, but considering how strong the winds were, one would have to believe there was considerable property damage and downed power poles as well.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a delayed report of estimated 70 mph winds that caused damage to 4 inch diameter limbs. The time of the event was based on radar.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The report was received via Twitter.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On the afternoon and evening of August 28 several thunderstorms affected the area with hail and wind. The winds ranged from 60 to 70 mph and did some damage to trees, power lines, and some structures.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous tree branches were down, and a few power lines were damaged in Shawnee.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On the afternoon and evening of August 28 several thunderstorms affected the area with hail and wind. The winds ranged from 60 to 70 mph and did some damage to trees, power lines, and some structures.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A few tree limbs of around 4 inches in diameter were broken.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A couple locations in Phillips County experienced severe winds and hail on this Monday, and significant rain also fell. At noon CST, an area of scattered thunderstorms moved into north central Kansas. The area of storms was leftover from previous afternoon and nighttime convection and was associated with an advancing outflow boundary. By this time, new thunderstorms were beginning to form over north central Kansas as well. A quasi-stationary line of thunderstorms formed from southwest to northeast across Phillips and Rooks counties between noon and 4 PM CST. This line fell apart, but one last storm moved into Rooks County by 5 PM CST and weakened as it moved into southeastern Phillips County by 6 PM CST. Severe hail occurred in a couple spots around 1 PM CST. Hail the size of pennies fell just north of the town of Speed, and hail the size of quarters fell near the Phillips-Smith County line north of Agra. The final storm that weakened over Phillips County produced winds up to 70 mph near the town of Glade. The echo-training resulted in heavy rainfall amounts between 3 and 4 inches from western Rooks into central Phillips counties. Meanwhile, an area of 4-8 inches of rain fell over Gove, Graham, and Trego counties, with the highest observation of 9.88 inches measured in southwestern Graham County. As all this water drained into the South Fork of the Solomon River and Bow Creek, along with their tributaries, water levels shot up rapidly during the evening, with flooding occurring in crop and pasture land adjacent to these features. The South Fork of the Solomon River west of the Webster Reservoir rose into moderate flood stage and crested at 13.56 ft around 6 AM CST Tuesday (flood stage is 8.5 ft). Bow Creek near Stockton rose into minor flood stage and crested at 10.55 ft late Tuesday morning (flood stage is 9.0 ft). Just downstream from the river gauge, water from Bow Creek was flowing over the bridge near east 500 Rd and Day Dream Rd. ||Scattered thunderstorms developed well to the west during the previous afternoon and night, along and ahead of a cold front. The resulting MCS sent an outflow boundary across north central Kansas, which aided in initiating new storms. A persistent trough was over the Western U.S. with an embedded cut-off low, with a downstream ridge over the Upper Midwest. Fairly weak southwest flow was over the Central Plains. In advance of the storms, temperatures had risen into the 80s with dewpoints in the 60s. Combined with mid-level lapse rates near 7.5 C/km, this resulted in MLCAPE between 2500 and 3000 J/kg. Deep layer shear was around 30 kts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Storm total precipitation of 3.81 inches was measured by the Phillipsburg Airport AWOS.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Storms produced very heavy rain, localized hail and wind damage, and even a brief tornado over north central Kansas on this Tuesday afternoon and evening. Around 2 PM CST, several thunderstorms rapidly developed southwest-to-northeast across Rooks and Smith counties. These storms merged into a line as they moved east and gradually evolved into two multicell clusters. Each cluster tracked across portions of Jewell, and Osborne and Mitchell counties. The Jewell County storm become a very small bow echo, but with no wind damage reported. However, some wind damage did occur over southeastern Osborne County where wood framing and metal sheeting were blown off an outbuilding on one farm. A hay rake and two empty grain trailers were also blown over. Hail occurred in many places, with the largest 2 inches in diameter over south central Mitchell County. This same storm produced a brief tornado that resembled an elephant trunk. As these storms moved into northeast Kansas, other storms continued to initiate near Interstate 70 and began lifting into southern Osborne and Mitchell counties after 6 PM CST. The axis of storms stopped lifting north and repeated storm development occurred over southern Osborne and Mitchell counties, between 7 and 11 PM CST, resulting in total rainfall amounts between 2.50 and 5.18 inches. The highest amount of 5.18 inches fell just southeast of Tipton. Flash flooding occurred in low-lying spots from southeast Osborne across central Mitchell counties, with water over multiple county roads. Flooding resulted in a washout where bridge work was being performed in Mitchell county on Victor road, between P and Q roads.||A low pressure system was near Lake Superior with a slow-moving cold front extending southwest across Kansas to the Oklahoma Panhandle. In the upper-levels, southwest flow covered most of the U.S., with a trough over the West and a ridge over the Northeast. Just prior to thunderstorm development, temperatures were in the lower to middle 80s with dewpoints in the lower 60s. With mid-level lapse rates near 8 C/km, MLCAPE was 2000-2500 J/kg. Deep layer shear was 40-50 kts, which was more than sufficient for severe thunderstorms.

A cold front moving southward across eastern Nebraska and western Iowa caused some flash freezing conditions on wet roadway surfaces.  In addition an area of snow developed behind the front.  Amounts between 3 to 5 inches fell over southeast Nebraska and southwest Iowa.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A total of 3.5 inches of snow fell in Nebraska City.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moving southward across eastern Nebraska and western Iowa caused some flash freezing conditions on wet roadway surfaces.  In addition an area of snow developed behind the front.  Amounts between 3 to 5 inches fell over southeast Nebraska and southwest Iowa.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A storm total of 3 inches of snow was reported at Offutt Air Force Base.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moving southward across eastern Nebraska and western Iowa caused some flash freezing conditions on wet roadway surfaces.  In addition an area of snow developed behind the front.  Amounts between 3 to 5 inches fell over southeast Nebraska and southwest Iowa.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Total snowfall reported at Bellevue was 2 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A major winter storm moved into the Central Plains on the 22nd.  A band of snow dumped over 10 inches of snow over a large area of northeast Nebraska.  Amounts of snow ranged from 1.8 inches in Lincoln to 17.6 inches in Bloomfield.  The largest amounts included 10 inches in Albion, 12.5 inches near Wakefield, 14 inches at Neligh, 14.6 inches at Norfolk, 15 inches at Stanton, and 16 inches at Pierce.  The heavy snow combined with strong winds created blizzard conditions across a large area of Northeastern Nebraska.  Roads were closed, and traffic came to a standstill on many highways.  Numerous power outages were reported as far south as Omaha.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High winds and heavy snowfall occurred across much of Butler County.  Whiteout conditions and zero visibility was experienced by motorists. Snowfall across the county ranged from 5 to 7 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms, several that were severe, broke out across Kansas late in the afternoon and continued well into the night. The severe thunderstorms were prolific wind producers as 60-70 mph speeds were reported in many areas throughout the event.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: No damage was reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A few isolated severe reports over a few days were noted across central Kansas.
A few isolated severe reports over a few days were noted across central Kansas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Fifty mph winds accompanied the hail.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Though not reported, it's very likely the baseball-sized hail caused damage on the northwest side of El Dorado.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A storm system dropped south across central sections of the state.  It started out as just below severe criteria before they exploded into a significant situation.  One tornado occurred with a long swath of winds between 75 and 90 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The trained spotter measured 70 mph on his Davis Weather Station.
