EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A couple thunderstorms briefly became severe on this Tuesday. Scattered showers and thunderstorms occurred throughout the day. During the late afternoon and early evening hours, a couple storms produced low-end severe weather, with a single report of 3/4 inch hail just south of the airport in Hastings. A separate storm may have produced severe winds in southern Thayer County where a spotter estimated winds around 60 mph near the town of Hubbell. However, three other spotters nearby estimated winds at 50 mph. The storm that produced these winds evolved into a small bow shape at the northern end of a large MCS that had developed over north central and central Kansas.||Weak flow was over the United States as the polar jet stream was unusually far to the north over Canada. A slow-moving cut-off low was over western South Dakota. During the day, a shortwave trough south of the low moved from Colorado into the Central Plains. A ridge was over the Great Lakes with another cut-off low over the Gulf Coast. The pressure pattern at the surface was extremely weak over the Central Plains. Temperatures were in the lower 80s with dewpoints near upper 60s. Mid-level lapse rates were 7-7.5 C/km, but MLCAPE was only 500 J/kg. Deep layer shear was around 40 kts due to a strong upper-level jet streak accompanying the trough.

Severe storms produced some hail and a little wind damage on this Tuesday afternoon and early evening. Around 4 PM CST, thunderstorms began forming over Rooks County and, by 5 PM, storm mergers resulted in the formation of a short line segment that extended from southwest to northeast. As this line expanded into Osborne County, other scattered storms formed over Smith, Jewell, and Mitchell counties. These storms joined others over central Kansas, as an MCS developed and a common cold pool formed. The large line of storms that evolved exited Smith, Jewell, and Mitchell counties by 7 PM. As a result, the initial line segment of storms rapidly weakened. The new line became severe over parts of Rooks, Osborne, and Mitchell counties, producing hail up to the size of ping pong balls along with high winds. Power lines were knocked down in Cawker City. Minor street flooding was reported in Beloit where an automated mesonet station measured 2.48 inches of rain in an hour and 15 minutes.||Weak flow was over the United States as the polar jet stream was unusually far to the north over Canada. A slow-moving cut-off low was over western South Dakota. During the day, a shortwave trough south of the low moved from Colorado into the Central Plains. A ridge was over the Great Lakes with another cut-off low over the Gulf Coast. The pressure pattern at the surface was extremely weak over the Central Plains. Just prior to thunderstorm development, temperatures were in the lower 80s with dewpoints in the upper 60s. Mid-level lapse rates were 7-7.5 C/km, but MLCAPE was only 1000-1500 J/kg. Deep layer shear was around 40 kts due to a strong upper-level jet streak accompanying the trough.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail ranging in size from quarters to half dollars was reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe storms produced numerous reports of hail and 3 brief, weak tornadoes on this Tuesday afternoon and evening. Between 230 and 330 PM CST, scattered fairly small supercell thunderstorms developed along a line from Red Cloud to Grand Island to Columbus. They were not mini-supercells, though, as cloud tops were near 40,000 ft. The storms generally remained along that line except for one storm that moved east into Clay County and another small multicell cluster that moved east along the Nebraska-Kansas border. Nearly 30 occurrences of severe hail were reported with most of between the sizes of quarters and golf balls. The largest hail reported was 2 inches in diameter in the town of Roseland. Three brief EF-0 tornadoes also occurred. The storms from Grand Island to Columbus formed along a slow-moving cold front. One tornado was associated with a supercell located on or very close to the front just west of Aurora. Another tornado formed near Doniphan as a north-northeastward-moving storm crossed the front. The third tornado occurred with the storm that moved east along the Nebraska-Kansas border. This storm evolved from a small bow echo and exhibited a spiral shape as it produced a brief tornado near Chester. The storms dissipated or moved out of south central Nebraska by 6 PM CST.||A low pressure system was near Lake Superior with a slow-moving cold front extending southwest across Nebraska to the Oklahoma Panhandle. In the upper-levels, southwest flow covered most of the U.S., with a trough over the West and a ridge over the Northeast. Just prior to thunderstorm development, temperatures were in the lower 80s with dewpoints in the upper 50s to near 60. With mid-level lapse rates near 8 C/km, MLCAPE was 2000-2500 J/kg. Deep layer shear was 40-50 kts, which was more than sufficient for supercell convective mode.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Quarter to golf ball size hail was reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A major winter storm moved into the Central Plains on the 22nd.  A band of snow dumped over 10 inches of snow over a large area of northeast Nebraska.  Amounts of snow ranged from 1.8 inches in Lincoln to 17.6 inches in Bloomfield.  The largest amounts included 10 inches in Albion, 12.5 inches near Wakefield, 14 inches at Neligh, 14.6 inches at Norfolk, 15 inches at Stanton, and 16 inches at Pierce.  The heavy snow combined with strong winds created blizzard conditions across a large area of Northeastern Nebraska.  Roads were closed, and traffic came to a standstill on many highways.  Numerous power outages were reported as far south as Omaha.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Blizzard conditions caused difficult travel on roads.  Law enforcement officials reported 3 to 4 foot snow drifts at 0900 CST and recommended no one travel on highways. An observer at Neligh reported 14 inches of snow from the storm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A few isolated severe reports over a few days were noted across central Kansas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind was measured at Strother field airport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms, several that were severe, broke out across Kansas late in the afternoon and continued well into the night. The severe thunderstorms were prolific wind producers as 60-70 mph speeds were reported in many areas throughout the event.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Fifty mph winds were also reported. This report came in via social media.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A few thunderstorms developed in Central Kansas in the morning, primarily over Barton County where golf ball-sized hail was reported 5 miles south/southwest of Great Bend. That afternoon and evening, the severe thunderstorms increased considerably as a weak cold front moved across South-Central and Southeast Kansas into a moisture-rich environment. Both large hail, which at times was very large, was the primary severe weather mode early in the event while damaging winds were the dominant mode as the event progressed. One rapidly developing thunderstorm did produce a strong tornado over Greenwood County that touched down on the southwest side of Eureka.  The tornado tore a path through town from southwest to northeast, producing EF3 damage on the northeast side of town.  Eight injuries occurred with the tornado but fortunately none were life-threatening.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of severe thunderstorms surged southeast from Russell County, through Barton and Ellsworth Counties, to as far southeast as Sedgwick County very early in the morning on the 29th. Damage was limited to trees, but considering how strong the winds were, one would have to believe there was considerable property damage and downed power poles as well.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A delayed report was received of tree limbs around 8 inches in diameter that had been blown down. The report was received via social media.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A couple thunderstorms briefly became severe on this Tuesday. Scattered showers and thunderstorms occurred throughout the day. During the late afternoon and early evening hours, a couple storms produced low-end severe weather, with a single report of 3/4 inch hail just south of the airport in Hastings. A separate storm may have produced severe winds in southern Thayer County where a spotter estimated winds around 60 mph near the town of Hubbell. However, three other spotters nearby estimated winds at 50 mph. The storm that produced these winds evolved into a small bow shape at the northern end of a large MCS that had developed over north central and central Kansas.||Weak flow was over the United States as the polar jet stream was unusually far to the north over Canada. A slow-moving cut-off low was over western South Dakota. During the day, a shortwave trough south of the low moved from Colorado into the Central Plains. A ridge was over the Great Lakes with another cut-off low over the Gulf Coast. The pressure pattern at the surface was extremely weak over the Central Plains. Temperatures were in the lower 80s with dewpoints near upper 60s. Mid-level lapse rates were 7-7.5 C/km, but MLCAPE was only 500 J/kg. Deep layer shear was around 40 kts due to a strong upper-level jet streak accompanying the trough.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts were estimated to be near 60 MPH.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe storms produced some hail and a little wind damage on this Tuesday afternoon and early evening. Around 4 PM CST, thunderstorms began forming over Rooks County and, by 5 PM, storm mergers resulted in the formation of a short line segment that extended from southwest to northeast. As this line expanded into Osborne County, other scattered storms formed over Smith, Jewell, and Mitchell counties. These storms joined others over central Kansas, as an MCS developed and a common cold pool formed. The large line of storms that evolved exited Smith, Jewell, and Mitchell counties by 7 PM. As a result, the initial line segment of storms rapidly weakened. The new line became severe over parts of Rooks, Osborne, and Mitchell counties, producing hail up to the size of ping pong balls along with high winds. Power lines were knocked down in Cawker City. Minor street flooding was reported in Beloit where an automated mesonet station measured 2.48 inches of rain in an hour and 15 minutes.||Weak flow was over the United States as the polar jet stream was unusually far to the north over Canada. A slow-moving cut-off low was over western South Dakota. During the day, a shortwave trough south of the low moved from Colorado into the Central Plains. A ridge was over the Great Lakes with another cut-off low over the Gulf Coast. The pressure pattern at the surface was extremely weak over the Central Plains. Just prior to thunderstorm development, temperatures were in the lower 80s with dewpoints in the upper 60s. Mid-level lapse rates were 7-7.5 C/km, but MLCAPE was only 1000-1500 J/kg. Deep layer shear was around 40 kts due to a strong upper-level jet streak accompanying the trough.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe storms produced numerous reports of hail and 3 brief, weak tornadoes on this Tuesday afternoon and evening. Between 230 and 330 PM CST, scattered fairly small supercell thunderstorms developed along a line from Red Cloud to Grand Island to Columbus. They were not mini-supercells, though, as cloud tops were near 40,000 ft. The storms generally remained along that line except for one storm that moved east into Clay County and another small multicell cluster that moved east along the Nebraska-Kansas border. Nearly 30 occurrences of severe hail were reported with most of between the sizes of quarters and golf balls. The largest hail reported was 2 inches in diameter in the town of Roseland. Three brief EF-0 tornadoes also occurred. The storms from Grand Island to Columbus formed along a slow-moving cold front. One tornado was associated with a supercell located on or very close to the front just west of Aurora. Another tornado formed near Doniphan as a north-northeastward-moving storm crossed the front. The third tornado occurred with the storm that moved east along the Nebraska-Kansas border. This storm evolved from a small bow echo and exhibited a spiral shape as it produced a brief tornado near Chester. The storms dissipated or moved out of south central Nebraska by 6 PM CST.||A low pressure system was near Lake Superior with a slow-moving cold front extending southwest across Nebraska to the Oklahoma Panhandle. In the upper-levels, southwest flow covered most of the U.S., with a trough over the West and a ridge over the Northeast. Just prior to thunderstorm development, temperatures were in the lower 80s with dewpoints in the upper 50s to near 60. With mid-level lapse rates near 8 C/km, MLCAPE was 2000-2500 J/kg. Deep layer shear was 40-50 kts, which was more than sufficient for supercell convective mode.

The storms generally remained along that line except for one storm that moved east into Clay County and another small multicell cluster that moved east along the Nebraska-Kansas border. EVENT_NARRATIVE: This tornado touched down approximately 2 miles south of Doniphan and moved north before lifting on the south edge of Doniphan. The tornado was rated an EF-0 with a maximum wind speed estimated to be 75 MPH. This rating was based on damage to an outbuilding and nearby home. The damage to the home was caused by flying debris from the outbuilding. Other structures in the area sustained minor damage, such as broken windows, damage to soffits and garage doors. ||The path was determined from a combination of storm survey information, video, radar data, and other reports. Several reports indicate the possibility of other small circulations near the parent tornado, but the most reliable path information is related to the main parent circulation as given.

Severe thunderstorms produced widespread high winds between Interstate 80 and Highway 6 on this Thursday night and Friday morning. During the mid to late-afternoon hours Thursday, scattered thunderstorms developed from the Nebraska Panhandle down into northeast Colorado. Storm mergers, and an increasing number of storms, resulted in the formation of a squall line by 700 PM CST. This line of storms crossed most of south central Nebraska between 10 PM CST on the 10th and 1 AM CST on the 11th. These storms produced widespread measured gusts between 58 and 70 mph along the entire way across south central Nebraska from the Interstate 80 corridor south to Highway 6. A couple unofficial weather stations measured higher wind speeds including 80 mph near Axtell and 78 near Norman, both in Kearney County. Despite the coverage and magnitude of the winds, damage was only reported in a few spots. Tree branches were snapped off in Minden, an irrigation pivot was overturned near Glenvil, a few trees were blown down in Central City, and six utility poles were blown down or snapped off near Harvard. There were reports in southern Adams County and western Clay County of zero visibility in blowing dust as the high winds from the outflow moved in before the rain fell. Farmers had been preparing the fields for planting. So, top soil was loose and available for easy lofting and transport. Behind the squall line, other scattered thunderstorms developed. The strongest storms moved east along the entire length of Interstate 80 from Lexington to York between 1230 AM and 330 AM CST. These storms were mostly sub-severe, but there was a single report of one inch hail in Kearney at 2 AM CST.||During the morning hours of Thursday, a strong southward-moving cold front crossed Nebraska and became stationary along the northern Kansas border. A low pressure center formed over Wyoming and, by early evening, began moving east along the front. Meanwhile, chilly high pressure moved from the Canadian Prairies into the Great Lakes region. A broad upper-level ridge was over the Plains with a trough along the East Coast and another trough advancing through the western states. MUCAPE was around 1500 J/kg immediately preceding the storms. These storms formed on the northeast fringe of an elevated mixed layer that was advecting into the region, ahead of the western trough. Deep layer shear was 50 kts and greater. This environment was more than sufficient for severe thunderstorms. The cold pool associated with the squall line was strong. The temperature at Lexington dropped 16 deg F in 20 minutes (76 to 60 deg F) as the gust front moved through, and 23 deg in 40 min (76 to 53 deg F).
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts estimated to be near 65 MPH resulted in multiple downed tree branches in Minden.

A major winter storm moved into the Central Plains on the 22nd.  A band of snow dumped over 10 inches of snow over a large area of northeast Nebraska.  Amounts of snow ranged from 1.8 inches in Lincoln to 17.6 inches in Bloomfield.  The largest amounts included 10 inches in Albion, 12.5 inches near Wakefield, 14 inches at Neligh, 14.6 inches at Norfolk, 15 inches at Stanton, and 16 inches at Pierce.  The heavy snow combined with strong winds created blizzard conditions across a large area of Northeastern Nebraska.  Roads were closed, and traffic came to a standstill on many highways.  Numerous power outages were reported as far south as Omaha.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Whiteout conditions were reported across the county.  Snowfall in Seward was around 3 inches. There was an accident on Interstate 80 where 14 vehicles piled up in Seward County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A major winter storm moved into the Central Plains on the 22nd.  A band of snow dumped over 10 inches of snow over a large area of northeast Nebraska.  Amounts of snow ranged from 1.8 inches in Lincoln to 17.6 inches in Bloomfield.  The largest amounts included 10 inches in Albion, 12.5 inches near Wakefield, 14 inches at Neligh, 14.6 inches at Norfolk, 15 inches at Stanton, and 16 inches at Pierce.  The heavy snow combined with strong winds created blizzard conditions across a large area of Northeastern Nebraska.  Roads were closed, and traffic came to a standstill on many highways.  Numerous power outages were reported as far south as Omaha.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Intense winds combined with a snow total of 15 produced blizzard conditions across Stanton County.  U.S. Highway 275 was closed between Nebraska Highway 15 and 57 due to several wrecks and jackknifed semi trucks.  Sixteen people had to be rescued from their vehicles on U.S. 275 in Stanton County.  There were some snow drifts as high as 7 feet tall on east-west roads in the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moving southward across eastern Nebraska and western Iowa caused some flash freezing conditions on wet roadway surfaces.  In addition an area of snow developed behind the front.  Amounts between 3 to 5 inches fell over southeast Nebraska and southwest Iowa.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A total of 3.5 inches of snow was reported at Murray.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A few thunderstorms developed in Central Kansas in the morning, primarily over Barton County where golf ball-sized hail was reported 5 miles south/southwest of Great Bend. That afternoon and evening, the severe thunderstorms increased considerably as a weak cold front moved across South-Central and Southeast Kansas into a moisture-rich environment. Both large hail, which at times was very large, was the primary severe weather mode early in the event while damaging winds were the dominant mode as the event progressed. One rapidly developing thunderstorm did produce a strong tornado over Greenwood County that touched down on the southwest side of Eureka.  The tornado tore a path through town from southwest to northeast, producing EF3 damage on the northeast side of town.  Eight injuries occurred with the tornado but fortunately none were life-threatening.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This was a Twitter report of hail that was slightly larger than quarters.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A couple of isolated wind events occurred across central Kansas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lincoln county Sheriff reported a shed had been blown over with some damaged power lines in the area.  The report was relayed via via NWS Topeka.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A couple of isolated wind events occurred across central Kansas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several trees and power lines were blown down in the city of Lindsborg.  In addition, a garage door was partially damaged.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong storms producing large hail and high winds moved across much of southern Kansas on the 11th.

A line of severe thunderstorms surged southeast from Russell County, through Barton and Ellsworth Counties, to as far southeast as Sedgwick County very early in the morning on the 29th. Damage was limited to trees, but considering how strong the winds were, one would have to believe there was considerable property damage and downed power poles as well.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There were no reports of damage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe storms produced some hail and a little wind damage on this Tuesday afternoon and early evening. Around 4 PM CST, thunderstorms began forming over Rooks County and, by 5 PM, storm mergers resulted in the formation of a short line segment that extended from southwest to northeast. As this line expanded into Osborne County, other scattered storms formed over Smith, Jewell, and Mitchell counties. These storms joined others over central Kansas, as an MCS developed and a common cold pool formed. The large line of storms that evolved exited Smith, Jewell, and Mitchell counties by 7 PM. As a result, the initial line segment of storms rapidly weakened. The new line became severe over parts of Rooks, Osborne, and Mitchell counties, producing hail up to the size of ping pong balls along with high winds. Power lines were knocked down in Cawker City. Minor street flooding was reported in Beloit where an automated mesonet station measured 2.48 inches of rain in an hour and 15 minutes.||Weak flow was over the United States as the polar jet stream was unusually far to the north over Canada. A slow-moving cut-off low was over western South Dakota. During the day, a shortwave trough south of the low moved from Colorado into the Central Plains. A ridge was over the Great Lakes with another cut-off low over the Gulf Coast. The pressure pattern at the surface was extremely weak over the Central Plains. Just prior to thunderstorm development, temperatures were in the lower 80s with dewpoints in the upper 60s. Mid-level lapse rates were 7-7.5 C/km, but MLCAPE was only 1000-1500 J/kg. Deep layer shear was around 40 kts due to a strong upper-level jet streak accompanying the trough.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: After a very dry summer, exceptional drought (D4) conditions were experienced area-wide, resulting in heavy losses for local farmers. Things changed in October when widespread heavy rain effectively ended that drought. Widespread 6 to 9 inches of rain fell, with some locations receiving over a foot of rain over the 4 day stretch from October 6 through October 9. By October 9th, the drought was effectively ended by the UNL drought monitor.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Due to widespread dry conditions through the summer and early fall of 2018 most counties experienced extreme to exceptional drought (D3-D4). While some counties saw marked improvement through the late summer and early fall the drought continued into the second week of October. The drought improved area-wide after 6-12 inches of rain fell in a four day stretch in early October. This effectively ended the drought area-wide. While the exact damage costs are unknown, it is estimated that farmer across the entire region suffered millions of dollars of losses due to the extremely dry conditions.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Periods of moderate to heavy snow fell across much of the Nebraska Panhandle producing in some locations 6 to 8 inches of snow. Heaviest snowfall amounts  reported in Sioux, Morrill and Cheyenne Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observer ten miles south-southeast of Broadwater measured 7.0 inches of heavy snow.

Severe to extreme drought conditions across portions of central and south central Kansas during the month of June, 2018.  But welcome rainfall during the middle and towards the end of the month, actually helped with drought conditions across portions of central Kansas.  Some areas of central Kansas actually received enough rainfall to drop out of a severe drought.  The areas still in extreme drought were located along the Little Arkansas River basin from McPherson to Newton to Wichita.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Severe to extreme drought conditions persisted over the entire county during the month of June 2018.  Welcome rainfall did occur by the end of the month which actually improved the drought in western sections of the county by the end of the month.

One rapidly developing thunderstorm did produce a strong tornado over Greenwood County that touched down on the southwest side of Eureka. EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of thunderstorms produced damaging winds in Richardson County which blew down a tree and caused the power to be lost to all of the residents of Rulo.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree was blown down in Rulo from thunderstorm winds.  All of Rulo was without power for about one hour due to the thunderstorm.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Severe to extreme drought conditions persisted over the entire county for the early portions of June 2018. But welcome rainfall during the middle and end of the month improved drought conditions considerably by the end of the month.

The areas still in extreme drought were located along the Little Arkansas River basin from McPherson to Newton to Wichita.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Severe drought conditions persisted over the entire county for the month of June 2018.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe storms produced some hail and a little wind damage on this Tuesday afternoon and early evening. Around 4 PM CST, thunderstorms began forming over Rooks County and, by 5 PM, storm mergers resulted in the formation of a short line segment that extended from southwest to northeast. As this line expanded into Osborne County, other scattered storms formed over Smith, Jewell, and Mitchell counties. These storms joined others over central Kansas, as an MCS developed and a common cold pool formed. The large line of storms that evolved exited Smith, Jewell, and Mitchell counties by 7 PM. As a result, the initial line segment of storms rapidly weakened. The new line became severe over parts of Rooks, Osborne, and Mitchell counties, producing hail up to the size of ping pong balls along with high winds. Power lines were knocked down in Cawker City. Minor street flooding was reported in Beloit where an automated mesonet station measured 2.48 inches of rain in an hour and 15 minutes.||Weak flow was over the United States as the polar jet stream was unusually far to the north over Canada. A slow-moving cut-off low was over western South Dakota. During the day, a shortwave trough south of the low moved from Colorado into the Central Plains. A ridge was over the Great Lakes with another cut-off low over the Gulf Coast. The pressure pattern at the surface was extremely weak over the Central Plains. Just prior to thunderstorm development, temperatures were in the lower 80s with dewpoints in the upper 60s. Mid-level lapse rates were 7-7.5 C/km, but MLCAPE was only 1000-1500 J/kg. Deep layer shear was around 40 kts due to a strong upper-level jet streak accompanying the trough.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A mesonet recorded 2.48 inches of rain, with most falling in 1 hour and 15 minutes. This rain resulted in some minor street flooding in Beloit.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Starting on October 6th, the atmosphere set itself up in a pattern conducive to bring a prolonged period of heavy rain to portions of northeastern Kansas and northwestern Missouri. The heaviest rain occurred Saturday and Sunday (Oct 6-7). By Tuesday night (October 9th) more than 11 inches of rain fell in and around the Kansas City Metro. Local drought conditions were still in the Extreme to Exceptional category going into the event, so flash flooding was relatively low impact, relegated mostly to several road closures. The bigger impact from this prolonged rainfall event came from local river and stream flooding. Several streams entered the moderate to major flooding category. The 4 day event spanning Oct 6-9 resulted in the greatest 4 day rain total in recorded Kansas City History. At Kansas City International Airport 9.79 inches were recorded for the Oct 6-9 time period, beating out Sept 12-15, 1977, which had 9.48 over the 4 day span.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple limbs were down, shingles were off a garage, and a tin shed roof was blown off. Witness reported winds lasted 3 minutes.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: During a stretch where 6-9 inches of rain fell across the region in a short couple days, isolated flash flooding occurred in various places. In this case, Kansas State Highway Route 5 was closed near Lansing due to fast moving water.

An isolated cell within an area of thunderstorms produced quarter size hail and damaging winds that blew down tree limbs.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A major winter storm moved into the Central Plains on the 22nd.  A band of snow dumped over 10 inches of snow over a large area of northeast Nebraska.  Amounts of snow ranged from 1.8 inches in Lincoln to 17.6 inches in Bloomfield.  The largest amounts included 10 inches in Albion, 12.5 inches near Wakefield, 14 inches at Neligh, 14.6 inches at Norfolk, 15 inches at Stanton, and 16 inches at Pierce.  The heavy snow combined with strong winds created blizzard conditions across a large area of Northeastern Nebraska.  Roads were closed, and traffic came to a standstill on many highways.  Numerous power outages were reported as far south as Omaha.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The broadcast media relayed a public report of 17 inches of snow 3 miles southeast of St. James.Intense winds also produced blizzard conditions.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A winter storm system brought wide spread precipitation to Northwest Kansas, beginning on the 26th.  The precipitation began as rain then transitioned to snow during the night of the 26th.  Winds became strong as the rain changed over to snow the night of the 26th.  This caused blizzard conditions to occur in the snowfall.  The blizzard conditions swept northeast across Northwest Kansas, ending as the snowfall shifted east.  Multiple accidents and slide-offs were reported on I-70 in Gove County due to the icy roadway and poor visibility.  One of the accidents involved a fatality.  The highest snowfall amount reported was 9.5 southwest of Hoxie.||Besides the snow, high wind gusts also occurred.  A gust of 58 MPH was measured at the Goodland airport, and a 60 MPH gust was measured at the Hill City airport.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Similar winds and radar imagery were observed over Rawlins County compared to counties that reported blizzard conditions.  Snowfall amounts ranged from a trace over the western part of the county to seven inches in the southeast corner of the county.

Storms produced very heavy rain, localized hail and wind damage, and even a brief tornado over north central Kansas on this Tuesday afternoon and evening. Around 2 PM CST, several thunderstorms rapidly developed southwest-to-northeast across Rooks and Smith counties. These storms merged into a line as they moved east and gradually evolved into two multicell clusters. Each cluster tracked across portions of Jewell, and Osborne and Mitchell counties. The Jewell County storm become a very small bow echo, but with no wind damage reported. However, some wind damage did occur over southeastern Osborne County where wood framing and metal sheeting were blown off an outbuilding on one farm. A hay rake and two empty grain trailers were also blown over. Hail occurred in many places, with the largest 2 inches in diameter over south central Mitchell County. This same storm produced a brief tornado that resembled an elephant trunk. As these storms moved into northeast Kansas, other storms continued to initiate near Interstate 70 and began lifting into southern Osborne and Mitchell counties after 6 PM CST. The axis of storms stopped lifting north and repeated storm development occurred over southern Osborne and Mitchell counties, between 7 and 11 PM CST, resulting in total rainfall amounts between 2.50 and 5.18 inches. The highest amount of 5.18 inches fell just southeast of Tipton. Flash flooding occurred in low-lying spots from southeast Osborne across central Mitchell counties, with water over multiple county roads. Flooding resulted in a washout where bridge work was being performed in Mitchell county on Victor road, between P and Q roads.||A low pressure system was near Lake Superior with a slow-moving cold front extending southwest across Kansas to the Oklahoma Panhandle. In the upper-levels, southwest flow covered most of the U.S., with a trough over the West and a ridge over the Northeast. Just prior to thunderstorm development, temperatures were in the lower to middle 80s with dewpoints in the lower 60s. With mid-level lapse rates near 8 C/km, MLCAPE was 2000-2500 J/kg. Deep layer shear was 40-50 kts, which was more than sufficient for severe thunderstorms.

An isolated strong thunderstorm behind a cold front produced pea to nickel size hail across parts of Platte and Colfax County in the mid morning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail up to penny size fell 9 miles north of Columbus.  Most of the stones were pea size.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An isolated strong thunderstorm behind a cold front produced pea to nickel size hail across parts of Platte and Colfax County in the mid morning.
An isolated strong thunderstorm behind a cold front produced pea to nickel size hail across parts of Platte and Colfax County in the mid morning.

Very little rainfall fell during the winter months with very little snowfall as well.  This led to severe drought conditions creeping into portions of south central Kansas during the month of February 2018. The severe drought conditions worsened during the month, spreading north of Highway 50 and east to the Kansas Turnpike.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Severe drought conditions worsened during the month of February, 2018.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An isolated thunderstorm that visited extreme Southwest Kingman County that evening produced an estimated 60-mph gust 3 miles north of Nashville.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: No damage was reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe to extreme drought conditions across portions of central and south central Kansas during the month of June, 2018.  But welcome rainfall during the middle and towards the end of the month, actually helped with drought conditions across portions of central Kansas.  Some areas of central Kansas actually received enough rainfall to drop out of a severe drought.  The areas still in extreme drought were located along the Little Arkansas River basin from McPherson to Newton to Wichita.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Extreme drought conditions persisted over the northwest portions of county. But welcome rainfall during the end of the month actually improved the drought to severe for southeast portions of the county by the end of the month.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Extreme drought conditions persisted over entire county during the month of June 2018.  Welcome rainfall did occur by the end of the month which actually improved the drought some by the end of the month.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: After a very dry summer, exceptional drought (D4) conditions were experienced area-wide, resulting in heavy losses for local farmers. Things changed in October when widespread heavy rain effectively ended that drought. Widespread 6 to 9 inches of rain fell, with some locations receiving over a foot of rain over the 4 day stretch from October 6 through October 9. By October 9th, the drought was effectively ended by the UNL drought monitor.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Due to widespread dry conditions through the summer and early fall of 2018 most counties experienced extreme to exceptional drought (D3-D4). While some counties saw marked improvement through the late summer and early fall the drought continued into the second week of October. The drought improved area-wide after 6-12 inches of rain fell in a four day stretch in early October. This effectively ended the drought area-wide. While the exact damage costs are unknown, it is estimated that farmer across the entire region suffered millions of dollars of losses due to the extremely dry conditions.

As these storms moved into northeast Kansas, other storms continued to initiate near Interstate 70 and began lifting into southern Osborne and Mitchell counties after 6 PM CST. The axis of storms stopped lifting north and repeated storm development occurred over southern Osborne and Mitchell counties, between 7 and 11 PM CST, resulting in total rainfall amounts between 2.50 and 5.18 inches. The highest amount of 5.18 inches fell just southeast of Tipton. Flash flooding occurred in low-lying spots from southeast Osborne across central Mitchell counties, with water over multiple county roads. Flooding resulted in a washout where bridge work was being performed in Mitchell county on Victor road, between P and Q roads.||A low pressure system was near Lake Superior with a slow-moving cold front extending southwest across Kansas to the Oklahoma Panhandle. In the upper-levels, southwest flow covered most of the U.S., with a trough over the West and a ridge over the Northeast. Just prior to thunderstorm development, temperatures were in the lower to middle 80s with dewpoints in the lower 60s. With mid-level lapse rates near 8 C/km, MLCAPE was 2000-2500 J/kg. Deep layer shear was 40-50 kts, which was more than sufficient for severe thunderstorms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A storm total rainfall amount of 4.50 inches was measured.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms produced widespread high winds between Interstate 80 and Highway 6 on this Thursday night and Friday morning. During the mid to late-afternoon hours Thursday, scattered thunderstorms developed from the Nebraska Panhandle down into northeast Colorado. Storm mergers, and an increasing number of storms, resulted in the formation of a squall line by 700 PM CST. This line of storms crossed most of south central Nebraska between 10 PM CST on the 10th and 1 AM CST on the 11th. These storms produced widespread measured gusts between 58 and 70 mph along the entire way across south central Nebraska from the Interstate 80 corridor south to Highway 6. A couple unofficial weather stations measured higher wind speeds including 80 mph near Axtell and 78 near Norman, both in Kearney County. Despite the coverage and magnitude of the winds, damage was only reported in a few spots. Tree branches were snapped off in Minden, an irrigation pivot was overturned near Glenvil, a few trees were blown down in Central City, and six utility poles were blown down or snapped off near Harvard. There were reports in southern Adams County and western Clay County of zero visibility in blowing dust as the high winds from the outflow moved in before the rain fell. Farmers had been preparing the fields for planting. So, top soil was loose and available for easy lofting and transport. Behind the squall line, other scattered thunderstorms developed. The strongest storms moved east along the entire length of Interstate 80 from Lexington to York between 1230 AM and 330 AM CST. These storms were mostly sub-severe, but there was a single report of one inch hail in Kearney at 2 AM CST.||During the morning hours of Thursday, a strong southward-moving cold front crossed Nebraska and became stationary along the northern Kansas border. A low pressure center formed over Wyoming and, by early evening, began moving east along the front. Meanwhile, chilly high pressure moved from the Canadian Prairies into the Great Lakes region. A broad upper-level ridge was over the Plains with a trough along the East Coast and another trough advancing through the western states. MUCAPE was around 1500 J/kg immediately preceding the storms. These storms formed on the northeast fringe of an elevated mixed layer that was advecting into the region, ahead of the western trough. Deep layer shear was 50 kts and greater. This environment was more than sufficient for severe thunderstorms. The cold pool associated with the squall line was strong. The temperature at Lexington dropped 16 deg F in 20 minutes (76 to 60 deg F) as the gust front moved through, and 23 deg in 40 min (76 to 53 deg F).
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts were estimated to be near 60 MPH.

Severe to extreme drought conditions across portions of central and south central Kansas during the month of June, 2018.  But welcome rainfall during the middle and towards the end of the month, actually helped with drought conditions across portions of central Kansas.  Some areas of central Kansas actually received enough rainfall to drop out of a severe drought.  The areas still in extreme drought were located along the Little Arkansas River basin from McPherson to Newton to Wichita.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Severe drought conditions persisted over the entire county for the month of June 2018.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe to extreme drought conditions across portions of central and south central Kansas during the month of June, 2018.  But welcome rainfall during the middle and towards the end of the month, actually helped with drought conditions across portions of central Kansas.  Some areas of central Kansas actually received enough rainfall to drop out of a severe drought.  The areas still in extreme drought were located along the Little Arkansas River basin from McPherson to Newton to Wichita.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Severe drought conditions were over the entire county for the early portion of the month, but welcome rainfall during the middle and end of the month improved the drought conditions considerably by the end of the month.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Extreme drought conditions persisted over entire county during the month of June 2018.  Welcome rainfall did occur by the end of the month, which actually improved the drought some by the end of the month.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: After a very dry summer, exceptional drought (D4) conditions were experienced area-wide, resulting in heavy losses for local farmers. Things changed in October when widespread heavy rain effectively ended that drought. Widespread 6 to 9 inches of rain fell, with some locations receiving over a foot of rain over the 4 day stretch from October 6 through October 9. By October 9th, the drought was effectively ended by the UNL drought monitor.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Due to widespread dry conditions through the summer and early fall of 2018 most counties experienced extreme to exceptional drought (D3-D4). While some counties saw marked improvement through the late summer and early fall the drought continued into the second week of October. The drought improved area-wide after 6-12 inches of rain fell in a four day stretch in early October. This effectively ended the drought area-wide. While the exact damage costs are unknown, it is estimated that farmer across the entire region suffered millions of dollars of losses due to the extremely dry conditions.

Despite the coverage and magnitude of the winds, damage was only reported in a few spots. Tree branches were snapped off in Minden, an irrigation pivot was overturned near Glenvil, a few trees were blown down in Central City, and six utility poles were blown down or snapped off near Harvard. There were reports in southern Adams County and western Clay County of zero visibility in blowing dust as the high winds from the outflow moved in before the rain fell. Farmers had been preparing the fields for planting. So, top soil was loose and available for easy lofting and transport. Behind the squall line, other scattered thunderstorms developed. The strongest storms moved east along the entire length of Interstate 80 from Lexington to York between 1230 AM and 330 AM CST. These storms were mostly sub-severe, but there was a single report of one inch hail in Kearney at 2 AM CST.||During the morning hours of Thursday, a strong southward-moving cold front crossed Nebraska and became stationary along the northern Kansas border. A low pressure center formed over Wyoming and, by early evening, began moving east along the front. Meanwhile, chilly high pressure moved from the Canadian Prairies into the Great Lakes region. A broad upper-level ridge was over the Plains with a trough along the East Coast and another trough advancing through the western states. MUCAPE was around 1500 J/kg immediately preceding the storms. These storms formed on the northeast fringe of an elevated mixed layer that was advecting into the region, ahead of the western trough. Deep layer shear was 50 kts and greater. This environment was more than sufficient for severe thunderstorms. The cold pool associated with the squall line was strong. The temperature at Lexington dropped 16 deg F in 20 minutes (76 to 60 deg F) as the gust front moved through, and 23 deg in 40 min (76 to 53 deg F).

Severe thunderstorms produced widespread high winds between Interstate 80 and Highway 6 on this Thursday night and Friday morning. During the mid to late-afternoon hours Thursday, scattered thunderstorms developed from the Nebraska Panhandle down into northeast Colorado. Storm mergers, and an increasing number of storms, resulted in the formation of a squall line by 700 PM CST. This line of storms crossed most of south central Nebraska between 10 PM CST on the 10th and 1 AM CST on the 11th. These storms produced widespread measured gusts between 58 and 70 mph along the entire way across south central Nebraska from the Interstate 80 corridor south to Highway 6. A couple unofficial weather stations measured higher wind speeds including 80 mph near Axtell and 78 near Norman, both in Kearney County. Despite the coverage and magnitude of the winds, damage was only reported in a few spots. Tree branches were snapped off in Minden, an irrigation pivot was overturned near Glenvil, a few trees were blown down in Central City, and six utility poles were blown down or snapped off near Harvard. There were reports in southern Adams County and western Clay County of zero visibility in blowing dust as the high winds from the outflow moved in before the rain fell. Farmers had been preparing the fields for planting. So, top soil was loose and available for easy lofting and transport. Behind the squall line, other scattered thunderstorms developed. The strongest storms moved east along the entire length of Interstate 80 from Lexington to York between 1230 AM and 330 AM CST. These storms were mostly sub-severe, but there was a single report of one inch hail in Kearney at 2 AM CST.||During the morning hours of Thursday, a strong southward-moving cold front crossed Nebraska and became stationary along the northern Kansas border. A low pressure center formed over Wyoming and, by early evening, began moving east along the front. Meanwhile, chilly high pressure moved from the Canadian Prairies into the Great Lakes region. A broad upper-level ridge was over the Plains with a trough along the East Coast and another trough advancing through the western states. MUCAPE was around 1500 J/kg immediately preceding the storms. These storms formed on the northeast fringe of an elevated mixed layer that was advecting into the region, ahead of the western trough. Deep layer shear was 50 kts and greater. This environment was more than sufficient for severe thunderstorms. The cold pool associated with the squall line was strong. The temperature at Lexington dropped 16 deg F in 20 minutes (76 to 60 deg F) as the gust front moved through, and 23 deg in 40 min (76 to 53 deg F).

Thunderstorms produced large hail over portions of Kimball and Cheyenne counties.
A thunderstorm produced large hail in western Cheyenne County.

During a roughly 36-hour period between the morning of Saturday the 1st and the evening of Sunday the 2nd, South Central Nebraska observed off-and-on rounds of snow, with cumulative totals generally ranging from 1-4 in most counties along/east of Highway 281, to generally 3-5 in most counties west of Highway 281. A couple of exceptions to this lower east/higher west generalization included Greeley and Polk counties, which (like many western areas) picked up a solid 3-5. Per NWS cooperative observers, some of the highest official totals featured: 5.5 in Holdrege, 5.1 near Shelby, 5.0 in Beaver City, 4.9 at Kearney, 4.7 in Cambridge and 4.5 in Ord. While this was not a true blizzard by any means, occasional visibility reductions to one-half mile or less were noted, especially on the afternoon and evening of the 1st, when sustained north winds of 20-25 MPH and frequent gusts of 30-40 MPH were most prevalent. ||Backing up in time a bit, snow was not the only story associated with this long-duration event, as it actually started off as a significant late-autumn rain-producer. In fact, most of the 24-county area measured 1-2 of soaking rain between the afternoon of Nov. 30th and the morning of the 1st, before precipitation finally switched over to snow. Due in part to much of the initial precipitation falling as rain, along with the fact that a significant batch of mid-level dry air got wrapped into the heart of the parent low pressure system, snowfall totals in most of the area fell well-short of expectations (many places only received about half of what was originally forecasted). In the mid-upper levels, the main driving force was a strong, slow-moving low pressure system that tracked from south central KS on the morning of the 1st to the IA/MO border area by the morning of the 2nd before weakening and shearing-out eastward into the Midwest. The intermittent areas of snow that persisted across the local area through most of the 1st-2nd were supported by weaker lobes of energy rotating around the backside of the parent system. At the surface, the associated low pressure center peaked in intensity around 988 millibars over eastern KS on the 1st, thus driving the modestly-strong north winds over Nebraska.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A snowfall total of 2.4 inches occurred at WFO Hastings, NE. North wind gusts of 35 to 45 mph developed the afternoon of December 1st, lasting into the overnight. This sent visibility down to one mile or less at times.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A winter storm produced heavy snowfall beginning in the early morning hours on December 1st, continuing into the early morning hours on December 2nd across most of western and north central Nebraska. Snowfall amounts ranged from 6 to 14 inches across much of the area with the higher amounts occurring across north central into west central Nebraska.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: General public located 45 miles south of Cody reported 14 inches of snowfall. Moderate to heavy snow occurred during the morning into the afternoon hours on December 1st. North winds of 15 to 25 mph caused areas of blowing and drifting snow with visibility frequently reduced to a half mile. Snowfall amounts ranged from 7 to 14 inches across western Cherry County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A winter storm produced heavy snowfall beginning in the early morning hours on December 1st, continuing into the early morning hours on December 2nd across most of western and north central Nebraska. Snowfall amounts ranged from 6 to 14 inches across much of the area with the higher amounts occurring across north central into west central Nebraska.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: General public located 5 miles east of Gordon reported 6.5 inches of snowfall. Light to moderate snow occurred during the morning into the afternoon hours on December 1st. Snowfall amounts ranged from 5 to 8 inches across Sheridan County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow fell across portions of Scotts Bluff and Banner Counties on the evening of the 16th ending in the evening of the 17th. Snowfall of over six inches reported across the cities of Gering and Melbeta while eight inches of snowfall was reported at the Banner County Sheriff's Office in Harrisburg.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Six inches of heavy snowfall was measured in the town of Melbeta.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A winter storm began in the afternoon hours on December 26th, continuing into the early morning hours on December 28th across the eastern half of western and north central Nebraska. Strong northwest winds of 25 to 35 mph with gusts to 45 mph occurred during the peak of the storm. This created low visibility and significant blowing and drifting. Blizzard conditions were observed in some areas. Some roads, including Interstate 80 west of North Platte became closed on December 27th. Snowfall amounts ranged from 5 to 12 inches across much of the area with the higher amounts occurring across Thomas, Blaine, Loup, and Custer Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A social media report from Bassett reported 10 inches of snowfall with 2 foot drifts. Snowfall amounts ranged from 5 to 10 inches across Rock County. Strong northwest winds of 25 to 35 mph with gusts to 45 mph occurred beginning during the early morning hours, daytime and evening hours on December 27th into the early morning hours on December 28th. This created low visibility and significant blowing and drifting.

Blizzard conditions were observed in some areas. Some roads, including Interstate 80 west of North Platte became closed on December 27th. Snowfall amounts ranged from 5 to 12 inches across much of the area with the higher amounts occurring across Thomas, Blaine, Loup, and Custer Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A Cooperative observer in O'Neill reported 6 inches of snowfall. Snowfall amounts ranged from 5 to 8 inches across Holt County. Strong northwest winds of 25 to 35 mph with gusts to 45 mph occurred beginning during the early morning hours, daytime and evening hours on December 27th into the early morning hours on December 28th. This created low visibility and significant blowing and drifting.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During a roughly 36-hour period between the morning of Saturday the 1st and the evening of Sunday the 2nd, South Central Nebraska observed off-and-on rounds of snow, with cumulative totals generally ranging from 1-4 in most counties along/east of Highway 281, to generally 3-5 in most counties west of Highway 281. A couple of exceptions to this lower east/higher west generalization included Greeley and Polk counties, which (like many western areas) picked up a solid 3-5. Per NWS cooperative observers, some of the highest official totals featured: 5.5 in Holdrege, 5.1 near Shelby, 5.0 in Beaver City, 4.9 at Kearney, 4.7 in Cambridge and 4.5 in Ord. While this was not a true blizzard by any means, occasional visibility reductions to one-half mile or less were noted, especially on the afternoon and evening of the 1st, when sustained north winds of 20-25 MPH and frequent gusts of 30-40 MPH were most prevalent. ||Backing up in time a bit, snow was not the only story associated with this long-duration event, as it actually started off as a significant late-autumn rain-producer. In fact, most of the 24-county area measured 1-2 of soaking rain between the afternoon of Nov. 30th and the morning of the 1st, before precipitation finally switched over to snow. Due in part to much of the initial precipitation falling as rain, along with the fact that a significant batch of mid-level dry air got wrapped into the heart of the parent low pressure system, snowfall totals in most of the area fell well-short of expectations (many places only received about half of what was originally forecasted). In the mid-upper levels, the main driving force was a strong, slow-moving low pressure system that tracked from south central KS on the morning of the 1st to the IA/MO border area by the morning of the 2nd before weakening and shearing-out eastward into the Midwest. The intermittent areas of snow that persisted across the local area through most of the 1st-2nd were supported by weaker lobes of energy rotating around the backside of the parent system. At the surface, the associated low pressure center peaked in intensity around 988 millibars over eastern KS on the 1st, thus driving the modestly-strong north winds over Nebraska.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A snowfall total of 2.3 inches occurred at the Central Nebraska Regional Airport in Grand Island. North wind gusts of 35 to 45 mph developed the afternoon of December 1st, lasting into the overnight. This sent visibility down to one mile or less at times.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A snowfall total of 5.1 inches occurred 3 miles northeast of Shelby, with blowing snow and visibility of one quarter to one half mile. Also, 4.3 inches occurred in Osceola, with periods of sleet reported early on Dec. 1st before the precipitation turned into all snow, along with windy conditions. Polk also received 3.0 inches of snow. North wind gusts of 35 to 45 mph developed the afternoon of December 1st, lasting into the overnight.

A couple of exceptions to this lower east/higher west generalization included Greeley and Polk counties, which (like many western areas) picked up a solid 3-5. Per NWS cooperative observers, some of the highest official totals featured: 5.5 in Holdrege, 5.1 near Shelby, 5.0 in Beaver City, 4.9 at Kearney, 4.7 in Cambridge and 4.5 in Ord. While this was not a true blizzard by any means, occasional visibility reductions to one-half mile or less were noted, especially on the afternoon and evening of the 1st, when sustained north winds of 20-25 MPH and frequent gusts of 30-40 MPH were most prevalent. ||Backing up in time a bit, snow was not the only story associated with this long-duration event, as it actually started off as a significant late-autumn rain-producer. In fact, most of the 24-county area measured 1-2 of soaking rain between the afternoon of Nov. 30th and the morning of the 1st, before precipitation finally switched over to snow. Due in part to much of the initial precipitation falling as rain, along with the fact that a significant batch of mid-level dry air got wrapped into the heart of the parent low pressure system, snowfall totals in most of the area fell well-short of expectations (many places only received about half of what was originally forecasted). In the mid-upper levels, the main driving force was a strong, slow-moving low pressure system that tracked from south central KS on the morning of the 1st to the IA/MO border area by the morning of the 2nd before weakening and shearing-out eastward into the Midwest. The intermittent areas of snow that persisted across the local area through most of the 1st-2nd were supported by weaker lobes of energy rotating around the backside of the parent system. At the surface, the associated low pressure center peaked in intensity around 988 millibars over eastern KS on the 1st, thus driving the modestly-strong north winds over Nebraska.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A snowfall total of at least 2.0 was reported six miles north of Aurora by a CoCoRaHS observer. North wind gusts of 35 to 45 mph developed the afternoon of December 1st, lasting into the overnight. This sent visibility down to one mile or less at times.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Although only 1.4 of snow was reported in St. Paul, snowfall analysis maps indicate that much of Howard County likely received 2-3 during this event. North wind gusts of 35 to 45 mph developed the afternoon of December 1st, lasting into the overnight. This sent visibility down to one mile or less at times.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The first true blizzard of the 2018-19 winter season struck much of the northwest half of South Central Nebraska on this Thursday, causing not only many of the usual winter storm disruptions, but also snarling post-Christmas travel. Among various other impacts, Interstate 80 was initially closed from Lexington westward to North Platte, but with this closure eventually creeping as far east as Grand Island to accommodate traffic back-up. There was a fairly sharp divide in snow totals and storm impacts across the area, as locations generally northwest of an Alma-Kearney-Fullerton line received the highest amounts of 4-9, and in turn, experienced the most severe blizzard conditions. Amounts dropped off steadily to the southeast of that line, with places such as Osceola, Grand Island, Hastings and Red Cloud only seeing 1-2. Even farther southeast, counties such as Thayer/Fillmore/Nuckolls barely received a dusting. Per NWS cooperative observers, some of the highest official totals featured: 8.5 in Greeley, 8 in Edison, 7.9 in Loup City, 7.2 six miles southeast of Lexington and 7 in Arcadia, Cambridge and Wilsonville. In the Tri Cities, Kearney led the way with 3.8, while Grand Island and Hastings only measured 1.9. Winds were certainly a major factor, as much of the 27th featured sustained north-northwest speeds of 25-35 MPH and frequent gusts of 40-50 MPH, resulting in considerable blowing/drifting snow and reducing visibilities to around 1/4 mile for several hours in the Blizzard Warning area. ||Breaking down event timing, and initially backing up a bit, this storm started off very similar to the one four weeks prior, and with something fairly unusual for this time of year: soaking winter rain! In fact, Wednesday the 26th featured widespread rainfall of 1-2, including daily records in Grand Island (1.42) and Hastings (1.41). As colder air invaded western counties late that night, rain quickly changed to snow, with blizzard conditions already in full force by sunrise on the 27th in places such as Kearney, Lexington and Ord. Even before snow impacts kicked into high gear, the initially rain-wettened roads became slick due to a flash freeze in the falling temperatures. For the hardest-hit northern/western counties, the bulk of snow occurred during the early-mid morning, while areas farther south/east nearer the Highway 281 corridor (including Grand Island/Hastings) observed the majority of snow and occasional white-out conditions during the late-morning through mid-afternoon. Although blowing/drifting snow persisted in many areas well into the night, South Central Nebraska saw a pronounced break from falling snow through the late afternoon-evening, before one last batch of light snow (accumulation largely under one-half inch) flared up on the morning of the 28th. In the mid-upper levels, the primary player was a powerful, large scale trough, with its center tracking from NM on the 26th, to western KS by daybreak on the 27th, then northward across eastern NE into MN during the afternoon and evening. The associated strong surface low pressure system started the morning of the 27th over central Kansas (pressure around 996 millibars), before steadily marching to around Kansas City by mid-day and the IA/MN border by evening. On a climate-related side note, this event put an exclamation point on an incredibly wet December, as most of South Central Nebraska received between 2.50-4.50 of precipitation for the month, or generally 300-600% of normal! For most official stations, it was a Top-3 wettest December on record, and was the outright-wettest at places such as Osceola.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Storm total snowfall of 1.9 inches was measured at the NWS office just north of Hastings. Wind gusts frequently reached 35 to 45 mph during the snow, frequently bringing visibility down to a half mile or less.

For the hardest-hit northern/western counties, the bulk of snow occurred during the early-mid morning, while areas farther south/east nearer the Highway 281 corridor (including Grand Island/Hastings) observed the majority of snow and occasional white-out conditions during the late-morning through mid-afternoon. Although blowing/drifting snow persisted in many areas well into the night, South Central Nebraska saw a pronounced break from falling snow through the late afternoon-evening, before one last batch of light snow (accumulation largely under one-half inch) flared up on the morning of the 28th. In the mid-upper levels, the primary player was a powerful, large scale trough, with its center tracking from NM on the 26th, to western KS by daybreak on the 27th, then northward across eastern NE into MN during the afternoon and evening. The associated strong surface low pressure system started the morning of the 27th over central Kansas (pressure around 996 millibars), before steadily marching to around Kansas City by mid-day and the IA/MN border by evening. On a climate-related side note, this event put an exclamation point on an incredibly wet December, as most of South Central Nebraska received between 2.50-4.50 of precipitation for the month, or generally 300-600% of normal! For most official stations, it was a Top-3 wettest December on record, and was the outright-wettest at places such as Osceola.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Storm total snowfall of 4.0 inches was measured in Minden, reported by a cooperative observer. Wind gusts frequently reached 35 to 45 mph during the snow, frequently bringing visibility down to a half mile or less.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The first true blizzard of the 2018-19 winter season struck much of the northwest half of South Central Nebraska on this Thursday, causing not only many of the usual winter storm disruptions, but also snarling post-Christmas travel. Among various other impacts, Interstate 80 was initially closed from Lexington westward to North Platte, but with this closure eventually creeping as far east as Grand Island to accommodate traffic back-up. There was a fairly sharp divide in snow totals and storm impacts across the area, as locations generally northwest of an Alma-Kearney-Fullerton line received the highest amounts of 4-9, and in turn, experienced the most severe blizzard conditions. Amounts dropped off steadily to the southeast of that line, with places such as Osceola, Grand Island, Hastings and Red Cloud only seeing 1-2. Even farther southeast, counties such as Thayer/Fillmore/Nuckolls barely received a dusting. Per NWS cooperative observers, some of the highest official totals featured: 8.5 in Greeley, 8 in Edison, 7.9 in Loup City, 7.2 six miles southeast of Lexington and 7 in Arcadia, Cambridge and Wilsonville. In the Tri Cities, Kearney led the way with 3.8, while Grand Island and Hastings only measured 1.9. Winds were certainly a major factor, as much of the 27th featured sustained north-northwest speeds of 25-35 MPH and frequent gusts of 40-50 MPH, resulting in considerable blowing/drifting snow and reducing visibilities to around 1/4 mile for several hours in the Blizzard Warning area. ||Breaking down event timing, and initially backing up a bit, this storm started off very similar to the one four weeks prior, and with something fairly unusual for this time of year: soaking winter rain! For most official stations, it was a Top-3 wettest December on record, and was the outright-wettest at places such as Osceola.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong winds behind a cold front occurred during the afternoon.

An upper level shortwave trough dug through eastern New Mexico and deepened into a closed low over west Texas by the morning of the 13th, pushing an attendant cold front through Southwest Kansas. Strong wind developed behind the front, which was sustained by a strong low level jet. Multiple severe wind gusts were reported across southwest Kansas from this system.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Measured at 5 WNW Elkhart.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level shortwave trough dug through eastern New Mexico and deepened into a closed low over west Texas by the morning of the 13th, pushing an attendant cold front through Southwest Kansas. Strong wind developed behind the front, which was sustained by a strong low level jet. Multiple severe wind gusts were reported across southwest Kansas from this system.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Measured at 6 NW of Scott City.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Periods of moderate to heavy snow fell across much of the Nebraska Panhandle producing in some locations 6 to 8 inches of snow. Heaviest snowfall amounts  reported in Sioux, Morrill and Cheyenne Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Plainsview ranch observer seventeen miles southeast of Agate reported heavy snowfall measuring 8.0 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A brief tornado occurred in Belleville Kansas around 815pm CDT.  Only minor tree limb damage was reported by EM along with power lines that were brought down by tree limbs. Radar and assessment of near storm environmental parameters suggest that this could have been a brief weak tornado.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Input from available data sources including radar, near storm environmental parameters and photos of damage suggest that at least some of the damage in Belleville could have been attributed to a brief weak tornado.  Damage indicators only show EF0 damage with mainly tree limbs down.  No structural damage was reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The first true blizzard of the 2018-19 winter season struck much of the northwest half of South Central Nebraska on this Thursday, causing not only many of the usual winter storm disruptions, but also snarling post-Christmas travel. Among various other impacts, Interstate 80 was initially closed from Lexington westward to North Platte, but with this closure eventually creeping as far east as Grand Island to accommodate traffic back-up. There was a fairly sharp divide in snow totals and storm impacts across the area, as locations generally northwest of an Alma-Kearney-Fullerton line received the highest amounts of 4-9, and in turn, experienced the most severe blizzard conditions. Amounts dropped off steadily to the southeast of that line, with places such as Osceola, Grand Island, Hastings and Red Cloud only seeing 1-2. Even farther southeast, counties such as Thayer/Fillmore/Nuckolls barely received a dusting. Per NWS cooperative observers, some of the highest official totals featured: 8.5 in Greeley, 8 in Edison, 7.9 in Loup City, 7.2 six miles southeast of Lexington and 7 in Arcadia, Cambridge and Wilsonville. In the Tri Cities, Kearney led the way with 3.8, while Grand Island and Hastings only measured 1.9. Winds were certainly a major factor, as much of the 27th featured sustained north-northwest speeds of 25-35 MPH and frequent gusts of 40-50 MPH, resulting in considerable blowing/drifting snow and reducing visibilities to around 1/4 mile for several hours in the Blizzard Warning area. ||Breaking down event timing, and initially backing up a bit, this storm started off very similar to the one four weeks prior, and with something fairly unusual for this time of year: soaking winter rain! In fact, Wednesday the 26th featured widespread rainfall of 1-2, including daily records in Grand Island (1.42) and Hastings (1.41). As colder air invaded western counties late that night, rain quickly changed to snow, with blizzard conditions already in full force by sunrise on the 27th in places such as Kearney, Lexington and Ord. Even before snow impacts kicked into high gear, the initially rain-wettened roads became slick due to a flash freeze in the falling temperatures. For the hardest-hit northern/western counties, the bulk of snow occurred during the early-mid morning, while areas farther south/east nearer the Highway 281 corridor (including Grand Island/Hastings) observed the majority of snow and occasional white-out conditions during the late-morning through mid-afternoon. Although blowing/drifting snow persisted in many areas well into the night, South Central Nebraska saw a pronounced break from falling snow through the late afternoon-evening, before one last batch of light snow (accumulation largely under one-half inch) flared up on the morning of the 28th. In the mid-upper levels, the primary player was a powerful, large scale trough, with its center tracking from NM on the 26th, to western KS by daybreak on the 27th, then northward across eastern NE into MN during the afternoon and evening. The associated strong surface low pressure system started the morning of the 27th over central Kansas (pressure around 996 millibars), before steadily marching to around Kansas City by mid-day and the IA/MN border by evening. On a climate-related side note, this event put an exclamation point on an incredibly wet December, as most of South Central Nebraska received between 2.50-4.50 of precipitation for the month, or generally 300-600% of normal! For most official stations, it was a Top-3 wettest December on record, and was the outright-wettest at places such as Osceola.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Storm total snowfall of 6.3 inches was measured eight miles south of Elwood, reported by a cooperative observer. Wind gusts frequently reached 40 to 50 mph during the snow, frequently bringing visibility down to a quarter mile or less.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A winter storm produced heavy snowfall beginning in the early morning hours on December 1st, continuing into the early morning hours on December 2nd across most of western and north central Nebraska. Snowfall amounts ranged from 6 to 14 inches across much of the area with the higher amounts occurring across north central into west central Nebraska.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Cooperative observers located 3 miles southwest of Atkinson and in O'Neill each reported 8 inches of snowfall. Light to moderate  snow occurred during the morning into the afternoon hours on December 1st, with light snow continuing during the early morning hours on December 2nd. North winds of 15 to 30 mph caused areas of blowing and drifting snow with visibility reduced to a half mile at times. Snowfall amounts ranged from 6 to 10 inches across Holt County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A winter storm produced heavy snowfall beginning in the early morning hours on December 1st, continuing into the early morning hours on December 2nd across most of western and north central Nebraska. Snowfall amounts ranged from 6 to 14 inches across much of the area with the higher amounts occurring across north central into west central Nebraska.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: General public located in Bassett reported 11.5 inches of snowfall. Moderate to heavy snow occurred during the morning into the afternoon hours on December 1st. North winds of 15 to 25 mph caused areas of blowing and drifting snow with visibility frequently reduced to a half mile. Snowfall amounts ranged from 9 to 12 inches across Rock County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level shortwave trough dug through eastern New Mexico and deepened into a closed low over west Texas by the morning of the 13th, pushing an attendant cold front through Southwest Kansas. Strong wind developed behind the front, which was sustained by a strong low level jet. Multiple severe wind gusts were reported across southwest Kansas from this system.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Measured at 6 NW of Scott City.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large cluster of t-storms developed during the afternoon of May 2 across central Kansas. The cluster evolved into a line or lines of storms that moved across northeast and east central Kansas during the afternoon and evening of May 2.  Wind damage reports occurred in addition to a few tornado reports with the lines.  At least 3 documented tornadoes occurred but all were short lived and relatively weak.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dime to nickel size hail was reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The first true near-blizzard to blizzard conditions of the 2018-19 winter season struck mainly Phillips and Rooks counties in western portions of North Central Kansas on this Thursday, causing not only many of the usual winter storm disruptions, but also snarling post-Christmas travel. Snow totals themselves were not very impressive, with reports from a combination of NWS cooperative observers and CoCoRaHS observers including: 2.5 at Logan, 2.2 east of Phillipsburg and 1.3 near Plainville. However, snowfall analysis maps and satellite imagery strongly suggest that far northwestern Phillips County likely received at least 3-4. Farther east, most of the remainder of this six-county area saw well under 1, if hardly any at all. That being said, winds were certainly a major factor, as much of the 27th featured sustained north-northwest speeds of 25-35 MPH and frequent gusts of 40-50 MPH, resulting in considerable blowing snow and reducing visibilities to well-under one mile at times. ||Breaking down event timing, and initially backing up a bit, this storm started off very similar to the one four weeks prior, and with something fairly unusual for this time of year: soaking winter rain! In fact, Wednesday the 26th featured widespread rainfall of 1-2 across all of North Central Kansas. As colder air invaded late that night, rain quickly changed to snow, with at least near-blizzard conditions already reported by sunrise in Phillips/Rooks counties. However, the majority of accumulating snow and overall-worst conditions focused between 10 a.m. and 1 p.m., with very little snow thereafter. In the mid-upper levels, the primary player was a powerful, large scale trough, with its center tracking from NM on the 26th, to western KS by daybreak on the 27th, then northward across eastern NE into MN during the afternoon and evening. The associated strong surface low pressure system started the morning of the 27th over central Kansas (pressure around 996 millibars), before steadily marching to around Kansas City by mid-day and the IA/MN border by evening. On a climate-related side note, this event put an exclamation point on an incredibly wet December, as most of North Central Kansas received between 2.50-3.50 of precipitation for the month, or generally 300-500% of normal! For most official stations, it was a Top-3 wettest December on record, and was the outright-wettest at places such as Beloit.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Storm total snowfall of 2.5 inches occurred in Logan (NWS coop observer) and 2.2 inches occurred six miles east of Phillipsburg (CoCoRaHS). Wind gusts frequently reached 40 to 50 mph during the snow, frequently bringing visibility down to a quarter mile or less.
