EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During a roughly 36-hour period between the morning of Saturday the 1st and the evening of Sunday the 2nd, North Central Kansas observed off-and-on rounds of snow, with cumulative totals generally ranging from 2-4 in most locations, but with isolated higher pockets here and there, as evidenced by NWS cooperative observer totals as high as 8 near Covert (rural Osborne County) and 5 at Jewell. While this was not a true blizzard by any means, occasional visibility reductions to one-half mile or less were noted, especially on the afternoon and evening of the 1st, when sustained north winds of 20-25 MPH and frequent gusts of 30-40 MPH were most prevalent. ||Backing up in time a bit, snow was not the only story associated with this long-duration event, as it actually started off as a significant late-autumn rain-producer. In fact, most of the six-county area measured 1-2 of soaking rain between the afternoon of Nov. 30th and the morning of the 1st, before precipitation finally switched over to snow. Due in part to much of the initial precipitation falling as rain, along with the fact that a significant batch of mid-level dry air got wrapped into the heart of the parent low pressure system, snowfall totals in most of the area fell short of expectations (many places received at least a few inches less than originally forecasted). In the mid-upper levels, the main driving force was a strong, slow-moving low pressure system that tracked from south central KS on the morning of the 1st to the IA/MO border area by the morning of the 2nd before weakening and shearing-out eastward into the Midwest. The intermittent areas of snow that persisted across the local area through most of the 1st-2nd were supported by weaker lobes of energy rotating around the backside of the parent system. At the surface, the associated low pressure center peaked in intensity around 988 millibars over eastern KS on the 1st, thus driving the modestly-strong north winds across the local area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A snowfall total of 3.5 inches occurred in Lebanon and 1.9 inches occurred in Smith Center. North wind gusts of 30 to 40 mph developed the afternoon of December 1st, lasting into the overnight, resulting in reduced visibilities in falling snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A winter storm began in the afternoon hours on December 26th, continuing into the early morning hours on December 28th across the eastern half of western and north central Nebraska. Strong northwest winds of 25 to 35 mph with gusts to 45 mph occurred during the peak of the storm. This created low visibility and significant blowing and drifting. Blizzard conditions were observed in some areas. Some roads, including Interstate 80 west of North Platte became closed on December 27th. Snowfall amounts ranged from 5 to 12 inches across much of the area with the higher amounts occurring across Thomas, Blaine, Loup, and Custer Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: CoCoRaHS observers in Burwell and 2 miles south southwest of Burwell reported 7.5 inches and 8.5 inches of snowfall respectively. Snowfall amounts ranged from 6 to 9 inches across Garfield County. Strong northwest winds of 25 to 35 mph with gusts to 50 mph occurred beginning during the early morning hours, daytime and evening hours on December 27th into the early morning hours on December 28th. This created low visibility of a quarter mile or less at times and significant blowing and drifting. Some county roads became closed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A thunderstorm produced large hail as it tracked east across eastern Kimball and western Cheyenne counties in western Nebraska.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong area of low pressure moved through the Midwest creating heavy snow and ice, along with strong northwesterly winds. the storm produced 2 to 8 inches across parts of northeast Nebraska, mainly in Cedar, Knox and Antelope Counties.  Lesser snowfall amounts were reported southeast of those counties.  Strong winds also accompanied the snow fall with gusts between 35 to 50 mph reported across eastern Nebraska and southwest Iowa.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law Enforcement reported 4 to 5 inches of snow across the county, but considerable blowing snow with whiteout conditions, especially in open areas.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong area of low pressure moved through the Midwest creating heavy snow and ice, along with strong northwesterly winds. the storm produced 2 to 8 inches across parts of northeast Nebraska, mainly in Cedar, Knox and Antelope Counties. EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong area of low pressure moved through the Midwest creating heavy snow and ice, along with strong northwesterly winds. the storm produced 2 to 8 inches across parts of northeast Nebraska, mainly in Cedar, Knox and Antelope Counties. EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong area of low pressure moved through the Midwest creating heavy snow and ice, along with strong northwesterly winds. the storm produced 2 to 8 inches across parts of northeast Nebraska, mainly in Cedar, Knox and Antelope Counties. EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotters reported a couple of inches of snow, with considerable blowing snow with reduced visibility. Winds gusted as high as 46 mph during the event. There was also one to two tenths of ice accumulation during the event, which made travel especially hazardous with multiple car accidents.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A closed upper level low lifted northeast across the 4-corners region and deepened as it crossed into western Kansas. An attendant cold front pushed into west-central and extreme southwest Kansas as deep low-level moisture continued to advect into the region. Rain showers began on the evening of the 26th, and transitioned to snow behind the front with strong northwest winds. Blizzard conditions were reported throughout the region, leaving roads closed and motorists stranded.  Snowfall in excess of 10 inches was widespread from near Elkhart, through Lakin and Garden City and up to near Scott City and Dighton.  There were several reports of 12 inches.  Snow drifts were over six feet at many locations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Near zero visibility in heavy snow and blowing snow.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The power outage from downed power lines may have lasted beyond 6 PM CST.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A winter storm system brought wide spread precipitation to Northwest Kansas, beginning on the 26th.  The precipitation began as rain then transitioned to snow during the night of the 26th.  Winds became strong as the rain changed over to snow the night of the 26th.  This caused blizzard conditions to occur in the snowfall.  The blizzard conditions swept northeast across Northwest Kansas, ending as the snowfall shifted east.  Multiple accidents and slide-offs were reported on I-70 in Gove County due to the icy roadway and poor visibility.  One of the accidents involved a fatality.  The highest snowfall amount reported was 9.5 southwest of Hoxie.||Besides the snow, high wind gusts also occurred.  A gust of 58 MPH was measured at the Goodland airport, and a 60 MPH gust was measured at the Hill City airport.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Similar winds and radar imagery were observed over Sheridan County compared to counties that reported blizzard conditions.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A winter storm system brought wide spread precipitation to Southwest Nebraska, beginning on the 26th. The precipitation began as rain then transitioned to snow during the night of the 26th. Winds became strong as the rain changed over to snow the night of the 26th. This caused blizzard conditions to occur in the snowfall. The blizzard conditions swept northeast into Nebraska, then ended as the snowfall shifted east.  The highest snowfall amount reported was 6.5 in Culbertson.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Whiteout conditions were reported in Culbertson during the storm.  Snowfall amounts ranged from around an inch in the western part of the county to six and a half inches in the east.

On the evening of May 2, 2018 a line of strong storms moved through eastern Kansas. While strong storms occurred across the entire eastern part of the state, the strongest impacts were felt within the Kansas City Metro area, where a EF-1 tornado formed in Overland Park, causing a fair amount of damage in the form of widespread tree damage, some structure damage to local schools, and numerous power lines and power poles were destroyed. The line of storms continued into western Missouri, where they went on to produce more tornadoes and scattered wind damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported a measured 82 mph wind gust.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On the evening of May 2, 2018 a line of strong storms moved through eastern Kansas. While strong storms occurred across the entire eastern part of the state, the strongest impacts were felt within the Kansas City Metro area, where a EF-1 tornado formed in Overland Park, causing a fair amount of damage in the form of widespread tree damage, some structure damage to local schools, and numerous power lines and power poles were destroyed. The line of storms continued into western Missouri, where they went on to produce more tornadoes and scattered wind damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The tornado formed near 143rd and Antioch doing damage to trees in residential neighborhoods in that area. The tornado then did damage to Overland Trail Middle School, blowing out over 20 windows at Mission and 133rd there were several power poles down, and the tornado likely dissipated near the Kansas Missouri state line near 130th Street.

Several strong thunderstorms produced large hail, gusty winds, and heavy rainfall across portions of the Nebraska Panhandle. Heavy rains inundated the storm drains in downtown Scottsbluff causing roadways to flood. Strong winds knocked over utility poles and even an irrigation pivot.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous streets across downtown Scottsbluff were covered with water due to recent heavy rainfall.

A strong thunderstorm moved across Scotts Bluff County producing one inch hail over the city of Scottsbluff.
Thunderstorms produced large hail, damaging winds, and torrential rainfall across northern and central portions of the Nebraska Panhandle.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Quarter size hail covered the ground south of Hay Springs.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms produced large hail, damaging winds, and torrential rainfall across northern and central portions of the Nebraska Panhandle.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Quarter size hail covered the ground at the Box Butte Campground.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms produced large hail, damaging winds, and torrential rainfall across northern and central portions of the Nebraska Panhandle.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Quarter size hail was observed south of Kimball.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms produced large hail, damaging winds, and torrential rainfall across northern and central portions of the Nebraska Panhandle.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Estimated wind gusts of 60 to 65 mph downed large tree limbs at Melbeta.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several rounds of thunderstorms along a stationary frontal boundary resulted in significant flash-flooding in portions of Riley, Marshall, and Pottawatomie Counties. Numerous damaging wind reports were noted as well.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Residents in the city of Keats were being evacuated due to the rapidly rising water on Wildcat Creek.  The flooding of Wildcat creek resulted in an estimated 17.2 million dollars in losses to property.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms produced large hail over portions of Sioux County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Quarter size hail was observed west of Agate.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms produced several reports of large hail and damaging winds throughout much of the Nebraska Panhandle.
Severe thunderstorms produced several reports of large hail and damaging winds throughout much of the Nebraska Panhandle.
Severe thunderstorms produced several reports of large hail and damaging winds throughout much of the Nebraska Panhandle.
Severe thunderstorms produced several reports of large hail and damaging winds throughout much of the Nebraska Panhandle.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread power outages were reported due to knocked over powerlines in addition to uprooted trees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A severe thunderstorm produced damaging winds and large hail in eastern Banner and Morrill counties.
Thunderstorms produced large hail and strong winds across portions of Banner and Box Butte counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Quarter size hail was observed 10 miles south of Harrisburg.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Additional heavy rain during the early morning hours of September 5th and 7th brought flash-flooding across portions of the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water was running over the road just west of the K-15 and K-9 intersection.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Additional heavy rain during the early morning hours of September 5th and 7th brought flash-flooding across portions of the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water was running over 30th road between Prairie and Quail roads.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Additional heavy rain during the early morning hours of September 5th and 7th brought flash-flooding across portions of the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water was flowing over the road at 26th and Jayhawk.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong to severe thunderstorms moved across portions of the Nebraska Panhandle producing large hail up to reported golf ball size.
Strong to severe thunderstorms moved across portions of the Nebraska Panhandle producing large hail up to reported golf ball size.
Strong winds and large hail were produced by passing thunderstorms over Scotts Bluff and Morrill Counties. Some power flashes were associated with downed power lines by these strong winds.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Half inch hail and heavy rains fell during time of observation.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong thunderstorm moved across portions of the Nebraska Panhandle producing strong wind gusts near the town of Dix.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Personal weather station recorded wind gusts varying from 55 to 60 mph along with other reports from nearby of estimated 60 mph wind gusts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of thunderstorms moved from the west to the east, producing numerous damaging wind reports across north-central Kansas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Estimated wind gust.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: As a shortwave disturbance rotated around a large southwest U.S. closed low aloft and into confluent flow aloft across the Northern Plains, light wintry precipitation developed on December 31. An arctic front surged southward early in the day with winds increasing to a gusty 30 to 45 mph, creating areas of blowing snow and visibility less than a half mile at times, as well as dangerously cold wind chills by late afternoon and evening of December 31.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: After around an inch snowfall, winds increased to 35 to 45 mph as temperatures plummeted, taking wind chill values as low as -25 at Yankton and -21 at Wayne during the evening hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure area moved out of the southern plains and moved northeast across the central portions of Kansas.   Abundant moisture moved north and wrapped into the low pressure area.  Widespread showers and embedded thunderstorms developed across Kansas.  Numerous rounds of showers moved across Kansas, with renewed flooding and even some flash flooding.  Rainfall amounts over the two day period were 7 to 10 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A middle school in Bushton had to be evacuated due to the driveway and parking lot becoming flooded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: For most of South Central Nebraska, this Sunday featured the earliest autumn snow since at least 2009, and in a few spots, the most significant early-season snow in decades! That being said, for most of the 24 local counties, totals were fairly minimal...no more than 1-2. The notable exception focused south-southeast of a line from Ayr-Harvard-Gresham, where amounts of at least 3-5 were common. Within that broader primary snow zone , a roughly 10-20 mile wide swath piled up as much as 5-7, primarily within the following counties: most of Fillmore, northern Thayer, northeastern Nuckolls, southeastern Clay and southeastern York. Per CoCoRaHS and NWS cooperative observers, some of the highest official totals featured: 7 in Geneva, 6.8 four miles south of Shickley, 5 six miles east-southeast of Clay Center and 4.6 in Hebron. Unofficial totals (including social media reports) included 6.6 in Milligan, 6.5 in Fairmont, 5 at Waco and 4.5 seven miles northeast of Superior. While only a small percentage of South Central Nebraska observed these highest totals, many counties endured at least a few hours of reduced visibility, and even brief near-blizzard conditions, thanks to sustained north winds averaging 15-25 MPH and gusting up to around 35 MPH. Climatologically, this was clearly an unusually-early snow event. As just a few examples: Geneva had its 2nd-earliest snowfall of 5+ inches on record (and the most significant early-season snow since 1970), and Hastings reported its 4th-earliest snowfall of 1+ inches. ||Timing-wise, this was a fairly quick-hitter, with most areas tallying the brunt of accumulation within a 4-8 hour period, starting in most counties between 6-8 a.m. CDT and largely ending from southwest-to-northeast during the 1-5 p.m. CDT time frame. In the mid-upper levels, the large scale regime featured a broad trough sinking southward into the central United States, anchored by a closed low tracking through the Manitoba-North Dakota-Minnesota border region. However, on the smaller scale, the driving force locally was a pronounced ribbon of mid-level frontogenesis (especially evident at 700 millibars). This resulted in mesoscale banding, and the aforementioned higher-than-expected snow totals centered over the Fillmore County area. At the surface, the gusty north winds were driven by an enhanced pressure gradient between a seasonably-strong cold front that bisected Kansas from southwest-to-northeast at daybreak, and a strong high pressure system (around 1034 millibars) centered over the Northern Rockies. The overall-strongest winds occurred during the morning, slowly letting up through the afternoon and evening. Temperature-wise, this event served as the grand finale to a markedly-cold start to October; in fact, most of the area endured a Top-5 coldest first half of the month. However, just two days later on the 16th temperatures soared into the upper 60s to around 70, quickly melting this early-season snow into a memory.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow totals generally averaged 3-5 across most of Nuckolls County, including CoCoRaHS totals of 3.0 in Superior and 4.5 seven miles northeast of Superior. An unofficial public report of 3.5 occurred in Nelson. Sustained north winds averaged 15-25 MPH with gusts up to around 35 MPH during the heaviest snow, promoting brief, near-blizzard conditions.

Also, unofficial public reports featured 5.0 in Waco and 4.5 in McCool Junction. Sustained north winds averaged 15-25 MPH with gusts up to around 35 MPH during the heaviest snow, promoting brief, near-blizzard conditions.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow totals generally averaged 3-6 across most of Thayer County, including official NWS observer totals of 4.6 in Hebron and 4.1 in Hubbell. Reports from northern portions of the county were scarce, but observations from neighboring counties along with satellite data strongly suggest that 5-6 likely fell, especially in the far north central and northwest. Sustained north winds averaged 15-25 MPH with gusts up to around 35 MPH during the heaviest snow, promoting brief, near-blizzard conditions.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: For most of this six-county North Central Kansas area, this Sunday featured the earliest measurable autumn snow since at least 1985! That being said, amounts were not very heavy, with most locations reporting between 1-3. Per CoCoRaHS and NWS cooperative observers, some of the highest official totals featured: 3.2 six miles east of Phillipsburg, 3.1 four miles west-northwest of Plainville and 3.0 at Natoma and Covert. Despite snow amounts staying fairly tame, most places endured at least a few hours of reduced visibility thanks to sustained north winds averaging 10-20 MPH and gusting to around 30 MPH. Climatologically, this was clearly an unusually-early snow event. As just one example: this was the 2nd-earliest snowfall of 3+ inches on record at Natoma. ||Timing-wise, this was a somewhat split event. While most areas received at least some snow during the morning and early afternoon hours mainly between 7 a.m-1 p.m. CDT (especially the northern three counties), the southern three counties picked up the majority of snow during a secondary band that developed during the late afternoon and evening, mainly between 4-10 p.m. CDT. In the mid-upper levels, the large scale regime featured a broad trough sinking southward into the central United States, anchored by a closed low tracking through the Manitoba-North Dakota-Minnesota border region. However, on the smaller scale, the driving force locally was a pronounced ribbon of mid-level frontogenesis (especially evident at 700 millibars), promoting mesoscale banding. At the surface, the gusty north winds were driven by an enhanced pressure gradient between a seasonably-strong cold front that bisected Kansas from southwest-to-northeast at daybreak, and a strong high pressure system (around 1034 millibars) centered over the Northern Rockies. The overall-strongest winds occurred during the morning, slowly letting up through the afternoon and evening. Temperature-wise, this event served as the grand finale to a markedly-cold start to October; in fact, most of the area endured a Top-3 coldest first half of the month. However, just two days later on the 16th temperatures soared into the upper 60s, quickly melting this early-season snow into a memory.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow totals averaged 1-3 across much of Jewell County, including official NWS observer totals of 2.5 in Ionia and 2.0 in Jewell. There were two primary rounds of snow, one during the morning and another during the evening.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Rain quickly changed to snow behind a cold front moving through the area. A 40-60 mile wide band of moderate to heavy snow of 3 to 7 inches set up from south central NE through west central IA, especially along the Interstate 80 corridor. Heavy wet snow falling on fully leafed trees, resulted in many downed trees and branches, and tens of thousands of people without power. Up to 55,000 people were without power at one time in the OPPD district, and several thousand in the LES district. However, impact on roads remained low since most roads remained wet through the event.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The emergency Manager reported 7.5 inches of snow 3 miles southeast of Friend, NE. Tobias, NE reported 6.8 inches. Other locations in the county recorded 3 to 5 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Rain quickly changed to snow behind a cold front moving through the area. A 40-60 mile wide band of moderate to heavy snow of 3 to 7 inches set up from south central NE through west central IA, especially along the Interstate 80 corridor. Heavy wet snow falling on fully leafed trees, resulted in many downed trees and branches, and tens of thousands of people without power. Up to 55,000 people were without power at one time in the OPPD district, and several thousand in the LES district. However, impact on roads remained low since most roads remained wet through the event.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several reports of 2 to 4 inches of heavy wet snow occurred. Up to 50,000 people in the OPPD service area lost power due to downed power lines.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Rain quickly changed to snow behind a cold front moving through the area. EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several reports of 3.5 to 5.5 inches of heavy wet snow occurred. Up to 10,000 people in the LES service area lost power due to downed power lines.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: For most of this six-county North Central Kansas area, this Sunday featured the earliest measurable autumn snow since at least 1985! That being said, amounts were not very heavy, with most locations reporting between 1-3. Per CoCoRaHS and NWS cooperative observers, some of the highest official totals featured: 3.2 six miles east of Phillipsburg, 3.1 four miles west-northwest of Plainville and 3.0 at Natoma and Covert. Despite snow amounts staying fairly tame, most places endured at least a few hours of reduced visibility thanks to sustained north winds averaging 10-20 MPH and gusting to around 30 MPH. Climatologically, this was clearly an unusually-early snow event. As just one example: this was the 2nd-earliest snowfall of 3+ inches on record at Natoma. ||Timing-wise, this was a somewhat split event. While most areas received at least some snow during the morning and early afternoon hours mainly between 7 a.m-1 p.m. CDT (especially the northern three counties), the southern three counties picked up the majority of snow during a secondary band that developed during the late afternoon and evening, mainly between 4-10 p.m. CDT. In the mid-upper levels, the large scale regime featured a broad trough sinking southward into the central United States, anchored by a closed low tracking through the Manitoba-North Dakota-Minnesota border region. However, on the smaller scale, the driving force locally was a pronounced ribbon of mid-level frontogenesis (especially evident at 700 millibars), promoting mesoscale banding. At the surface, the gusty north winds were driven by an enhanced pressure gradient between a seasonably-strong cold front that bisected Kansas from southwest-to-northeast at daybreak, and a strong high pressure system (around 1034 millibars) centered over the Northern Rockies. The overall-strongest winds occurred during the morning, slowly letting up through the afternoon and evening. Temperature-wise, this event served as the grand finale to a markedly-cold start to October; in fact, most of the area endured a Top-3 coldest first half of the month. However, just two days later on the 16th temperatures soared into the upper 60s, quickly melting this early-season snow into a memory.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow totals averaged 1-2 across much of Mitchell County, including an official NWS observer total of 2.0 at Cawker City, and a CoCoRaHS report of 2.0 near Hunter. Although some snow fell in the morning and early afternoon, the primary round occurred during the late afternoon and evening.

Starting on October 6th, the atmosphere set itself up in a pattern conducive to bring a prolonged period of heavy rain to portions of northeastern Kansas and northwestern Missouri. The heaviest rain occurred Saturday and Sunday (Oct 6-7). By Tuesday night (October 9th) more than 11 inches of rain fell in and around the Kansas City Metro. Local drought conditions were still in the Extreme to Exceptional category going into the event, so flash flooding was relatively low impact, relegated mostly to several road closures. The bigger impact from this prolonged rainfall event came from local river and stream flooding. Several streams entered the moderate to major flooding category. The 4 day event spanning Oct 6-9 resulted in the greatest 4 day rain total in recorded Kansas City History. At Kansas City International Airport 9.79 inches were recorded for the Oct 6-9 time period, beating out Sept 12-15, 1977, which had 9.48 over the 4 day span.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: From FOX 4 Kansas City: Miami County Sheriff���s Office confirmed to FOX4 that a missing 78-year-old woman has been found dead. Authorities found  Hazel Phillips inside her vehicle near Hospital Drive south of 327th Street Friday morning. According to deputies, someone noticed the roof of a silver car showing after flood waters in the area receded and alerted authorities. Osawatomie Fire Department pulled the car from the water and determined it belonged to Phillips. Phillips was still inside. Phillips��� family reported her missing Wednesday. They said they last spoke to her Tuesday night when she told them she was going to Drexel, Missouri, on Wednesday morning. ||https://fox4kc.com/2018/10/12/missing-78-year-old-miami-county-woman-found-dead-in-vehicle-pulled-from-flood-waters/ .

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A small line of storms moved across Brown County between 4pm and 5pm on Monday October 8th.  A brief weak tornado appears to have occurred a few miles WNW of Hiawatha. EVENT_NARRATIVE: A small brief tornado developed along a line of storms. It tracked northeast and damaged one known farmstead. Start and end points and time is estimated based on tornado damage signature dual-pol radar data and damage report. Estimated path of 3-4 miles.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rainfall and runoff caused extensive flooding along the Ninnescah river flooding the city park, Memorial lake and the Kansas Department of Wildlife offices and rearing ponds.  At the lake, several vehicles, tents and campers were inundated by flood waters.  At the fish hatchery at the KDWP offices, many of the ponds were breached washing fingerling fish and brood fish out into the swollen river.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: After a very dry summer, exceptional drought (D4) conditions were experienced area-wide, resulting in heavy losses for local farmers. Things changed in October when widespread heavy rain effectively ended that drought. Widespread 6 to 9 inches of rain fell, with some locations receiving over a foot of rain over the 4 day stretch from October 6 through October 9. By October 9th, the drought was effectively ended by the UNL drought monitor.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Due to widespread dry conditions through the summer and early fall of 2018 most counties experienced extreme to exceptional drought (D3-D4). While some counties saw marked improvement through the late summer and early fall the drought continued into the second week of October. The drought improved area-wide after 6-12 inches of rain fell in a four day stretch in early October. This effectively ended the drought area-wide. While the exact damage costs are unknown, it is estimated that farmer across the entire region suffered millions of dollars of losses due to the extremely dry conditions.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Abundant low level moisture streamed north into most of the Kansas during the evening and overnight hours of October 8th. 2018.   As the warm front associated with the main low pressure area in the southern plains moved north, widespread showers and embedded thunderstorms developed across much of southern and southeast Kansas.  The stalled warm front, led to numerous rounds of moderate to heavy rainfall, with numerous reports of flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several county roads were reported closed due to high water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The late afternoon and evening hours on this Wednesday featured some of the most-intense winds of fall 2018 within South Central Nebraska, as a sharp cold front raced southward across the region. Starting around 4 p.m. CDT in far northern local counties (such as Valley/Greeley) and reaching the Kansas border area by 7 p.m. CDT, most places observed at least a one-to-two hour period of sustained north-northwest winds generally 25-40 MPH and frequent gusts at least 40-50 MPH. Several official and unofficial automated stations clocked peak gusts over 50 MPH, highlighted by severe-criteria magnitudes of 62 MPH at Ord airport and 58 MPH at Grand Island airport. Hastings airport fell just shy of severe-criteria with a peak gust of 56 MPH. While there were no significant damage reports, small tree limbs were reported down in Ord (this likely occurred in other places as well). ||As for the meteorological setup, and starting with the mid levels, a vigorous shortwave trough passed well north of the local area, tracking from ND to MN. However, pronounced pressure rises accompanied the associated surface cold front into Nebraska, featuring a bullseye of two-hour rises between 4-6 millibars, emanating from an expansive high centered over eastern MT. The combination of these notable pressure rises into a deeply-mixed afternoon boundary layer proved more than sufficient to whip up the intense winds. In addition to the winds, this cold front was also  responsible for a drastic 24-hour temperature change. Afternoon highs across South Central Nebraska on the 3rd (just ahead of this front) soared to record/near-record values in the upper-80s to mid-90s F. However, daytime highs on the 4th were a remarkable 45-55 degrees colder, only reaching the upper-30s to mid-40s in most counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind gust of 62 mph occurred at Evelyn Sharp Field in Ord, behind a strong cold front.

As the warm front associated with the main low pressure area in the southern plains moved north, widespread showers and embedded thunderstorms developed across much of southern and southeast Kansas.  The stalled warm front, led to numerous rounds of moderate to heavy rainfall, with numerous reports of flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Some minor street flooding was reported in Arkansas City.

The stalled warm front, led to numerous rounds of moderate to heavy rainfall, with numerous reports of flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A low water bridge was closed due to high water near the intersection of southwest Prairie Creek Road and southwest 170th Street.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure area moved out of the southern plains and moved northeast across the central portions of Kansas.   Abundant moisture moved north and wrapped into the low pressure area.  Widespread showers and embedded thunderstorms developed across Kansas.  Numerous rounds of showers moved across Kansas, with renewed flooding and even some flash flooding.  Rainfall amounts over the two day period were 7 to 10 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several rural roads around Kingman county were impassible due to high water. Rushing water eroded some of the culverts on county roads.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The late afternoon and evening hours on this Wednesday featured some of the most-intense winds of fall 2018 within South Central Nebraska, as a sharp cold front raced southward across the region. Starting around 4 p.m. CDT in far northern local counties (such as Valley/Greeley) and reaching the Kansas border area by 7 p.m. CDT, most places observed at least a one-to-two hour period of sustained north-northwest winds generally 25-40 MPH and frequent gusts at least 40-50 MPH. Several official and unofficial automated stations clocked peak gusts over 50 MPH, highlighted by severe-criteria magnitudes of 62 MPH at Ord airport and 58 MPH at Grand Island airport. Hastings airport fell just shy of severe-criteria with a peak gust of 56 MPH. While there were no significant damage reports, small tree limbs were reported down in Ord (this likely occurred in other places as well). ||As for the meteorological setup, and starting with the mid levels, a vigorous shortwave trough passed well north of the local area, tracking from ND to MN. However, pronounced pressure rises accompanied the associated surface cold front into Nebraska, featuring a bullseye of two-hour rises between 4-6 millibars, emanating from an expansive high centered over eastern MT. The combination of these notable pressure rises into a deeply-mixed afternoon boundary layer proved more than sufficient to whip up the intense winds. In addition to the winds, this cold front was also  responsible for a drastic 24-hour temperature change. Afternoon highs across South Central Nebraska on the 3rd (just ahead of this front) soared to record/near-record values in the upper-80s to mid-90s F. However, daytime highs on the 4th were a remarkable 45-55 degrees colder, only reaching the upper-30s to mid-40s in most counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind gust of 58 mph occurred at Central Nebraska Regional Airport in Grand Island, behind a strong cold front.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: For most of South Central Nebraska, this Sunday featured the earliest autumn snow since at least 2009, and in a few spots, the most significant early-season snow in decades! That being said, for most of the 24 local counties, totals were fairly minimal...no more than 1-2. The notable exception focused south-southeast of a line from Ayr-Harvard-Gresham, where amounts of at least 3-5 were common. Within that broader primary snow zone , a roughly 10-20 mile wide swath piled up as much as 5-7, primarily within the following counties: most of Fillmore, northern Thayer, northeastern Nuckolls, southeastern Clay and southeastern York. Per CoCoRaHS and NWS cooperative observers, some of the highest official totals featured: 7 in Geneva, 6.8 four miles south of Shickley, 5 six miles east-southeast of Clay Center and 4.6 in Hebron. Unofficial totals (including social media reports) included 6.6 in Milligan, 6.5 in Fairmont, 5 at Waco and 4.5 seven miles northeast of Superior. While only a small percentage of South Central Nebraska observed these highest totals, many counties endured at least a few hours of reduced visibility, and even brief near-blizzard conditions, thanks to sustained north winds averaging 15-25 MPH and gusting up to around 35 MPH. Climatologically, this was clearly an unusually-early snow event. As just a few examples: Geneva had its 2nd-earliest snowfall of 5+ inches on record (and the most significant early-season snow since 1970), and Hastings reported its 4th-earliest snowfall of 1+ inches. ||Timing-wise, this was a fairly quick-hitter, with most areas tallying the brunt of accumulation within a 4-8 hour period, starting in most counties between 6-8 a.m. CDT and largely ending from southwest-to-northeast during the 1-5 p.m. CDT time frame. In the mid-upper levels, the large scale regime featured a broad trough sinking southward into the central United States, anchored by a closed low tracking through the Manitoba-North Dakota-Minnesota border region. However, on the smaller scale, the driving force locally was a pronounced ribbon of mid-level frontogenesis (especially evident at 700 millibars). This resulted in mesoscale banding, and the aforementioned higher-than-expected snow totals centered over the Fillmore County area. At the surface, the gusty north winds were driven by an enhanced pressure gradient between a seasonably-strong cold front that bisected Kansas from southwest-to-northeast at daybreak, and a strong high pressure system (around 1034 millibars) centered over the Northern Rockies. The overall-strongest winds occurred during the morning, slowly letting up through the afternoon and evening. Temperature-wise, this event served as the grand finale to a markedly-cold start to October; in fact, most of the area endured a Top-5 coldest first half of the month. However, just two days later on the 16th temperatures soared into the upper 60s to around 70, quickly melting this early-season snow into a memory.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow totals across Adams County ranged from as little as 1-2 in northern areas (including 1.1 at the NWS Hastings office), up to around 4 in southern areas (including an NWS employee's residence near Pauline). Sustained north winds averaged 15-25 MPH with gusts up to around 35 MPH during the heaviest snow, promoting brief, near-blizzard conditions.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Within South Central Nebraska, Fillmore County likely bore the biggest brunt of this event, with snow totals across nearly the entire county averaging 4-7, including official NWS observer totals of 7.0 in Geneva and 6.8 four miles south of Shickley. Unofficial, public reports also featured 6.6 in Milligan, 6.5 in Fairmont and 5.5 in Exeter. Sustained north winds averaged 15-25 MPH with gusts up to around 35 MPH during the heaviest snow, promoting brief, near-blizzard conditions.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure area moved out of the southern plains and moved northeast across the central portions of Kansas.   Abundant moisture moved north and wrapped into the low pressure area.  Widespread showers and embedded thunderstorms developed across Kansas.  Numerous rounds of showers moved across Kansas, with renewed flooding and even some flash flooding.  Rainfall amounts over the two day period were 7 to 10 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding was reported on the south side if Kingman, where the Riverside Park flooded up to 4 feet deep due to high water and water from the Ninnescah River.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moving through the area produced wind gusts from 50 to 61 mph. The strong winds flipped a bounce toy at a pumpkin patch near Lincoln, NE, injuring 1 child and killing another.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The ASOS south of Norfolk, NE reported a 61 mph wind gust as a cold front moved through.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain occurred across the area on October 8th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water was reported over a county road west of Cook, NE. The person reported 4.20 inches of rain since the storm began earlier in the day.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A blizzard occurred south and east of Hastings on this Saturday night and Sunday, and near-blizzard conditions occurred, at times, in many other locations. Saturday afternoon, a narrow band of snow developed, in the shape of an arc, from Omaha through the Sandhills and then southwest to Denver. This band formed in the deformation zone of developing low pressure. During the evening, this band expanded and moved southeast, enveloping all of south central Nebraska. At 2 AM CST Sunday, the northern terminus of the snow shield began moving into south central Nebraska. By 7 AM CST, the snow had ended over most of the area, except to the south and east of Hastings. By noon, the snow had exited to the east, bringing an end to the snow there as well. Windy conditions maintained blowing snow for 3 to 5 hours after the snow ended. Widespread, frequent wind gusts between 35 and 50 mph were common, which severely reduced the visibility in falling and blowing snow, especially south and east of Hastings. Near zero visibility was reported at Clay Center, Geneva, Hebron, and Nelson. A couple locations recorded wind gusts above 50 mph, including 55 mph at Hastings, and 62 mph at Nelson. The strength of the winds resulted in scattered power outages in Phelps, Hall, Hamilton, and Merrick counties. State troopers and other first responders were busy responding to slide-offs and minor accidents due to slippery roads. Motorists were urged to avoid traveling, and many spent the night in hotels. One hotel mentioned that travelers were checking-in all night, and others that intended to travel to the region had cancelled their reservations. Despite the nasty conditions, the Grand Island and Kearney airports remained open. However, numerous churches cancelled services. A few schools in Webster, Nuckolls, and Thayer counties even delayed their start time Monday morning. Measuring the snowfall was extremely difficult due to the wind. Most locations estimated 1 to 3 inches of snow fell. The exception was southeast of Hastings where Shickley estimated 3.5 inches, Clay Center estimated 4, and Hubbell estimated 6.||During the daytime hours Saturday, an Arctic cold front advanced south across Nebraska. A separate low pressure system moved through Wyoming and Colorado into southwest Kansas. This low and its associated fronts moved east along the Kansas-Oklahoma border Saturday night while the Arctic front continued moving south in its wake. The low moved into Missouri Sunday while high pressure over the Canadian Prairies begin building into Nebraska. In the upper-levels, amplification was occurring with a building ridge along the West Coast. This resulted in a shortwave trough deepening and becoming a closed low over Nebraska and Kansas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall amounts across the area generally ranged from 1 to 3 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Some light snow fell over parts of north central Kansas on this Thursday. During the mid-late morning hours, a large shield of light snow developed across northern Kansas, south of Highway 36. After midday, the shield of snow progressed north to the Nebraska state line. Snow continued falling through mid-afternoon. Between 4 and 7 PM CST, the snow ended from northwest to southeast across north central Kansas. When the snow ended, the greatest accumulations were between 2 and 3 inches. However, because this snow was generated by frontogenetic forcing, there were some areas that measured 1 inch or less. The highest snow total reported was 3 inches at Jewell.||A continental polar air mass encompassed the central U.S. with the polar front along the Gulf Coast and banked up against the Rockies. High pressure was over the northern Plains. The upper-level pattern was similar to other situations, in the past, in which a frontogenetic band of snow forms. A low was over central Canada with a broad trough over the Lower 48. The subtle axis of the trough extended from North Dakota to Utah Thursday morning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall amounts ranging from 2 to 4 inches were reported across the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Some light snow fell over parts of north central Kansas on this Thursday. During the mid-late morning hours, a large shield of light snow developed across northern Kansas, south of Highway 36. After midday, the shield of snow progressed north to the Nebraska state line. Snow continued falling through mid-afternoon. Between 4 and 7 PM CST, the snow ended from northwest to southeast across north central Kansas. When the snow ended, the greatest accumulations were between 2 and 3 inches. However, because this snow was generated by frontogenetic forcing, there were some areas that measured 1 inch or less. The highest snow total reported was 3 inches at Jewell.||A continental polar air mass encompassed the central U.S. with the polar front along the Gulf Coast and banked up against the Rockies. High pressure was over the northern Plains. The upper-level pattern was similar to other situations, in the past, in which a frontogenetic band of snow forms. A low was over central Canada with a broad trough over the Lower 48. The subtle axis of the trough extended from North Dakota to Utah Thursday morning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall amounts ranging from 2 to 4 inches were reported across the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A few inches of light snow fell mainly between Highway 136 and Interstate 80 on this Wednesday and Thursday. Small patches of snow began overspreading south central Nebraska Wednesday evening, mainly west of Highway 281 and along and south of Interstate 80. Around 300 AM CST Thursday, a better-organized, but narrow, east-west oriented band of snow developed with its main axis centered along Highway 6. Between 300 and 900 AM CST, this band moved east across south central Nebraska. After 900 AM, the band weakened. A few small patches of light snow lingered behind this band after 900 AM, but the snow ended, from northwest to southeast, during the early afternoon hours. Snowfall totals ranged from 2 to 7 inches in a narrow, roughly 2-county wide area. The highest totals include 7 inches at Holdrege, where snow fell with moderate intensity between 400 and 600 AM CST, 6 at Minden, 5.8 at Cambridge, and 5.5 at Elwood. As one example of the narrowness of this band, Wilsonville is 12 miles south of Cambridge, and the cooperative observer there indicated only a trace of snow fell.||A continental polar air mass encompassed the central U.S. with the polar front along the Gulf Coast and banked up against the Rockies. High pressure was over the northern Plains. The upper-level pattern was similar to other situations, in the past, in which a frontogenetic band of snow forms. A low was over central Canada with a broad trough over the Lower 48. The subtle axis of the trough extended from North Dakota to Utah Thursday morning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall amounts generally ranging from 2 to 5 inches were reported, mainly affecting the southern third of the county. Totals included 5.5 inches in Overton and 4.5 inches 6 miles southwest of Lexington.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong area of low pressure moved out of the central Rockies and produced snowfall of 2 to 11 inches across eastern Nebraska. Blizzard conditions were met in southeast Nebraska with measured wind gusts 40 to 53 mph and widespread whiteout conditions. NSP Troopers responded to 25 crashes, performed 110 motorist assists, and assisted other agencies with 15 incidents. Interstate 80 was closed for awhile between Lincoln and Omaha due to crashes. 1 elderly man passed away in Johnson county, indirectly related to the blizzard.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Emergency Manager reported blizzard conditions. Deputies were unable to get to stranded motorists for a while. Peak wind speeds of 45 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An extremely early season blizzard impacted eastern Kansas on November 25, 2018. The snowstorm was more indicative of a storm that would affect the area in the deep winter, as opposed to the middle to late part of autumn. The storm brought between 4 and 6 inches across northeast Kansas, including the Kansas City Metro area. Further separating this storm from other typical winter storms was the strong winds that accompanied the heavy snow. Most locations through the region experienced winds in excess of 35 mph at times during the storm. The strongest wind gusts came across northeast Kansas and northwest Missouri, where 50-60 mph winds were recorded in Wyandotte County and Leavenworth County (Kansas) and at Kansas City International Airport.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Blizzard conditions started after a few hours of lightly to moderately falling snow. Once the heavy snow arrived winds gusted up to 41 mph for nearly 4 hours, creating whiteout conditions, officially measured by the ASOS at nearby KMKC and KMCI as sub-quarter mile for that duration. Despite the heavy impacts from this system affecting Thanksgiving weekend return traffic, no serious injuries occurred from this event.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong area of low pressure moved out of the central Rockies and produced snowfall of 2 to 11 inches across eastern Nebraska. Blizzard conditions were met in southeast Nebraska with measured wind gusts 40 to 53 mph and widespread whiteout conditions. NSP Troopers responded to 25 crashes, performed 110 motorist assists, and assisted other agencies with 15 incidents. Interstate 80 was closed for awhile between Lincoln and Omaha due to crashes. 1 elderly man passed away in Johnson county, indirectly related to the blizzard.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Around 2-3 of snow was reported around the county. Poor weather conditions were observed for a few hours. A couple of cars had also gone off the road.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Blizzard conditions were observed by the Emergency Manager. Snow amounts up to 10 were reported in the county. A number of vehicles were stranded in the county and at least one accident.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong area of low pressure moved out of the central Rockies and produced snowfall of 2 to 11 inches across eastern Nebraska. Blizzard conditions were met in southeast Nebraska with measured wind gusts 40 to 53 mph and widespread whiteout conditions. EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public reported blizzard conditions. Peak wind speeds of 48 mph were measured at the Beatrice airport. Snow amounts up to 8.2 were reported in the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A blizzard swept through most of Central Kansas on the 25th from early in the morning until mid-afternoon. A strong upper-level shortwave that surged from the Central Rockies into the Great Plains induced rapid surface cyclogenesis across Southern Kansas. As the strengthening low pressure moved across Southeast Kansas, strong north winds sustained around 40 mph with gusts around 55 mph, combined with heavy snow to cause widespread visibilities around 1/4 mile.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 455 AM CST, the Russell Airport ASOS measured sustained speeds of 40 mph with 58 mph gusts. The ASOS also reported heavy snow that, along with the strong winds, reduced visibilities to 1/4 mile. The Russell ASOS stopped reporting around 6 AM CST. In addition, at 400 AM CST, KSN Channel 3 relayed a report of power poles that were snapped that caused power outages in Russell. At 814 AM CST, I-70 was closed from Wakeeney to Russell. At 851 AM CST, a spotter estimated 3 to 4 inches of snow 7 miles SSE of Paradise. The spotter also reported that power was flickering.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A blizzard swept through most of Central Kansas on the 25th from early in the morning until mid-afternoon. A strong upper-level shortwave that surged from the Central Rockies into the Great Plains induced rapid surface cyclogenesis across Southern Kansas. As the strengthening low pressure moved across Southeast Kansas, strong north winds sustained around 40 mph with gusts around 55 mph, combined with heavy snow to cause widespread visibilities around 1/4 mile.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfalls from 1 to 4 inches combined with 50-60 knot gusts to cause severe visibility restrictions across most of the county. At 1222 PM CST, the Hutchinson Airport ASOS measured a 50 knot gust.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A blizzard swept through most of Central Kansas on the 25th from early in the morning until mid-afternoon. A strong upper-level shortwave that surged from the Central Rockies into the Great Plains induced rapid surface cyclogenesis across Southern Kansas. As the strengthening low pressure moved across Southeast Kansas, strong north winds sustained around 40 mph with gusts around 55 mph, combined with heavy snow to cause widespread visibilities around 1/4 mile.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The KDOT web-cam located on I-70 at Mile Post 229 4 miles SSW of Westfall that overlooked Lincoln Hill displayed a whiteout in progress. Nearby reports and observations confirmed that a blizzard was in progress.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A blizzard swept through most of Central Kansas on the 25th from early in the morning until mid-afternoon. A strong upper-level shortwave that surged from the Central Rockies into the Great Plains induced rapid surface cyclogenesis across Southern Kansas. As the strengthening low pressure moved across Southeast Kansas, strong north winds sustained around 40 mph with gusts around 55 mph, combined with heavy snow to cause widespread visibilities around 1/4 mile.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A blizzard was reported at Geneseo where heavy snow and high winds reduced visibilities to around 1/4 mile at 727 AM CST.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A blizzard swept through most of Central Kansas on the 25th from early in the morning until mid-afternoon. A strong upper-level shortwave that surged from the Central Rockies into the Great Plains induced rapid surface cyclogenesis across Southern Kansas. As the strengthening low pressure moved across Southeast Kansas, strong north winds sustained around 40 mph with gusts around 55 mph, combined with heavy snow to cause widespread visibilities around 1/4 mile.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 854 AM CST, on I-70, at Mile Post 206, heavy snow and high winds reduced visibilities to 1/4 mile. At 859 AM CST, a video was received, via social media, of a whiteout occurring on Highway 40 in Ellsworth. The time of the blizzard's onset is an estimate based on nearby reports just to the northwest of Ellsworth County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A blizzard swept through most of Central Kansas on the 25th from early in the morning until mid-afternoon. A strong upper-level shortwave that surged from the Central Rockies into the Great Plains induced rapid surface cyclogenesis across Southern Kansas. As the strengthening low pressure moved across Southeast Kansas, strong north winds sustained around 40 mph with gusts around 55 mph, combined with heavy snow to cause widespread visibilities around 1/4 mile.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Although only minor accumulations were reported at this time, high winds combined with the snow to restrict visibilities to 1/4 mile and cause power to flicker. At 1004 AM CST, the public reported, via Facebook, winds estimated around 50 knots combined with heavy snow to cause a whiteout in Norwich.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A north to south corridor of snow and wind, creating blizzard conditions, developed during the late evening over Southwest Nebraska, extending south into Northwest Kansas.  As the night progressed the blizzard conditions expanded across the rest of Southwest Nebraska.  The highest snowfall amount of five inches was reported where the corridor of snow first developed, near Stratton, then declined to two or three inches to the east and west.  The blizzard conditions ended from north to south.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Zero visibility was reported across Cheyenne County to the south, from the same band that was over the Dundy County.  Snowfall amount ranged from close to five inches on the eastern border to close to two inches along the southern border of the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A north to south corridor of snow and wind, creating blizzard conditions, developed during the late evening over Southwest Nebraska, extending south into Northwest Kansas.  As the night progressed the blizzard conditions expanded across the rest of Southwest Nebraska.  The highest snowfall amount of five inches was reported where the corridor of snow first developed, near Stratton, then declined to two or three inches to the east and west.  The blizzard conditions ended from north to south.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Quarter mile visibility was reported in both Oberlin and Norton from the same storm that was affecting Red Willow County.  Snowfall amounts ranged from three and a half inches at McCook, to two inches over the eastern part of the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A north to south corridor of snow and wind, creating blizzard conditions, developed during the late evening over Southwest Nebraska, extending south into Northwest Kansas.  As the night progressed the blizzard conditions expanded across the rest of Southwest Nebraska.  The highest snowfall amount of five inches was reported where the corridor of snow first developed, near Stratton, then declined to two or three inches to the east and west.  The blizzard conditions ended from north to south.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Zero visibility was reported in Cheyenne County KS from the same band that was over Hitchcock County.  Snowfall amounts ranged from five inches north of Stratton, to around three inches over the eastern part of the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A intense winter storm brought high winds and heavy snow to parts of Kansas on Sunday November 25th.  The snow began to fall as early as 4 am across parts of north central Kansas and overspread the rest of northeast Kansas through the morning.  Thunder snow was reported at times across the area with snow fall rates of 1 to 2 inches per hour at the height of the storm.  In addition, the impacts were significant not only from the intensity of the snow but from the combination of northwest winds that gusted 40-55 mph through the duration of the storm.  This produced near zero visibility and interstate 70 was closed for a time from Topeka west due to the blizzard conditions on Sunday afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several reports measured 6 to 8 inches of snow across Jackson county by storms end around 5 pm on Sunday.  The snow started to fall around 9 am with intense heavy snow falling between noon and 4 pm.  Northwest winds gusting 40-50 mph also occurred causing blizzard conditions across the county.  Hoyt reported the greatest snow depth at 8.3 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A intense winter storm brought high winds and heavy snow to parts of Kansas on Sunday November 25th.  The snow began to fall as early as 4 am across parts of north central Kansas and overspread the rest of northeast Kansas through the morning.  Thunder snow was reported at times across the area with snow fall rates of 1 to 2 inches per hour at the height of the storm.  In addition, the impacts were significant not only from the intensity of the snow but from the combination of northwest winds that gusted 40-55 mph through the duration of the storm.  This produced near zero visibility and interstate 70 was closed for a time from Topeka west due to the blizzard conditions on Sunday afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Reports from multiple agencies including law enforcement and spotters reported zero visibility due to strong winds and heavy snow between 8 am and 2 pm on Sunday morning. Thunder snow was also reported indicating the intensity of the snowfall rates which were 1-2 inches per hour.  Total snow accumulations measured and estimated 5 to 8 inches across Riley county from this storm.  The ASOS at Manhattan airport also reported visibility one quarter mile in heavy snow with winds gusting 45 to 50 mph between 9 am and 1 pm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An extremely early season blizzard impacted eastern Kansas on November 25, 2018. The snowstorm was more indicative of a storm that would affect the area in the deep winter, as opposed to the middle to late part of autumn. The storm brought between 4 and 6 inches across northeast Kansas, including the Kansas City Metro area. Further separating this storm from other typical winter storms was the strong winds that accompanied the heavy snow. Most locations through the region experienced winds in excess of 35 mph at times during the storm. The strongest wind gusts came across northeast Kansas and northwest Missouri, where 50-60 mph winds were recorded in Wyandotte County and Leavenworth County (Kansas) and at Kansas City International Airport.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Blizzard conditions started after a few hours of lightly to moderately falling snow. Once the heavy snow arrived winds gusted up to 53 mph for nearly 4 hours, creating whiteout conditions, officially measured by the ASOS at nearby KOJC and KCNU as sub-quarter mile for that duration. Despite the heavy impacts from this system affecting Thanksgiving weekend return traffic, no serious injuries occurred from this event.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Snow overspread the state as a short wave trough lifted out of the southern Rockies. There was a moderate amount of blowing and drifting of the snow.  In general amounts were less than three inches.  However, there was a heavier band that stretch from near Ulysses to near Scott City where 4 to 5.5 inches were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow amounts ranged from 2 to 3 inches across the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front and weak upper level shortwave moved across parts of the area during the early morning.  While there was only 1 to 3 inches of snow, winds were in excess of 60 MPH with gusts to 70 MPH which caused blizzard conditions during the morning hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The visibility dropped to less than 1/4 of a mile and occasionally to zero for about 4 hours as snow and high winds swept through the area.  Snowfall was 1 to 3 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A intense winter storm brought high winds and heavy snow to parts of Kansas on Sunday November 25th.  The snow began to fall as early as 4 am across parts of north central Kansas and overspread the rest of northeast Kansas through the morning.  Thunder snow was reported at times across the area with snow fall rates of 1 to 2 inches per hour at the height of the storm.  In addition, the impacts were significant not only from the intensity of the snow but from the combination of northwest winds that gusted 40-55 mph through the duration of the storm.  This produced near zero visibility and interstate 70 was closed for a time from Topeka west due to the blizzard conditions on Sunday afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Reports from multiple agencies including law enforcement and KDOT reported zero visibility due to strong winds and heavy snow between 5am and 10am on Sunday morning.  Total snow accumulations estimated 5 to 10 inches across the county.

Other measurements and estimates ranged from 5 to 7 inches across the county.  Winds gusted 40 to 50 mph during the snowfall causing blizzard conditions especially between noon and 4 pm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A north to south corridor of snow and wind, creating blizzard conditions, developed during the late evening over Northwest Kansas, extending north into Southwest Nebraska.  As the night progressed the blizzard conditions expanded across the rest of Northwest Kansas.  The highest snowfall amount of five and a half inches was reported where the corridor of snow first developed, which ran from Bird City and Ludell south to Edson then southeast to Hoxie and Quinter.  The snowfall declined to two or three inches to the northeast and southwest.  The blizzard conditions ended from northwest to southeast.||In addition to the blizzard conditions, high winds also occurred with this winter storm at Goodland and and Hill City.  The peak gust at both locations was 59 MPH.  However the peak gust for Goodland occurred eight hours before the blizzard conditions began, due to very strong winds occurring before the snow began.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Zero visibility was reported across the county during the winter storm.  Snowfall amounts ranged from close to four inches in the eastern part of the county where the snow first developed, to two inches in the west.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong area of low pressure moved out of the central Rockies and produced snowfall of 2 to 11 inches across eastern Nebraska. Blizzard conditions were met in southeast Nebraska with measured wind gusts 40 to 53 mph and widespread whiteout conditions. NSP Troopers responded to 25 crashes, performed 110 motorist assists, and assisted other agencies with 15 incidents. Interstate 80 was closed for awhile between Lincoln and Omaha due to crashes. 1 elderly man passed away in Johnson county, indirectly related to the blizzard.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Emergency Manager reported blizzard conditions. Deputies were unable to get to stranded motorists for a while. Peak wind speeds of 45 mph. Snow amounts of 8 to 10 were reported.

The peak gust at both locations was 59 MPH.  However the peak gust for Goodland occurred eight hours before the blizzard conditions began, due to very strong winds occurring before the snow began.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: White-out conditions were reported in Oakley.  Snowfall amounts ranged from two inches in Oakley to an inch or less to the southwest.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: White-out conditions reported on Highways 383 and 36 across the county.  Snowfall amounts ranged from four inches in Norton to close to two inches along the western border.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A blizzard swept through most of Central Kansas on the 25th from early in the morning until mid-afternoon. A strong upper-level shortwave that surged from the Central Rockies into the Great Plains induced rapid surface cyclogenesis across Southern Kansas. As the strengthening low pressure moved across Southeast Kansas, strong north winds sustained around 40 mph with gusts around 55 mph, combined with heavy snow to cause widespread visibilities around 1/4 mile.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The 50-knot gust was measured by the Eisenhower Airport ASOS.

Interstate 80 was closed for awhile between Lincoln and Omaha due to crashes. 1 elderly man passed away in Johnson county, indirectly related to the blizzard.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Blizzard conditions were observed at the Nebraska City AWOS. Peak wind speeds of 40 mph were measured. Snow amounts up to 10 were reported in the county.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility ranged from near zero to a quarter mile at Highway 83 and I-70.  Snowfall amounts ranged from two to three inches across the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An extremely early season blizzard impacted eastern Kansas on November 25, 2018. The snowstorm was more indicative of a storm that would affect the area in the deep winter, as opposed to the middle to late part of autumn. The storm brought between 4 and 6 inches across northeast Kansas, including the Kansas City Metro area. Further separating this storm from other typical winter storms was the strong winds that accompanied the heavy snow. Most locations through the region experienced winds in excess of 35 mph at times during the storm. The strongest wind gusts came across northeast Kansas and northwest Missouri, where 50-60 mph winds were recorded in Wyandotte County and Leavenworth County (Kansas) and at Kansas City International Airport.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Blizzard conditions started after a few hours of lightly to moderately falling snow. Once the heavy snow arrived winds gusted up to 49 mph for nearly 6 hours, creating whiteout conditions, officially measured by the ASOS at nearby KFNB as sub-quarter mile for that duration. Despite the heavy impacts from this system affecting Thanksgiving weekend return traffic, no serious injuries occurred from this event.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A blizzard swept through most of Central Kansas on the 25th from early in the morning until mid-afternoon. A strong upper-level shortwave that surged from the Central Rockies into the Great Plains induced rapid surface cyclogenesis across Southern Kansas. As the strengthening low pressure moved across Southeast Kansas, strong north winds sustained around 40 mph with gusts around 55 mph, combined with heavy snow to cause widespread visibilities around 1/4 mile.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A blizzard was confirmed at Great Bend Airport when, at 833 AM CST, the ASOS reported heavy snow and gusts that were measured at 40 knots to cause 1/4 mile visibilities. At 1031 AM CST, the Emergency Manager estimated 6 inches in Hoisington.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A blizzard swept through most of Central Kansas on the 25th from early in the morning until mid-afternoon. A strong upper-level shortwave that surged from the Central Rockies into the Great Plains induced rapid surface cyclogenesis across Southern Kansas. As the strengthening low pressure moved across Southeast Kansas, strong north winds sustained around 40 mph with gusts around 55 mph, combined with heavy snow to cause widespread visibilities around 1/4 mile.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 810 AM CST, the Salina Airport ASOS measured gusts at exactly 50 knots 2 miles WSW of Salina. The high winds combined with heavy snow to cause 1/8 to 1/4 mile visibilities. At 900 AM CST, the Salina Airport measured a second gust at exactly 50 knots that combined with heavy snow to reduce visibilities to 1/8 mile. At 906 AM CST, a spotter 1 mile west of Salina estimated 3 to 4 inches of snow with heavy snow continuing. The heavy snow combined with high winds to reduce visibilities to a few hundred feet. At 909 AM CST, the Kansas Highway Patrol reported that I-70 was closed in both directions near and around Salina with multiple accidents west of Salina. At 951 AM CST, the Emergency Manager also reported some downed power lines in Salina. Parts of Saline County received 4 to 6 inch accumulations with drifts up to 2 feet. At 1057 AM CST, the Salina Airport ASOS measured a 54-knot gust. At 142 PM CST, the public measured a total of 6 inches on I-70 at Exit 244 6 ESE of Glendale along with drifts of unspecified depths.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A blizzard swept through most of Central Kansas on the 25th from early in the morning until mid-afternoon. A strong upper-level shortwave that surged from the Central Rockies into the Great Plains induced rapid surface cyclogenesis across Southern Kansas. As the strengthening low pressure moved across Southeast Kansas, strong north winds sustained around 40 mph with gusts around 55 mph, combined with heavy snow to cause widespread visibilities around 1/4 mile.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 757 AM CST, the McPherson Airport AWOS reported heavy snow and measured 39 knot gusts (45 mph) that restricted visibilities to 1/4 mile. At 944 AM CST, the public reported blowing snow restricting visibilities to around 100 yards. At 1018 AM CST, the public reported, via Twitter, that heavy snow and blowing snow were nearly causing a whiteout in McPherson.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A blizzard swept through most of Central Kansas on the 25th from early in the morning until mid-afternoon. As the strengthening low pressure moved across Southeast Kansas, strong north winds sustained around 40 mph with gusts around 55 mph, combined with heavy snow to cause widespread visibilities around 1/4 mile.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An MPing report was received of blowing snow that caused severe visibility restrictions.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong area of low pressure moved out of the central Rockies and produced snowfall of 2 to 11 inches across eastern Nebraska. Blizzard conditions were met in southeast Nebraska with measured wind gusts 40 to 53 mph and widespread whiteout conditions. NSP Troopers responded to 25 crashes, performed 110 motorist assists, and assisted other agencies with 15 incidents. Interstate 80 was closed for awhile between Lincoln and Omaha due to crashes. 1 elderly man passed away in Johnson county, indirectly related to the blizzard.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Around 2 of snow was reported at Milford. Peak winds were also reported around 47 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A north to south corridor of snow and wind, creating blizzard conditions, developed during the late evening over Northwest Kansas, extending north into Southwest Nebraska.  As the night progressed the blizzard conditions expanded across the rest of Northwest Kansas.  The highest snowfall amount of five and a half inches was reported where the corridor of snow first developed, which ran from Bird City and Ludell south to Edson then southeast to Hoxie and Quinter.  The snowfall declined to two or three inches to the northeast and southwest.  The blizzard conditions ended from northwest to southeast.||In addition to the blizzard conditions, high winds also occurred with this winter storm at Goodland and and Hill City.  The peak gust at both locations was 59 MPH.  However the peak gust for Goodland occurred eight hours before the blizzard conditions began, due to very strong winds occurring before the snow began.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The peak gust was reported at the Goodland airport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A blizzard occurred across most of north central Kansas on this Saturday night and Sunday. Saturday afternoon, a narrow band of snow developed, in the shape of an arc, across Nebraska to near Denver. This band formed in the deformation zone of developing low pressure. During the evening, this band expanded and moved southeast. The core of this band crossed north central Kansas between 11 PM CST Saturday and 11 AM CST Sunday, although windy conditions maintained blowing snow a little while after the snow ended. Widespread, frequent wind gusts between 45 and 55 mph were common, which severely reduced the visibility in falling and blowing snow. Near zero visibility was reported at Beloit, Lebanon, Mankato, Osborne, Phillipsburg, Smith Center, and Stockton. The strength of the winds resulted in scattered power outages across all six counties. First responders were busy responding to slide-offs and minor accidents due to slippery roads. Motorists were urged to avoid traveling. Measuring the snowfall was extremely difficult due to the wind, with most locations estimating 3 to 7 inches of accumulation. The highest estimated amounts were 8.0 inches near Hunter, 7.1 at Plainville, and 7.0 at Beloit. Snow drifted to 3 and 4 ft deep in spots. The snow and wind resulted in numerous closed or impassible roads. The Kansas Governor declared a state of emergency. Numerous churches cancelled services. Schools in Beloit, Osborne, Plainville, and Smith Center were closed Monday, and Phillipsburg schools were delayed 2 hours. ||A woman lost her life near Cawker City due to the storm. She abandoned her vehicle after it slid off the road and became stuck in a ditch on Highway 24 in Mitchell county. She succumbed from exposure to the cold and was found Tuesday, the 27th, some distance from her vehicle. ||During the daytime hours Saturday, an Arctic cold front advanced south across Nebraska. A separate low pressure system moved through Wyoming and Colorado into southwest Kansas. This low and its associated fronts moved east along the Kansas-Oklahoma border Saturday night while the Arctic front continued moving south into Kansas in its wake. The low moved into Missouri Sunday while high pressure over the Canadian Prairies begin building into Kansas. In the upper-levels, amplification was occurring with a building ridge along the West Coast. This resulted in a shortwave trough deepening and becoming a closed low over Nebraska and Kansas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall amounts across the area ranged from 4 to 8 inches.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall amounts across the area ranged from 4 to 8 inches. There was one fatality. A woman had attempted to go to work on Sunday, but due to dangerous conditions, turned back to go home. She was reported missing when she didn't report for work on Monday, and her abandoned car was found in a ditch along Highway 24 near Glen Elder State Park. Her body was found on Tuesday in a field near Waconda Lake, about 3 miles from her car.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A blizzard occurred south and east of Hastings on this Saturday night and Sunday, and near-blizzard conditions occurred, at times, in many other locations. Saturday afternoon, a narrow band of snow developed, in the shape of an arc, from Omaha through the Sandhills and then southwest to Denver. This band formed in the deformation zone of developing low pressure. During the evening, this band expanded and moved southeast, enveloping all of south central Nebraska. At 2 AM CST Sunday, the northern terminus of the snow shield began moving into south central Nebraska. By 7 AM CST, the snow had ended over most of the area, except to the south and east of Hastings. By noon, the snow had exited to the east, bringing an end to the snow there as well. Windy conditions maintained blowing snow for 3 to 5 hours after the snow ended. Widespread, frequent wind gusts between 35 and 50 mph were common, which severely reduced the visibility in falling and blowing snow, especially south and east of Hastings. Near zero visibility was reported at Clay Center, Geneva, Hebron, and Nelson. A couple locations recorded wind gusts above 50 mph, including 55 mph at Hastings, and 62 mph at Nelson. The strength of the winds resulted in scattered power outages in Phelps, Hall, Hamilton, and Merrick counties. State troopers and other first responders were busy responding to slide-offs and minor accidents due to slippery roads. Motorists were urged to avoid traveling, and many spent the night in hotels. One hotel mentioned that travelers were checking-in all night, and others that intended to travel to the region had cancelled their reservations. Despite the nasty conditions, the Grand Island and Kearney airports remained open. However, numerous churches cancelled services. A few schools in Webster, Nuckolls, and Thayer counties even delayed their start time Monday morning. Measuring the snowfall was extremely difficult due to the wind. Most locations estimated 1 to 3 inches of snow fell. The exception was southeast of Hastings where Shickley estimated 3.5 inches, Clay Center estimated 4, and Hubbell estimated 6.||During the daytime hours Saturday, an Arctic cold front advanced south across Nebraska. A separate low pressure system moved through Wyoming and Colorado into southwest Kansas. This low and its associated fronts moved east along the Kansas-Oklahoma border Saturday night while the Arctic front continued moving south in its wake. The low moved into Missouri Sunday while high pressure over the Canadian Prairies begin building into Nebraska. In the upper-levels, amplification was occurring with a building ridge along the West Coast. This resulted in a shortwave trough deepening and becoming a closed low over Nebraska and Kansas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall amounts across the area ranged from 2 to 4 inches.
